revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=December 2016}} {{Spanish name|Silang|Andaya}} {{For|the Philippine Navy ship|BRP Diego Silang (PF-9)}} {{Infobox Governor | name = Diego Silang | imagesize = | caption = | order = | office = Governor of [[Free Ilocos|Ilocos]]
[[British Occupation of the Philippines|British Philippines]] | term_start = 1762 | term_end = 1763 | vicegovernor = | predecessor = | successor = | image = | birth_name=Diego Silang y Pineda | birth_date = December 16, 1730 | birth_place = [[Aringay|Aringay, Pangasinan]], [[Captaincy General of the Philippines]]
(now [[Aringay, La Union]]) | death_date = {{death date and age|1763|5|28|1730|12|16}} | death_place = [[Bantay, Ilocos Sur]], [[Captaincy General of the Philippines]] | other_names = | spouse = [[Gabriela Silang|Josefa Gabriela Silang]] }} '''Diego Silang y Andaya''' ({{IPA-es|ˈdjeɣo si.ˈlaŋg janˈdaʝa|lang}} : December 16, 1730 – May 28, 1763) was a Filipino revolutionary leader who conspired with [[United Kingdom|British]] forces to overthrow [[Spain|Spanish]] rule in the northern [[Philippines]] and establish an independent [[Ilocano people|Ilocano]] [[Westphalian state|state]]. His revolt was fueled by grievances stemming from Spanish taxation and abuses, and by his belief in self-government, that the administration and leadership of the [[Roman Catholic church|Roman Catholic Church]] and government in the Ilocos be invested in trained Ilocano officials. He met an [[Itneg people|Itneg]] woman with the name of [[Gabriela Silang|Gabriela Cariño]]. He married her and raised a family in the Ilocos Province. == Early life == Born in [[Aringay]], [[Pangasinan]] (an area in present-day Caba or Aringay, La Union), Silang's mother was [[Ilocano people|Ilocano]]; his father was [[Pangasinan people|Pangasinense]]. Young Diego worked as a messenger for a local Castilian priest in Vigan, Ilocos Sur. Bright, passionate, and fluent in Spanish, he ferried correspondence from the Ilocos to Manila; journeys that gave him his first glimpse of colonial injustice and that planted the seed of rebellion. == Revolt == Spain allied with France during the [[Seven Years' War]], in opposition to Great Britain. The British in response sought to diminish the Spanish Empire. The seizure of Manila by British naval forces in October 1762, and the subsequent surrender of the Spanish Philippines to Britain during the [[British occupation of Manila|British occupation of the Philippines]], inspired uprisings in the farthest north of Ilocos Norte and Cagayan, where anti-Spanish sentiments festered. Though Silang initially wanted to replace Spanish functionaries in the Ilocos with native-born officials and volunteered to head Ilocano forces against the British, desperate Spanish administrators instead transferred their powers to the Catholic Bishop of Nueva Segovia (Vigan), who rejected Silang's offer. Silang's group attacked the city and imprisoned its priests. He then began an association with the British who appointed him governor of the Ilocos on their behalf and promised him military reinforcement. The British force never materialized. == Assassination == [[File:CabaLaUnionjf709.JPG|200px|thumbnail|right|Memorial of Diego Silang in his birthplace [[Caba, La Union]].]] Diego Silang was killed by one of his friends, a Spanish-Ilocano mestizo named Miguel Vicos, whom church authorities paid to assassinate Silang with the help of Pedro Becbec.Lamberto Gabriel, ''Ang Pilipinas: Heograpiya, Kasaysayan, at Pamahalaan''. 1997 {{ISBN|971-621-192-9}} He was 32 years old. == Legacy == {{main article|Gabriela Silang}} After Silang's death, his Spanish-[[Itneg]] [[Filipino mestizo|mestiza]] wife, Gabriela Silang, took command of the revolt and fought courageously. The Spanish sent a strong force against her. She was forced to retreat to Abra. Gabriela led her troops towards Vigan but was driven back. She fled again to Abra, where she was captured. Gabriela and her men were summarily hanged on September 20, 1763; she being hanged the last. == In popular culture == * Portrayed by [[Gardo Versoza]] in the 1999 TV Series ''[[Bayani (TV series)|Bayani]]'' in this episode "Diego Silang: Ang Sulat". * Portrayed by [[JC Tiuseco]] in the 2013 TV series, ''[[Indio (TV series)|Indio]]''. ==Notes== ==References== *{{cite book | author=Zaide, Gregorio F. | title=Philippine History and Government|publisher=National Bookstore Printing Press |year=1984}} *Rebecca Ramilo Ongsotto, Reena R. Ongsotto: ''Philippine History Module-based Learning''. Rex Bookstore Inc, 2. Auflage 2003, {{ISBN|971233449X}}, p. 109 ({{Google books|ITLRpPrrcykC|online copy|page=109}}) *C. Duka: ''Struggle for Freedom''. Rex Bookstore Inc, 2008, {{ISBN|9789712350450}}, p. 103 ({{Google books|4wk8yqCEmJUC|online copy|page=104}}) {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Silang, Diego}} [[Category:1730 births]] [[Category:1763 deaths]] [[Category:British invasion of Manila]] [[Category:People from Pangasinan]] [[Category:People of Spanish colonial Philippines]] [[Category:Paramilitary Filipinos]] [[Category:Ilocano people]]

{{Infobox NFL player |name=Domenik Hixon |image=Domenik Hixon with Panthers.jpg |image_size=150 |caption=Hixon represents the Panthers at the Do the Right Thing 2013 Awards |number=12, 87 |position=[[Wide Receiver]] / [[Special teamer]] |birth_date={{birth date and age|1984|10|8}} |birth_place=[[Neunkirchen am Potzberg|Neunkirchen]], [[West Germany]] |death_date= |death_place= |height_ft = 6 |height_in = 2 |weight_lbs = 197 |high_school = [[Whitehall-Yearling High School|Whitehall (OH) Whitehall-Yearling]] |college=[[Akron Zips football|Akron]] |draftyear=2006 |draftround=4 |draftpick=130 |pastteams= * [[Denver Broncos]] ({{NFL Year|2006}}–{{NFL Year|2007}}) * [[New York Giants]] ({{NFL Year|2007}}–{{NFL Year|2012}}) * [[Carolina Panthers]] ({{NFL Year|2013}}) * [[Chicago Bears]] ({{NFL Year|2014}})* |pastteamsnote = yes |highlights= * Second-team All-[[Mid-American Conference|MAC]] (2005) * 2× [[Super Bowl|Super Bowl Champion]] ([[Super Bowl XLII|XLII]], [[Super Bowl XLVI|XLVI]]) |statlabel1=Receptions |statvalue1=109 |statlabel2=Receiving yards |statvalue2=1,460 |statlabel3=Total return yards |statvalue3=2,563 |statlabel4=Total touchdowns |statvalue4=9 |nfl=HIX462619 }} '''Domenik Hixon''' (born October 8, 1984) is a former [[American football]] [[wide receiver]] and [[return specialist]] in the [[National Football League]] (NFL). He was drafted by the [[Denver Broncos]] in the fourth round of the [[2006 NFL Draft]]. He played [[college football]] at [[Akron Zips football|Akron]]. He was also a member of [[New York Giants]], with whom he became a two-time [[Super Bowl]] winner against the [[New England Patriots]] twice, as well as, a member of the [[Carolina Panthers]] and the [[Chicago Bears]].
==Early years== Hixon was born to an [[African American]] father and a [[Germany|German]] mother. He attended [[Whitehall-Yearling High School]] in [[Whitehall, Ohio]] and was a [[Letterman (sports)|letterman]] in [[High school football|football]], [[basketball]], [[Track and field|track]], and [[baseball]]. In basketball, he was named Honorable Mention All-State as a [[point guard]]. In track, he cleared 6-5 in the [[high jump]] event.
Hixon was a high school teammate of [[NFL]] [[defensive back]] [[Keiwan Ratliff]].
==College career== Hixon was one of [[Charlie Frye]]'s passing weapons during his first 3 years at Akron. In the 2005 MAC Championship game, [[Luke Getsy]] found Hixon for what would be the game winning 36 yard touchdown pass with 11 seconds remaining in the fourth quarter, earning Akron its first MAC Championship in school history.
==Professional career==
===Denver Broncos=== Hixon played 4 games for the [[Denver Broncos]] to start the [[2007 NFL season|2007 season]] then was released in early October. He functioned as the team's starting kick returner. At the start of the second quarter in the first game of the season against the [[Buffalo Bills]], tight end [[Kevin Everett]] suffered a serious spinal cord injury while tackling Hixon.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2007/football/nfl/09/10/bc.fbn.bills.everetthur.ap/index.html?cnn=yes |title=Everett's injury 'catastrophic' |accessdate=2007-09-11 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070920060906/http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2007/football/nfl/09/10/bc.fbn.bills.everetthur.ap/index.html?cnn=yes |archivedate=September 20, 2007 |df= }}</ref> Everett had a near-full recovery after a grim prognosis but never played another NFL game.<ref>http://www.buffalobills.com/news/article-2/Kevin-Everett-five-years-later/5222c099-6845-49bd-ba77-2726fb7ca0d1</ref>
===New York Giants=== The [[New York Giants]] quickly signed Hixon and soon he took over the main kickoff returning duties. Domenik had one reception for 5 yards against the [[Minnesota Vikings]] on November 25. He made his mark by returning a kickoff 74 yards for a [[touchdown]] in the Giants' 2007 regular season finale against the undefeated [[New England Patriots]]. Hixon's touchdown put the Giants ahead 14-10 in the 2nd quarter, but the Giants lost 38-35.
As the main kickoff returner, Hixon returned 10 kickoffs for an average of 25.3 yards during the Giants' run to [[Super Bowl XLII]]. His returns provided the Giants with good field position and helped propel their offense into the end zone on several occasions. He recovered a critical fumble late in the 4th quarter of the NFC Championship game on January 20 at frigid [[Lambeau Field]], a game the Giants eventually won in overtime. Hixon also recorded 2 special teams tackles in the [[2007 NFL Playoffs|2007 playoffs]].
Hixon later broke out in the Giants second [[preseason]] game against the [[Cleveland Browns]], catching two touchdown passes and then returned an 82-yard kickoff for a touchdown, all in the first quarter.
In week 5 of the [[2008 NFL season|2008 season]], Hixon was forced to start after Giants [[wide receiver]] [[Plaxico Burress]] was suspended for breaking team rules.
Hixon would have 4 catches for 102 yards and a touchdown in his first career start. He left the game late in the first half after suffering a concussion.
In Week 14, Hixon would again be placed in the starting role for the rest of the season, due to the suspension of Burress for conduct detrimental to the team after suffering an accidental self-inflicted gunshot wound to his leg.
On June 16, 2010, Hixon suffered a torn ACL at a practice at the Giants' new home in the New Meadowlands, and was pronounced out for the season. He was waived/injured and subsequently placed on the [[injured reserve]] list on July 17.
On August 13, 2011, Hixon returned to the team in the New York Giants and Carolina Panthers preseason game.
On week 2 of the [[2011 NFL season|2011 Season]], Hixon tore his ACL while making a spectacular bobbling catch in the endzone. He was declared out for the season.
In his career, he's made 31 special teams tackles, caught 63 passes for 838 yards (13.3 avg) and 4 touchdowns, ran 3 times on reverse plays for 18 yards, returned 51 punts for 561 yards and a touchdown and 80 kickoffs for 1,966 yards and a touchdown.
On March 3, 2012 Hixon re-signed with the New York Giants.
===Carolina Panthers=== At the start of free agency, Hixon reportedly turned down an offer from the [[Detroit Lions]]. After receiving interest from the [[Cleveland Browns]] and [[Carolina Panthers]], Hixon ultimately agreed to terms on a one-year deal with the Panthers on April 3, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|work=NFL.com|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap1000000157088/article/domenik-hixon-carolina-panthers-reportedly-strike-deal|title=Domenik Hixon, Panthers reportedly strike contract|first=Dan|last=Hanzus|date=April 3, 2013|accessdate=2013-04-03}}</ref> In a week 16 game against the New Orleans Saints, Hixon caught a game winning 14 yard TD pass from [[Cam Newton]] to give the Panthers a 17-13 win and give them first place in the [[NFC South]].
===Chicago Bears=== On March 13, 2014, Hixon signed a one-year contract with the [[Chicago Bears]].<ref>[http://www.chicagobears.com/news/article-1/Bears-add-DE-Young-WR-Hixon/816d48ca-981c-4f95-927d-f7b024786274 Bears add DE Young, WR Hixon]</ref> On May 27, 2014, during the Organized Team Activities (OTA), he suffered a torn [[Anterior cruciate ligament|ACL]] for the third time in his career.<ref>{{cite web|work=NFL.com|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap2000000353753/article/chicago-bears-domenik-hixon-suffers-third-torn-acl|title=Chicago Bears' Domenik Hixon suffers third torn ACL|first=Dan|last=Hanzus|date=May 27, 2014|accessdate=2014-05-27}}</ref>
===Retirement=== On the same day that his injury during the Bears' OTAs was announced, Hixon announced through his [[Facebook]] page that he would be retiring from the NFL.<ref>{{cite web|work=Giants101.com|url=http://www.giants101.com/2014/05/28/ex-giant-domenik-hixon-suffers-third-acl-tear-announces-retirement-from-nfl|title=Ex-Giant Domenik Hixon Suffers Third ACL Tear; Announces Retirement from NFL|date=May 28, 2014|first=Dan|last=Benton|accessdate=2014-06-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|work=NBCSports.com|url=http://profootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2014/05/27/domenik-hixon-says-he-has-suffered-another-acl-tear/|title=Domenik Hixon says he has suffered another ACL tear|first=Mike|last=Wilkening|date=May 27, 2014|accessdate=2014-06-05}}</ref> On June 3, 2014, the Bears terminated Hixon's contract with an injury settlement.<ref>{{cite web|work=ESPN.com|url=http://espn.go.com/blog/chicago-bears/post/_/id/4692549/bears-sign-edwards-spurlock|title=Bears sign Edwards, Spurlock|date=June 3, 2014|first=Michael|last=Wright|accessdate=2014-06-05}}</ref>
==Charity work== Hixon hosts the Next Level Football Camp, with co-founder Anthony Jordan, which provides underprivileged children in the Columbus, Ohio area with a summer football training program.<ref>[http://www.nlfcamp.org/next-level-founders.html Next Level Football Camp profile] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140202122839/http://www.nlfcamp.org/next-level-founders.html |date=February 2, 2014 }}</ref> In the past, the camp has been staffed by current and former NFL players such as [[Lance Moore]], [[Chase Blackburn]], and [[Gary Joshua]].
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[http://www.chicagobears.com/team/roster/Domenik-Hixon/5170597c-2c1b-489d-b40f-ed218a0319cb Chicago Bears bio] *[http://www.panthers.com/team/roster/Domenik-Hixon/ced914f3-e176-47f3-9fd1-9239f76baa0d Carolina Panthers bio]

{{Infobox artist | name = Elliott Linwood | image = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age |1956|7|14|}} | birth_place = [[Lowell, Massachusetts]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[Americans|American]] | field = [[Photography]], [[Sculpture]], [[Conceptual Art]] | movement = Stand Up Theory }} '''Elliott Linwood''' (born July 14, 1956) is an [[Americans|American]] conceptual artist known for his large-scale photo grids<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.visualaids.org/artists/detail/elliott-linwood|title=Elliott Linwood|last=AIDS|first=Visual|website=Visual AIDS|language=en|access-date=2017-06-01}}</ref> and cross-referencing sculptural installations.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.aidsart.org/elliott-linwood|title=The Art of AIDS Prevention|website=The Art of AIDS Prevention|access-date=2017-06-01}}</ref> He is based in [[San Diego|San Diego, California]].
== Early life, career and education == Linwood was born July 14, 1956 in Lowell and attended Billerica Memorial High School<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://archive.org/details/warriorbillerica1974unse|title=1974 Billerica Memorial High School Year Book, pg. 66|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> in Massachusetts before moving to [[New York City]] when he was nineteen. He came out as a gay man just before the [[HIV/AIDS|AIDS]] epidemic struck. Testing positive for the HIV virus in the early 1980s led him to a life of activism around this condition. Linwood worked in the field of electronic publishing most of his life. He earned dual Bachelor degrees in sociocultural anthropology and philosophy from [[New York University]] (NYU) in 1982, then attended the [[University of Chicago]] through 1983. He earned dual Masters degrees in Arts and Education from [[San Francisco State University]]’s (SFSU) Interdisciplinary Arts Program in 1993. He attended [[New College School of Law]] in San Francisco through a state-funded HIV empowerment grant,<ref>{{Cite news|url=|title=Law school graduation a first for four New College students|last=Laird|first=Cynthia|date=May 24, 2001|work=San Francisco Bay Area Reporter|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> and became a California attorney in 2002.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://members.calbar.ca.gov/fal/Member/Detail/220890|title=State Bar of CA :: Elliott Linwood|last=California|first=The State Bar of|website=members.calbar.ca.gov|language=en-US|access-date=2017-06-01}}</ref>
== Influences == Linwood was influenced by the work of [[Christine Tamblyn]], a feminist media artist and critic, who was Linwood’s instructor and mentor at SFSU. Tamblyn studied under [[Allan Kaprow]], the originator of [[Happening]]s and Life Art,<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2017-02-14|title=Allan Kaprow|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Allan_Kaprow&oldid=765421639|journal=Wikipedia|language=en}}</ref> at the [[University of California, San Diego|University of California San Diego]].<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2017-02-17|title=Christine Tamblyn|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Christine_Tamblyn&oldid=766041198|journal=Wikipedia|language=en}}</ref> Through Tamblyn’s tutelage Linwood learned about the performative aspects of Life Art. In a 1991 interview with her Linwood wrote, “In her role as art instructor, Christine Tamblyn teaches that happenings, process-oriented conceptual art, body art, feminist art, persona art, even documentation art . . . can all be considered ‘Life Art."<ref>{{Cite news|url=|title=Life Art: Performing Christine Tamblyn|last=Linwood|first=Elliott|date=1991|work=The San Francisco Sentinel|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> At NYU Linwood was also introduced to works of anthropologist [[Gregory Bateson]] which analyzed rituals<ref>{{Cite book|title=Naven: A Survey of the Problems Suggested by a Composite Picture of the Culture of a New Guinea Tribe Drawn from Three Points of View|last=Bateson|first=Gregory|publisher=Stanford University Press|year=1936|isbn=0-80470520-8|location=|pages=}}</ref> using [[cybernetics]] and [[Systems theory in anthropology|systems theory]] models.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Steps to an Ecology of Mind: Collected Essays in Anthropology, Psychiatry, Evolution and Epistemology|last=Bateson|first=Gregory|publisher=University of Chicago Press|year=1976|isbn=0-226-03905-6|location=|pages=}}</ref> These ideas, combined with his practical knowledge of computer programming and design of index and list publications, informed his art practice.
Film director [[Blue (1993 film)|Dereck Jarman’s movie ''Blue'']]'','' also influenced work that Linwood presented in “Share Your Vision,”<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.visualaids.org/projects/detail/share-your-vision|title=Share Your Vision catalog|last=|first=|date=2003|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> for which he won first place and an award. This outreach exhibition was organized to raise awareness about [[Cytomegalovirus retinitis|CMV retinitis]], a preventable condition that causes blindness in people with compromised immune systems. Organized by Visual AIDS<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.visualaids.org/|title=Visual AIDS, NY, NY|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> and [[Hoffmann-La Roche|Roche Pharmaceuticals]], the show was presented at [[Artists Space]] in New York City in 2003. An homage to Jarman’s film (consisting entirely of a blue lit movie screen with dialog of the artist visiting doctors about his loss of sight) appears in Linwood’s ''Halos,'' which reads as blurred silhouettes like dark pupils immersed in a field of iris blue light.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.visualaids.org/gallery/detail/460|title=Visual AIDS Online Gallery|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Teaching == Linwood developed core graduate curricula in Life Art which he taught at SFSU. These seminars explored conceptual and de-materialized art forms,<ref>{{Cite book|title=Six Years: The Dematerialization of the Art Object from 1966 to 1972|last=Lippard|first=Lucy|publisher=University of California Press|year=1997|isbn=978-0520210134|location=|pages=}}</ref> and ephemera (printed matter, video, digital communication, etc.) generated around performance spectacles, as documentary records, which might then be commodified.<ref>{{Cite news|url=|title=Performance Artist Nao Bustamante's Wake Up Calls|last=Linwood|first=Elliott|date=1994|work=San Francisco Bay Area Reporter|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
==Cultural criticism == Linwood wrote for ''High Performance Magazine'' in Los Angeles, and the ''Bay Area Reporter'', ''The Sentinel'' and ''PhotoMetro'' in San Francisco from 1990 to 1994. Some of the writers and artists Linwood wrote about include [[Christine Tamblyn]], [[Nao Bustamante]], [[Sheree Rose]], [[Millie Wilson]], [[Carrie Mae Weems]], [[Diamanda Galás|Diamanda Gallas]], The Theory Girls, [[Jerome Caja]], Cliff Hengst, [[Paul Monette]], [[Sapphire (author)|Sapphire]], [[Dodie Bellamy]], [[Kevin Killian]], [[Justin Chin]], The Hittite Empire, [[Joe Goode]] and others.
== "Stand Up Theory" == Describing the phenomenon of witnessing several prominent Bay Area theorists using body art<ref>{{Cite news|url=|title=Stand Up Theory|last=Linwood|first=Elliott|date=1990|work=High Performance Magazine|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> and other types of performance to demonstrate the gaps between subcultural concerns and dominant cultural assumptions,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.oac.cdlib.org/findaid/ark:/13030/kt6779q51c/|title=The Online Archive of California Guide to Christine Tamblyn Papers|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Linwood coined the term “Stand Up Theory”<ref>{{Cite book|title=Reprogramming the Stage: A Heuristic for Posthuman Performance|last=Gingrich-Philbrook|first=Craig|publisher=Text and Performance Quarterly|year=2015|isbn=|location=|pages=Vol. 25, Issue 4}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Writing Performance: Poeticizing the Researcher's Body|last=Pelas|first=Ronald J.|publisher=Southern Illinois University Press|year=1999|isbn=0-8093-2235-8|location=|pages=}}</ref> to highlight how these performance artists highjacked the mic to seduce, ambush, and educate their audiences.<ref>{{Cite news|url=|title=Performance Artist Nao Bustamante's Wake Up Calls|last=Linwood|first=Elliott|date=1994|work=San Francisco Bay Area Reporter|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> Linwood’s sculptural works deploy these strategies. Of ''Initiation,'' a sculpture referencing AIDS and made of honey, Tamblyn wrote, “The piece adroitly expressed the melancholic sensibility that the disease evokes by capitalizing on honey’s association with seduction, entrapment and preservation.”<ref>{{Cite news|url=|title=Boys Club, Craft Hut, Carnival or Cyberspace?|last=Tamblyn|first=Christine|date=1993|work=High Performance Magazine|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
== Photo grids & cross-referencing installations == [[File:Halos.jpg|thumb|Elliott Linwood's ''Halos,'' part of an exhibition Share Your Vision, 2003]] Linwood is best known for his large-scale photo grids composed of original and found images culled from the environment, the Internet, cult movies and magazine ads. His cross-referencing installations are similarly made up of found and fabricated objects.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.visualaids.org/artists/detail/elliott-linwood|title=Visual AIDS, Elliott Linwood (detail)|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Both bodies of work share similar characteristics, such as a non-linear viewpoint and an indexical relationship between the images and objects presented, which in turn point to things outside their framing device.<ref>{{Cite news|url=|title=Elliott Linwood at Morphos|last=Hormel|first=Julie|date=1994|work=Visions Art Quarterly|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> His sculptures, ''Initiation,'' and ''Resistance,'' and his projection ''Citizen Pan,'' were displayed in ''A Living Testament of the Blood Fairies'' at Artists Space in New York in 1997,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://artistsspace.org/exhibitions/a-living-testament-of-the-blood-fairies|title=A Living Testament of the Blood Fairies at Artists Space|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> an exhibition that Frank Moore curated around text-based work.
== Reception == [[File:Swarm_Installation.jpg|thumb|Elliott Linwood, 1993. Left: "Initiation," Right: "Resistance," part of an A Living Testament of the Blood Fairies, 1996]] Holland Cotter in the April 1997 ''Art in America'' wrote of the exhibition: “The bittersweet tone was set [by] pieces by Elliott Linwood which opened the show. One was a slide projection of words from Sir J.M. Barrie’s ''Peter Pan:'' ‘When the first baby laughed for the first time, the laugh broke into a thousand pieces and spread over the entire world, and that was the beginning of fairies. But all the fairies are dying now because children know such a lot they don’t believe or laugh anymore.’”<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.artinamericamagazine.com/news-features/magazine/from-the-archives-art-aids-the-stuff-life-is-made-of/print/|title=Art & AIDS - The Stuff Life is Made Of|last=Cotter|first=Holland|date=1997|work=Art in America|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> Bill Arning, in the December 10, 1996 ''Village Voice'' also wrote about Linwood’s work in the exhibition, “This synthesis of queer politics, camp humour, dark children’s stories, and magic sets us up for a different kind of AIDS show than New York has seen before.”<ref>{{Cite news|url=|title=Days With Artt|last=Arning|first=Bill|date=1996|work=Village Voice|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
== Awards == * 1994, California Arts Council Fellowship, Sacramento, CA<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.arts.ca.gov/|title=California Arts Council|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> * 1994, John Caldwell Award for Excellence administered by Visual AID, San Francisco, CA<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://visualaid.org/|title=Visual AID San Francisco|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> * 1996, Art Matter Grant and Artists Space Grant, New York, NY * 2003, Share Your Vision Award presented by Visual AIDS and funded by Roche Pharmaceuticals, New York, NY<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://artdaily.com/news/7515/Visual-AIDS-Presents-Share-Your-Vision#.WTF49hPysUE|title=Visual AIDS Presents Share Your Vision|last=|first=|date=|work=ArtDaily.org|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
== Further reading == * Strong, Strong (2003). “Sharing a Vision,” ''Art and Understanding,'' December, p. 21, repro. * Forbes, Rhomylly (2003). “Living Testament,” ''Art and Understanding,'' November, pp. 20–21 * Gould, Claudia (1998). ''5000 Artists Return to Artists Space: 25 Years,'' Artists Space, New York, NY, p. 293 repro. * Cotter, Holland (1997). “The Stuff Life is Made of,” ''Art in America,'' April, pp. 50–51, repro. * Arning, Arning (1996). “Days with Art,” ''Village Voice,'' December 10, p. 95 * ''Art in America'' (1996). “Previews,” August, p. 25 * Walker, Hamza (1995). ''Better Living Through Chemistry,'' Randolph Street Gallery, Chicago, IL, repro. * Hormel, Julie (1994). ''Visions Art Quarterly,'' Winter'','' pp. 336–37, repro. * Roth, David M. (1994). “Marked Man,” ''Artweek,'' November 3, p. 12, repro. * Wolf, Sara (1994). “Corpus Memorandum,” ''Visions Art Quarterly,'' Summer, p. 22 * Darling, Michael (1994). “Skin Deep,” ''Artweek'', February 3, back cover * Levi Strauss, David (1993). “Review,” ''Artforum'', “summer, pp. 114-115 * Tamblyn, Christine (1993). “Boys Club, Crafthut, Carnival or Cyberspace?,” ''High Performance,'' Summer'','' pp. 60, 62, repro. * Roche, Harry (1993). “Tongue in Cheek,” ''San Francisco Sentinel,'' August 25, p. 28, repro. * Helfand, Glen (1993). “Like a Den of Inequity,” ''San Francisco Weekly,'' August 4, p. 13, repro. * Fazzolari, Bruno (1992). “Rites of Suffering,” ''Artweek,'' December 17, repro.

{{more footnotes|date=January 2014}} {{distinguish|George Magheru}} [[Image:Gheorghe Magheru desen.png|thumb|250px|Gheorghe Magheru]]
General '''Gheorghe Magheru''' ({{IPA-ro|ˈɡe̯orɡe maˈɡeru}}; 1802, [[Albeni|Bârzeiul de Gilort]], [[Gorj County]] – 23 March 1880) was a [[Romanians|Romanian]] revolutionary and soldier from [[Wallachia]], and political ally of [[Nicolae Bălcescu]].
==A Pandur and radical conspirator==
Magheru began his activities as an [[Oltenia]]n [[hajduk]] in the area around [[Băilești]], and led his group into volunteering for the [[Imperial Russia]]n side in the [[Russo-Turkish War (1828–1829)|Russo-Turkish War]] — playing a part in the almost impossible victory of the small Russian vanguard under general [[Friedrich Caspar von Geismar|Geismar]] over the dominating Ottoman forces at the battle of Băileşti 26—27 of September 1828. For his personal contribution, Magheru was decorated with the [[Order of St. Anna|Order of Saint Anne III class]] — and the [[Gold Sword for Bravery|golden sable ″For Bravery″]] to wear it — by the personal edict of [[Tsar]] [[Nicholas I of Russia|Nicholas I]].
He was one of the first [[Vladimirescu's Pandurs|Pandurs]] to join the [[Wallachian uprising of 1821|Wallachian uprising]] of 1821 under the leadership of [[Tudor Vladimirescu]]. After the latter's assassination and the rebellion's failure, he returned to life as a local [[outlaw]], only to join the Wallachian Army after a few years.
A competent soldier, Magheru went through several ranks in quick succession; at the same time, his past and career made him an important asset for the young radicals, who quickly won him for their side. He joined the [[Freemasonry]]-inspired ''Frăţia'' ("Brotherhood") secret society, founded in 1834 by Bălcescu, [[Christian Tell]], and [[Ion Ghica]], one which aimed to counter the arbitrary rule of [[Alexandru Ghica]], and then plotting against [[Gheorghe Bibescu]].
==Râureni== After the outbreak of the [[1848 Wallachian Revolution]], Magheru served in the [[Provisional government]] formed by the radicals.
He is noted for organizing the revolutionary and Pandur army camp in Râureni—on the grounds belonging to the [[Schitu Troianu]] Monastery, at the time near [[Râmnicu Vâlcea]] (and now part of the city).
Magheru intended to use the army camp as a base for opposing threats to the Revolution, as early as the summer of that year. However, when the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] troops swept into [[Bucharest]] in September, he ordered his troops to disband. In this, he probably followed the advice of the United Kingdom [[Consul (representative)|consul]] in the Wallachian capital. The pro-Ottoman attitude remained prevalent among revolutionaries: they had been well received by the Turks, who saw them as a means to oppose the overwhelming Russian influence over the [[Danubian Principalities]], and were probably right in seeing the Turkish move as prompted exclusively by Russian requests (with [[Abd-ul-Mejid I]] careful not to leave the countries opened to the full force of Russian repression, which soon joined the Turkish armies in the occupation). This created the [[paradox]] of Russia enforcing [[Conservatism|conservative]] policies in Wallachia and [[Moldavia]], while most revolutionaries were taking refuge in [[Istanbul]]. Magheru was very likely aware of such nuances, and he probably thought it best not to provoke a violent response.
==Exile== In exile in Paris (mainly), Magheru was involved in many activities of the Wallachian [[émigré]]s. He expressed his concern that the [[Transylvania]]n [[The Revolutions of 1848 in the Habsburg areas|Revolution of Romanian Austrian subjects]], aimed at the separatist [[Hungary|Hungarian]] government, was likely to provoke the Romanian fighters under [[Avram Iancu]] to side with a Russian intervention, thus making it impossible for Wallachia to negotiate or fight its way out of the occupation.
He approached the Hungarian leader [[Lajos Kossuth]] in January 1849, with a project that would have replaced the tight [[Centralized government|centralization]] with a [[confederation]] between Hungary and a more Romanian than not Transylvania.
The project was ignored by both sides: the Transylvanian Romanians thought of themselves as loyal subjects of the [[Habsburg]] Crown, and had already suffered waves of violence after [[Józef Bem]]'s armies marched into the region (in the very same project, Magheru asked that Kossuth renounce the politics of [[political repression|repression]] and [[revolutionary terror]]).
==Later life and legacy==
Magheru returned to Wallachia and was active in ''[[Partida Naţională]]'', the movement working for the Union of Moldavia and Wallachia (it was largely composed of former 1848-activists in the two countries). Their political ideal was fulfilled on 24 January 1859, when the already [[List of Moldavian rulers|Prince]] of Moldavia [[Alexandru Ioan Cuza]] was elected in [[Bucharest]].
One of the main arteries in Bucharest bears Magheru's name (''see [[Bulevardul Magheru]]''), and the campsite in Râureni is now a museum. He is honored on a postage stamp<ref>World Association for the Development of Philately, [http://www.wnsstamps.ch/stamps/RO001.05/en.html Postage stamp featuring Gheorghe Magheru]</ref> issued by the [[Poşta Română|Romanian Postal Service]].
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== *Liviu Maior, ''1848-1849. Români şi unguri în revoluţie'', Bucharest, Editura Enciclopedică, 1998
{{Authority control}}

{{Infobox person | name = Hubert Looser | image = Hubert_Looser.jpg | caption = Art collector Hubert Looser | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1938|4|5}} | birth_place = [[Vilters-Wangs|Vilters]], [[Switzerland]] | residence = [[Zürich]] | education = [[Columbia University]] (M.B.A.) | occupation = Swiss [[Businessperson|businessman]], [[Philanthropy|philanthropist]] and [[Private collection|art collector]] | spouse = Ursula Looser Stingelin | children = 2 }} '''Hubert Looser''' (born 5 April 1938 in [[Vilters-Wangs|Vilters]], [[Switzerland]])<ref name="A">{{cite web |url=http://www.altertuemliches.at/biografie/hubert-looser |title=Hubert Looser |publisher=FindART |access-date=26 April 2018}}</ref> is a former Swiss [[Businessperson|businessman]], [[Philanthropy|philanthropist]] and [[Private collection|art collector]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.museum-folkwang.de/fileadmin/_BE_Gruppe_Folkwang/Dokumente/2016_Pressemitteilungen/Looser/PM_Looser_MuseumFolkwang_Biografie.pdf |title=Biografie Hubert Looser |publisher=Museum Folkwang |access-date=26 April 2018}}</ref> Looser was President of Walter Rentsch Holding AG and ELCO Looser Holding AG. Today Looser is active as a member of the board of the Hubert Looser Foundation.
== Life == Looser was the sixth born of seven children in 1938 in the Swiss town of Vilters, where he also grew up and attended school. His parents were [[Entrepreneurship|entrepreneurs]] and had built the company ELCO. After Looser had earned his MBA from [[Columbia University]] [[New York (state)|New York]],<ref name="A" /> he joined his parents company in 1964 and was responsible for the establishment and leadership of the ELCO Group in [[France]], [[Belgium]] and [[Luxembourg]] until 1980.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nzz.ch/zuerich/zuercher_kultur/das-kunsthaus-muss-spannender-werden-1.18090779 |title=Das Kunsthaus muss spannender werden |author=Samuel Herzog, Urs Steiner |date=1 June 2013 |publisher=Neue Zürcher Zeitung (NZZ) |access-date=26 April 2018}}</ref>
During this time, the founding of Remaco AG for business mediation and the takeover of Walter Rentsch AG in the field of office technology took place. In 1973, Looser took over the management of Walter Rentsch AG with 120 employees, which at his resignation in 1992, consisted of 1,200 employees. 1990/92 Looser resigned as president of the corporate groups Walter Rentsch AG and ELCO Looser Holding AG.<ref name="B">{{cite web |url=http://fondation-hubert-looser.ch/Literatur/pdf/Der_Sammler_Lebenslauf.pdf |title=Lebenslauf Hubert Looser |date=1 March 2017 |publisher=Fondation Hubert Looser |access-date=26 April 2018}}</ref>
After selling his company shares, Hubert Looser became increasingly involved in the Fondation Hubert Looser, which he co-founded in 1988 and in which he still serves as president and financially supports his fortune with around 40 worldwide [[aid]] projects. Among other things, came the realization of projects for people with disabilities and children in need, as well as training support for young people in countries such as [[Cambodia]], [[Albania]] and [[Romania]] or [[HIV/AIDS|AIDS]] projects in [[South Africa]], [[Zimbabwe]] and [[Nigeria]].<ref name="B" />
Looser is married with Ursula Looser Stingelin, a father of two children from a previous marriage and lives in Zurich.<ref name="A" />
== Art collection == During his stay in Paris in 1957 in order to learn the language, posters from an [[Impressionism|Impressionist]] exhibition made a big impression on him and he went to museums around the world whenever he had the time. In his twenties, Looser completed various study trips during his training period to [[Mexico]], [[Japan]], [[Paris]], [[London]] or [[New York (state)|New York]] and laid the foundation of his passion for collecting art. However, his collections first 200 works were mostly Swiss art. Today, Hubert Looser, is considered to be an outstanding private art collector in the Swiss area. His collections main focus is on works of [[surrealism]], [[Abstract expressionism]] and [[minimalism]]. One of [[Willem de Kooning]]'s largest collections outside of the [[United States|US]] is as part of the collection. The museum-suitable works of the collection were introduced in 2008 to the Fondation Hubert Looser, which makes this cultural asset available to the public as a permanent exhibition at the [[Kunsthaus Zürich]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.blick.ch/life/kunst-kunsthaus-zuerich-erhaelt-74-zeitgenoessische-werke-als-dauerleihgabe-id1854822.html |title=Kunsthaus Zürich erhält 74 zeitgenössische Werke als Dauerleihgabe |publisher=Blick |access-date=26 April 2018}}</ref>

{{DEFAULTSORT:Looser, Hubert}}

[[Hacker (computer security)|Hacker]]

[[Red team|Red Team]]{{cite web|title=Black Hat USA 2013|url=https://www.blackhat.com/us-13/training/red-team-training.html|website=www.blackhat.com}} }} '''Iftach Ian Amit''' (Hebrew: יפתח איאן עמית) is an Israeli [[Hacker (computer security)|Hacker]]{{cite news | last= | first=| title =קבוצת Defcon Israel בכנס Hackathon ראשון| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language =Hebrew | publisher =Geektime| date =28 June 2011| url =http://www.geektime.co.il/defcon-israel-hackathon/| accessdate =7 June 2016}}/[[computer security]]{{cite news|last=Leyden|first=John|title=Hackers exploit Neosploit to booby trap BBC, US postal service|newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = English| publisher = [[The Register]]|date = 3 Oct 2008|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2008/10/03/neosploit_powered_mass_hack_attack/|accessdate=7 June 2016}} researcher and practitioner. He is one of the co-founders of the Tel Aviv [[DEF CON]] Group DC9723, the Penetration Testing Execution Standard, and presented at [[hacker (computer security)|hacker]] conventions such as DEF CON,{{cite web|last1=Tangent|first1=The Dark|title=DEF CON® Hacking Conference - DEF CON 17 Archive|url=https://defcon.org/html/links/dc-archives/dc-17-archive.html#Amit|website=defcon.org|accessdate=7 June 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Tangent|first1=The Dark|title=DEF CON® Hacking Conference - DEF CON 18 Archive|url=https://www.defcon.org/html/links/dc-archives/dc-18-archive.html#Amit|website=www.defcon.org}}{{cite news | last=Greene | first=Tim| title =Defcon: VoIP makes a good platform for controlling botnets| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =[[Network World]]| date =9 August 2011| url =http://www.networkworld.com/article/2180023/uc-voip/defcon--voip-makes-a-good-platform-for-controlling-botnets.html| accessdate=7 June 2016}} [[Black Hat Briefings|Black Hat]],{{cite web|title=Black Hat : Black Hat Speakers Page|url=https://www.blackhat.com/html/bh-europe-08/bh-eu-08-archives.html#Amit|website=www.blackhat.com|publisher=BlackHat|accessdate=7 June 2016}}{{cite web|title=Black Hat ® Technical Security Conference: Europe 2010 // Archives|url=https://www.blackhat.com/html/bh-eu-10/bh-eu-10-archives.html#Amit|website=www.blackhat.com|accessdate=7 June 2016}}{{cite web|title=Black Hat USA 2012|url=http://blackhat.com/html/bh-us-12/bh-us-12-briefings.html#Amit|website=blackhat.com}} [[BlueHat]],{{cite web|title=BlueHat Security Briefings: Fall 2008 Sessions and Interviews|url=https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/security/cc748656.aspx|website=TechNet|publisher=Microsoft|accessdate=7 June 2016}} [[RSA Conference]].{{cite web|title=The Newest Element of Risk Metrics: Social Media {{!}} USA 2016 {{!}} RSA Conference|url=https://www.rsaconference.com/events/us16/agenda/sessions/2558/the-newest-element-of-risk-metrics-social-media|website=www.rsaconference.com|accessdate=7 June 2016}} He has been named SC Magazine's top experts{{cite news|last1=Epper Hoffman|first1=Karen|title=An epic ride: A look back at the ever-changing information security industry|url=http://www.scmagazine.com/an-epic-ride-a-look-back-at-the-ever-changing-information-security-industry/article/385052/|accessdate=7 June 2016|work=SC Magazine|date=8 December 2014}} and featured at Narratively's cover piece on Attack of the Superhackers{{cite web|last1=Rosen|first1=Kenneth|title=Attack of the Superhackers|url=http://narrative.ly/attack-of-the-superhackers/|website=Narratively|publisher=Narrative.ly|accessdate=7 June 2016|date=16 May 2014}} and is frequently quoted and interviewed{{cite web|last1=Francis|first1=Melissa|title=Ian Amit on Fox Business' Money With Melissa Francis March 21 2014|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rfHC_mKDPOw|publisher=Fox|date=21 March 2014}}{{cite web|title=US CENTCOM Twitter Hijack 'Purely' Vandalism|url=http://www.darkreading.com/us-centcom-twitter-hijack-purely-vandalism/d/d-id/1318588|website=Dark Reading}}{{cite web|title=Experts to talk Threat Intelligence at cybersecurity symposium – Seidenberg School News|url=http://seidenbergnews.blogs.pace.edu/2015/10/30/experts-to-talk-threat-intelligence-at-cybersecurity-symposium/|website=seidenbergnews.blogs.pace.edu}}{{cite web|last1=Ragan|first1=Steve|title=Hacked Opinions: The legalities of hacking – Ian Amit|url=http://www.csoonline.com/article/2988286/security-industry/hacked-opinions-the-legalities-of-hacking-ian-amit.html|website=CSO Online}}{{cite web|last1=Santarcangelo|first1=Michael|title=Two perspectives on social media for security leaders|url=http://www.csoonline.com/article/3058879/leadership-management/two-perspectives-on-social-media-for-security-leaders.html|website=CSO Online}} == Career == Amit started his professional career in 1998 at the Israeli information security consultancy Comsec as a Unix and Internet Application consultant. In 2001 he moved to the US to work as a software architect at Praxell (later to be acquired by Datavantage,{{cite web|last1=Mears|first1=Jennifer|title=Server clusters offer speed, savings|url=http://www.networkworld.com/article/2332465/data-center/server-clusters-offer-speed--savings.html|website=Network World}} and then [[MICROS Systems|Micros]]). On 2004 Amit left the US to co-found Israeli startup BeeFence and served as its [[Chief Technology Officer]]. Then in 2006 he took position as the director of security research at the security vendor [[Finjan]], and a similar position in 2008 with [[Aladdin Knowledge Systems]]. He then set out to serve as the vice president of consulting with Security-Art, and in 2012 took a position as director of services with the security consulting firm IOActive. Starting in 2014 he served as vice president of the social media cyber security startup ZeroFOX, after which in 2016 he became a manager with [[Amazon.com]] information security. Since 2018 he is serving as the [[Chief Security Officer]] of [[Cimpress]]. He serves as a general director of the board of BSides Las Vegas, a Senior Advisory Board member of Axon Cyber, and an Advisory Board member of ZeroFOX. == Research == During his career, Amit focused his research on varying topics ranging from uncovering the business elements of cybercrime,{{cite web|title=Security researcher discovers massive criminal database|url=http://www.computerweekly.com/news/2240087045/Security-researcher-discovers-massive-criminal-database|website=ComputerWeekly}}{{cite web|last1=Tangent|first1=The Dark|title=DEF CON® Hacking Conference - DEF CON 17 Archive|url=https://defcon.org/html/links/dc-archives/dc-17-archive.html#Amit|website=defcon.org}} through connecting state sponsored activities with criminal ones.{{cite web|last1=Tangent|first1=The Dark|title=DEF CON® Hacking Conference - DEF CON 18 Archive|url=https://www.defcon.org/html/links/dc-archives/dc-18-archive.html#Amit|website=www.defcon.org}} He has contributed to one of the first research papers conducted on the [[Stuxnet]] worm,{{cite web|title=CSFI - Cyber Security Forum Initiative|url=http://www.csfi.us/?page=volunteer|website=www.csfi.us}} and was featured on the cover of the inaugural Pentest Magazine about the Penetration Testing Execution Standard (PTES).{{cite web|last1=Duc|first1=Hiep Nguyen|title=2011 PENTEST REGULAR ISSUES - Pentestmag|url=https://pentestmag.com/download/2011-pentestmag/|website=Pentestmag}} He also co-authored research with Aviv Raff on Windows Vista's inherently insecure Widgets,{{cite web|title=Report: Widgets Will Be Your Next Woe|url=http://www.eweek.com/c/a/Security/Report-Widgets-Will-Be-Your-Next-Woe|website=www.eweek.com}} which were later removed from the operating system. In 2011, Amit and Itzik Kotler presented at DEF CON, demonstrating how a bot master could communicate with [[botnets]] and with "zombie machines" using [[VoIP]] conference calls. Their open-source software, Moshi Moshi, illustrated how they could send instructions to and receive data from botnets and infiltrated networks using any phone line (including payphones).{{cite web|last1=Greene|first1=Tim|title=Defcon: VoIP makes a good platform for controlling botnets|url=http://www.networkworld.com/article/2180023/uc-voip/defcon--voip-makes-a-good-platform-for-controlling-botnets.html|website=Network World|accessdate=8 June 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Greene|first1=Tim|title=10 scariest hacks from Black Hat and Defcon|url=http://www.networkworld.com/article/2868939/lan-wan/10-scariest-hacks-from-black-hat-and-defcon.html#slide3|website=Network World}} This research was also based on his original research into advanced data exfiltration, in which he uncovered a method for side-channel data exfiltration{{cite web|title=NCSC|url=https://www.ncsc.nl/conference/conference-2011/speakers/iftach-ian-amit.html|website=www.ncsc.nl}} through various channels - including phone lines and fax machines, and released an open source tool for it{{cite web|title=iiamit/data-sound-poc|url=https://github.com/iiamit/data-sound-poc|website=GitHub}} == Presentations == * [https://www.bsidestlv.com/agenda/ Keynote]. BSidesTLV 2017 {{cite web|title=Closing Keynote - Ian Amit|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TfIky1agmDY|date=28 June 2017}} * [https://bsidescle16.sched.org/event/7SMT/morning-keynote Keynote]. BSidesCleveland 2016 {{cite web|title=Opening Keynote - Ian Amit|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZHS7RnEgRZU&feature=youtu.be&t=288|date=25 June 2016}} * [http://hackmiami.org/2016/04/26/iftach-ian-amit-keynote-speaker-sun-05-15-16/ Keynote]. [[HackMiami]] 2016 * [http://infosecworld.misti.com/ian-amit Actionable Threat Intelligence]. InfoSecWorld Orlando 2016 * [https://www.rsaconference.com/events/us16/agenda/sessions/2558/the-newest-element-of-risk-metrics-social-media The Newest Elements of Risk Metrics]. RSA Conference 2016 * [http://bsideslv2015.sched.org/event/1b0289628c6efda6763c4902a41cf225 Actionable Threat Intelligence]. BSidesLasVegas 2015 * [http://blackhat.com/html/bh-us-12/bh-us-12-briefings.html#Amit Sexydefense - Maximizing the Home-Field Advantage]. BlackHatUSA 2012{{cite web|last1=Simonite|first1=Tom|title=Hey, Hackers: Defense Is Sexy, Too|url=https://www.technologyreview.com/s/428649/hey-hackers-defense-is-sexy-too/|website=MIT Technology Review|publisher=MIT Technology Review}} == Publications and articles == * Contributed to NATO's [http://www.act.nato.int/global-commons-cyberspace-workshop Assured Access to the Global Commons - Cyberspace Workshop] at the Cooperative Cyber Defence Centre of Excellence (CCD COE), October 2010.{{cite journal|title=NATO in the Cyber Commons|journal=NATO CCD-COE Publications|date=19 October 2010|url=http://www.act.nato.int/images/stories/events/2010/gc/report05_tallinn.pdf|accessdate=7 June 2016}} * [http://risk-metrics.com/ Social Media Risk Metrics] == References == {{reflist|2}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Amit, Iftach Ian}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People in information technology]] [[Category:Writers about computer security]]

{{Infobox musical artist | name = Jim James | image = Jim James 8-12-11.jpg | caption = James performing on August 8, 2011 | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = James Edward Olliges Jr. | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1978|04|27}} | alias = Yim Yames | origin = [[Louisville, Kentucky|Louisville]], [[Kentucky]], United States | instrument = [[Vocals]], [[guitar]], [[bass guitar|bass]], [[keyboard instrument|keyboards]], [[omnichord]], [[drums]], [[percussion]], [[harmonica]], [[banjo]] | genre = [[Psychedelic rock]], [[indie rock]], [[jam rock]] | occupation = Singer songwriter, musician, guitarist | years_active = 1992—present | label = [[ATO Records]]
[[MapleMusic Recordings]] (Canada) | associated_acts = [[My Morning Jacket]], [[M. Ward]], [[Bright Eyes (band)|Bright Eyes]], [[The Decemberists]], [[Monsters of Folk]], [[New Multitudes]], [[The New Basement Tapes]] | website = }} [[File:Jim james langerado.jpg|thumb|right|220px|James performing in 2007]] '''James Edward Olliges Jr.''' (born April 27, 1978), professionally known as '''Jim James''' or '''Yim Yames''',{{cite web | url=http://pitchfork.com/news/48542-my-morning-jackets-jim-james-announces-debut-solo-album-shares-new-track/ | title=My Morning Jacket's Jim James Announces Debut Solo Album, Shares New Track | publisher=[[Pitchfork Media|Pitchfork]] | date=2012-11-12 | accessdate=March 18, 2015 | author=Minsker, Evan}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/q-a-jim-james-on-his-dark-period-going-solo-and-my-morning-jackets-next-album-20130129|title=Q&A: My Morning Jacket's Jim James on the Band's Next Album and His Dark Period|last=Doyle|first=Patrick|date=January 29, 2013|work=|newspaper=Rolling Stone|access-date=2016-12-10|via=}} is an American [[vocalist]], guitarist, producer, and primary songwriter of the [[rock band]] [[My Morning Jacket]]. He has released three solo albums. ==Early life== James grew up in the [[Highlands–Douglass, Louisville|Highlands–Douglass]] neighborhood of [[Louisville, Kentucky]]. He attended St. Martha grade school and graduated from [[St. Xavier High School (Louisville)|St. Xavier High School]] in 1996.{{cite web| url= http://www.louisville.com/content/21-questions-my-morning-jackets-jim-james-music | publisher=Louisville.com | title=21 Questions with My Morning Jacket's Jim James| author= Lou | date= 25 October 2010 | accessdate= 8 May 2013}} James briefly attended the [[University of Kentucky]]. ==Career== [[File:New Multitudes at Webster Hall.jpg|alt=New Multitudes onstage bathed in red stage lights|thumb|James playing bass guitar as Yim Yames with the ''[[New Multitudes]]'' band]] Prior to forming My Morning Jacket, James was the vocalist and guitarist of Month of Sundays, currently known as Mont de Sundua.{{Citation needed|date=February 2018}} As the vocalist, [[frontman]], [[Record production|producer]] and lead songwriter for My Morning Jacket, James has been instrumental in defining the sound of the band.{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/music/artists/mymorningjacket/z?q=Z%20My%20Morning |title=Z Reviews, Ratings, Credits, and More at Metacritic |publisher=Metacritic.com |date= |accessdate=2011-08-13}} He was given an "Esky" for best songwriter in [[Esquire (magazine)|''Esquire'']]'s 2006 Esky Music Awards in the April issue. James typically plays [[rhythm guitar]], [[acoustic guitar]], and occasional [[lead guitar]] on My Morning Jacket songs. He played the role of the band leader in the [[Bob Dylan]] biopic ''[[I'm Not There]]'', singing the song "Going to Acapulco", with [[Calexico (band)|Calexico]] as his backing band, which was featured on the soundtrack of the film. [[Rolling Stone (magazine)|''Rolling Stone'']] listed James among their "20 New Guitar Gods" along with fellow My Morning Jacket guitarist [[Carl Broemel]]. In 2008, James, along with former My Morning Jacket guitarist and cousin Johnny Quaid, formed Removador Recordings and Solutions record label. The label, as described on its website, functions "on the simple principal of yielding the highest annual percentage of aural joy back into the hearts and minds of investors and shareholders with ease and convenience".{{cite web|url=http://removador.com/about-removador/ |title=About Removador |publisher=Removador Recordings and Solutions |date= |accessdate=2011-08-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715173617/http://removador.com/about-removador/ |archivedate=July 15, 2011 }} He contributed vocals on [[The Decemberists]]' 2009 album ''[[The Hazards of Love]]''. On April 4, 2009, James performed at the [[Radio City Music Hall]], New York City, in the "Change Begins Within" concert benefitting the [[David Lynch Foundation]].{{cite web|title=Jim James & Bettye Lavette added to David Lynch Foundation show|url=http://www.brooklynvegan.com/archives/2009/03/jim_james_betty.html|website=Brooklyn Vegan|accessdate=31 July 2014}} On July 7, 2009, James released ''[[Tribute To]]'', an EP covering [[George Harrison]] songs. A portion of the proceeds from the album were donated to the [[Woodstock Farm Animal Sanctuary]]. The EP was available on yimyames.com as both a digital download and a physical CD/LP.{{cite web| url=http://www.nme.com/news/my-morning-jacket/45589 |title=My Morning Jacket man to release George Harrison covers EP |work=[[NME]] |date= |accessdate=2011-09-28}} In 2009, James and the rest of My Morning Jacket played themselves in "[[My Morning Straitjacket]]", an episode of the animated television series ''[[American Dad!]]'' In 2012, [[Rounder Records]] released the [[Woody Guthrie]] tribute album ''[[New Multitudes]]'' which features songs [[cover songs|covered]] by a variety of musicians including James (as Yim Yames) and [[Jay Farrar]]. James wrote an article on My Morning Jacket,{{cite web| url= http://www.louisville.com/content/my-morning-jacket-my-morning-jacket-jim-james-music |title=My Morning Jacket by My Morning Jacket: Jim James |work=Louisville|date= |accessdate= 2012-07-11}} discussing how the band got its name and growing up in Louisville, for the July 2012 issue of ''[[Louisville (magazine)|Louisville]]'' magazine. Bandmates [[Patrick Hallahan]] and [[Tom Blankenship]] also wrote articles for the issue. James released his debut solo full-length album, ''[[Regions of Light and Sound of God]]'', on [[ATO Records]] on February 5, 2013. In early 2014 James recorded for ''[[Lost on the River: The New Basement Tapes]]'' alongside Elvis Costello, Marcus Mumford, Taylor Goldsmith and Rhiannon Giddens. The album was produced by T-Bone Burnett and is a compilation of partial songs written by Bob Dylan that were never released. On November 5, 2015, the [[David Lynch Foundation]] organised another benefit concert at New York City's [[Carnegie Hall]] named "Change Begins Within" to promote [[transcendental meditation]] for stress control. Jim James participated with [[Katy Perry]], [[Sting (musician)|Sting]], [[Jerry Seinfeld]], [[Angelique Kidjo]], and classical guitarist [[Sharon Isbin]]. And since each of the performers actively practices [[transcendental meditation]], they also spoke to its power.{{cite news |last= Grow |first= Kory |date= |title= Katy Perry, Sting Stun at David Lynch's Meditation Benefit Concert - Jerry Seinfeld, Angelique Kidjo, Jim James and others also perform and explain relaxation technique's importance to them at New York's Carnegie Hall |url= https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/katy-perry-sting-stun-at-david-lynchs-meditation-benefit-concert-20151105 |newspaper= Rolling Stone Magazine |location= |archive-url= https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/katy-perry-sting-stun-at-david-lynchs-meditation-benefit-concert-20151105 |archive-date=November 5, 2015 |access-date= November 14, 2015 }} James plays himself and sings in episodes 4 and 10 of the Showtime series ''[[Roadies (TV series)|Roadies]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.sho.com/video/50000/roadies-on-set-with-jim-james |title=Roadies: Roadies: On Set with Jim James | SHOWTIME |publisher=Sho.com |date=2016-07-07 |accessdate=2017-06-10}} In November 2016 he released his second solo album ''Eternally Even''.{{cite web|url=http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/22570-eternally-even/|title=Jim James: Eternally Even Album Review|last=Leas|first=Ryan|date=November 7, 2016|website=pitchfork.com|publisher=|access-date=2016-12-10}} On April 17, 2018, James announced the June 29 release of his third solo album of original material, ''[[Uniform Distortion]]''. Along with the announcement was the release of a single and music video for the album's opening track ‘Just A Fool’. Also, included with the announcement was a letter James wrote to photographer [[Duane Michals]] requesting use of his photograph ‘The Illuminated Man’ for the album's cover art. James discovered the photo in the 1971 publication ''[[Whole Earth Catalog|The Last Whole Earth Catalog]]'', which he stated was a primary inspiration for the new album.{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/allsongs/2018/04/17/603048490/jim-james-decries-blanket-distortion-in-society-with-new-song-album|title=Jim James Decries Media Distortion In Society With New Song, Album|work=NPR.org|access-date=2018-04-18|language=en}} ==Personal life== James was raised Catholic and attended Catholic grade school and high school.{{cite web|last1=Newman|first1=Jason|title=Jim James Q&A: How a Near-Death Experience and a 1929 Graphic Novel Saved His Life|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1538566/jim-james-qa-how-a-near-death-experience-and-a-1929-graphic-novel-saved-his?page=0%2C1|website=Billboard|accessdate=16 September 2014}} He has been practicing [[Transcendental Meditation technique|Transcendental Meditation]] since 2009. In 2008 he fell off the stage during a concert in Iowa, which inspired the recording of his first solo album. ==Discography== ===My Morning Jacket=== {{main|My Morning Jacket discography}} *''[[The Tennessee Fire]]'' (1999) *''[[At Dawn]]'' (2001) *''[[It Still Moves]]'' (2003) *''[[Z (My Morning Jacket album)|Z]]'' (2005) *''[[Evil Urges]]'' (2008) *''[[Circuital (album)|Circuital]]'' (2011) *''[[The Waterfall (album)|The Waterfall]]'' (2015) ===Monsters of Folk=== * ''[[Monsters of Folk (album)|Monsters of Folk]]'' (2009) ===The New Basement Tapes=== * ''[[Lost on the River: The New Basement Tapes]]'' (2014) ===Solo=== * ''[[Tribute To]]'' (2009, EP) * ''[[New Multitudes]] [With [[Jay Farrar]], [[Will Johnson (musician)|Will Johnson]] and [[Anders Parker]]] (2012) * ''[[Regions of Light and Sound of God]]'' (2013) * ''[[Eternally Even]]'' (2016) * ''Tribute To 2'' (2017) * ''Uniform Distortion'' (2018) * ''Uniform Clarity'' (2018) ===Guest appearances=== * Jim James appeared with The Sachal Ensemble on their album ''Song of Lahore'' (Universal, 2016)[http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/la-ca-mn-lahore-20151108-story.html Pakistan's Sachal Jazz Ensemble rises above the risks in 'Song of Lahore'] ==Equipment== ;Guitars * Gibson Custom ES-335 (Dot figured-top electric guitar with gloss finish honey burst) {{cite web|url=http://www.uberproaudio.com/who-plays-what/382-my-morning-jacket-jim-james-guitar-gear-rig-and-equipment |title=My Morning Jacket – Jim James Guitar Gear Rig and Equipment |publisher= |date= |accessdate=2011-09-28}} * Gibson 1998 Limited Edition Flying V with custom chrome pickguard * 1976 Gretsch Broadkaster (Plain wood finish. Used as secondary performance guitar 1999–2003 tours. Also used in recording of ''Tennessee Fire'', ''At Dawn'', and all EPs recorded prior to 2004) * Gretsch Super Axe (red) * Fender Stratocaster (sunburst, black pickguard, maple neck) * Ovation Preacher 12-string electric * Gibson J-185 acoustic/electric * Takamine acoustic G335 * Gretsch Broadkaster * Ventura Barney Kessel ;Electronics * [[Omnichord]] (OM-27, OM-100, OM-200m) * [[Roland SP-404]] ;Other instruments *[[Gibson Ripper|Gibson Ripper bass]] *Gold Tone banjo *Autoharp *Tenor Saxophone ;Amplifiers and cabinets * Mesa Boogie Tremoverb * Carr Rambler * Mesa Boogie 2x12" cabinets ;Pickups, effects and other equipment * SIB Mr. echo pedal * Boss RV-5 digital reverb pedal * Boss BD-2 blues driver pedal * Boss OC-3 super octave pedal * Boss TU-2 Chromatic Stompbox tuner * Hot Hand phaser/flanger * Zvex Wooly Mammoth fuzz pedal * Zvex Vexter Box of Rock pedal * Jim Dunlop Green Tortex picks * Grain silo[https://www.theguardian.com/music/2011/oct/27/my-morning-jacket-jim-james-interview My Morning Jacket: 'We had to work it out ourselves' | Music | The Guardian] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commons category}} * {{Official website|http://jimjames.com/}} * {{Discogs artist|Jim James}} * Brown, Catherine. [http://coolalbumoftheday.com/?p=28555 Review of ''Regions of Light and Sound of God''] on Cool Album of the Day {{My Morning Jacket}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:James, Jim}} [[Category:1978 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American male singer-songwriters]] [[Category:American singer-songwriters]] [[Category:American rock songwriters]] [[Category:American male songwriters]] [[Category:American rock guitarists]] [[Category:American male guitarists]] [[Category:American rock singers]] [[Category:Musicians from Louisville, Kentucky]] [[Category:My Morning Jacket members]] [[Category:St. Xavier High School (Louisville) alumni]] [[Category:Transcendental Meditation practitioners]] [[Category:Singers from Kentucky]] [[Category:Songwriters from Kentucky]] [[Category:Rock musicians from Kentucky]] [[Category:20th-century American singers]] [[Category:21st-century American singers]] [[Category:20th-century American guitarists]] [[Category:21st-century American guitarists]] [[Category:Rock bass guitarists]] [[Category:Guitarists from Kentucky]] [[Category:Monsters of Folk members]]

{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox writer <!-- For more information see [[:Template:Infobox Writer/doc]]. --> | name = Kavery Nambisan | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | pseudonym = Kavery Bhatt | birth_name = | birth_date = <!-- {{Birth date and age|df=yes|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | birth_place = Palangala, [[Kodagu district]], India | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|df=yes|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | death_place = | resting_place = | occupation = Surgeon | language = English, [[Kodava language|Kodava]] | nationality = Indian | ethnicity = | citizenship = Indian | education = | alma_mater = [[St. John's Medical College]], [[Bangalore]] | period = | genre = | subject = | movement = | notableworks = ''The Story that Must Not Be Told'' | spouse = [[Vijay Nambisan]]<ref name=fountainink/> | partner = | children = | relatives = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | module = | website = <!-- www.example.com --> | portaldisp = }} '''Kavery Nambisan''' is a novelist from [[India]]. She is also a surgeon who practices in rural India. Her career in medicine has been a strong influence in her fiction.<ref name=hindu2013>{{cite news|newspaper=The Hindu|url=http://www.thehindu.com/books/judges-for-the-hindu-prize-2013/article5375517.ece?homepage=true|title=Judges for the Hindu Prize 2013|date=21 November 2013|accessdate=22 November 2013}}</ref>
==Life==
Kavery Nambisan was born in Palangala village in south [[Kodagu]], India, in a politician's family.<ref name=decher2006>{{cite news|newspaper=Deccan Herald|date=3 January 2006|title=A surgeon and a writer|accessdate=23 November 2013|url=http://archive.deccanherald.com/Deccanherald/jan32006/spectrum161735200612.asp}}</ref> Her father, [[C.M. Poonacha]], was at one time a Union railway minister.<ref name=readinghour>{{cite journal|journal=Reading Hour|url=http://readinghour.in/content.php?ctype_id=MjI%3D|date=May–June 2011|volume=1|issue=3|author=Vijay Nair|title=Chatting with Kavery Nambisan}}</ref> She spent her early years in [[Madikeri]].<ref name=decher2006/> She studied medicine in [[St. John's Medical College]], [[Bangalore]] from 1965<ref name=stjohn>{{cite web|url=http://johnite.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=143:well-kown-author-and-rural-surgeonkavery-nambisan&catid=40:profiles&Itemid=70|title=Well Known Author and Rural Surgeon: Kavery Nambisan|date=17 August 2005|author=Carol D'Souza|publisher=Johnite|accessdate=23 November 2013}}</ref> and then studied surgery at the [[University of Liverpool]], England,<ref name=fountainink>{{cite web|publisher=Fountain Ink|date=4 November 2013|author=Nandini Krishnan|accessdate=22 November 2013|title=The doctor is in the house|url=http://fountainink.in/?p=4361}}</ref> where she obtained the [[Fellowship of the Royal College of Surgeons|FRCS]] qualification.<ref name=decher2006/> She worked as a surgeon in various parts of rural India<ref name=fountainink/> before moving to [[Lonavala]] to start a free medical centre for migrant labourers.<ref name="hindu2008">{{cite news|url=http://www.hindu.com/mag/2008/11/09/stories/2008110950060200.htm|title=Quiet Activism|date=9 November 2008|newspaper=The Hindu|author=Sonya Dutta Choudhury|accessdate=23 November 2013}}</ref>
Nambisan works as surgeon and medical advisor at the Tata Coffee Hospital in [[Kodagu district|Kodagu]], Karnataka,<ref name=hindu2013/> and is the Chief Medical Officer for [[Tata Coffee]].<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=Economic Times|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2013-06-24/news/40166735_1_cyrus-mistry-ratan-tata-tata-global-beverages-ltd|date=24 June 2013|title=Cyrus Mistry wants more women at leadership roles in Tata group|accessdate=23 November 2013}}</ref> She has created several programmes for child immunisation and family planning for the rural communities. She is vocal in her critiques of urban centred health planning.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hindu.com/mag/2005/02/20/stories/2005022000270100.htm|author=Kavery Nambisan|newspaper=The Hindu|title=Magazine : Saving lives ... at what cost?|date=20 February 2005}}</ref>
Nambisan was married to [[Vijay Nambisan]], a journalist and poet.<ref name=fountainink/> She has a daughter, Chetana, from an earlier marriage to Dr K.R. Bhatt, which lasted eighteen years.<ref name=stjohn/>
==Literary career== Kavery Nambisan began by writing under her first married name Kavery Bhatt for children's magazines. She wrote stories for the now defunct children's magazine ''[[Target (magazine)|Target]]''. She also contributed to ''[[Femina (India)|Femina]]'' and ''Eve's Weekly''.<ref name=fountainink/>
Nambisan has authored several novels for adults, each with widely differing themes.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Nambisan, Kavery (1949-), Routledge Encyclopedia of Post-Colonial Literatures in English, Second Edition|last=Narayan|first=Shyamala A.|publisher=Routledge|year=2005|isbn=|location=London|pages=}}</ref> Her first book, published under the name Kavery Bhatt, ''The Truth (almost) About Bharat,'' is the story of a rebellious young medical student who runs away from medical college, and begins a cross-country road trip on his motorcycle. The book went out of print and was recently re-released.{{Citation needed|date=March 2017}} Her second novel, ''The Scent of Pepper'' (1996) was set in her birthplace, [[Kodagu district|Kodagu]] and is a portrait of the life and culture of its people, through the eyes of a family from colonial rule to independence.<ref name=":0" /> ''Mango-coloured Fish'' (1998) concerns a woman whose marriage has been arranged to a man she does not love.<ref name=":0" /> ''On Wings of Butterflies'' (2002) is set in the women's movement in independent India and narrates the story of a group of women entering politics.<ref name=":0" /> ''The Hills of Angheri'' (2005) draws from Nambisan's own experiences as a doctor, tracing a young woman's medical career.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pai|first=Sanjay A.|date=2006-01-01|title=Review of The Hills Of Angheri|jstor=25456186|journal=BMJ: British Medical Journal|volume=332|issue=7538|pages=429–429}}</ref> Her sixth novel,''The Story that Must Not Be Told'' was shortlisted for the [[DSC Prize for South Asian Literature]] in 2012,<ref name="toi2012">{{cite news|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-11-03/bangalore/30354593_1_shortlist-english-translation-dsc-prize|title=Home-turf stories bring laurels to B'lore writers|date=3 November 2011|author=Shrabonti Bagchi|accessdate=22 November 2013|newspaper=The Times of India}}</ref> as well as the [[Man Asian Literary Prize]] in 2008.<ref name="hindu2008" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.penguinbooksindia.com/en/content/kavery-nambisan|title=Kavery Nambisan|publisher=Penguin India|accessdate=22 November 2013}}</ref> Her seventh and most recent novel, ''A Town Like Ours'' (2014) is an account of the lives of several people, narrated by a sex worker living in a small town, and engages with themes of identity and industrialisation.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/books/a-town-like-ours-story-of-a-small-town-as-seen-by-a-sex-worker/story-GuTCUx8nq1xhduY5Kh9XYI.html|title=A Town Like Ours: Story of a small town as seen by a sex worker|date=2015-01-03|work=hindustantimes.com/|access-date=2017-03-25|language=en}}</ref>
Nambisan's story ''Dr Sad and the Power Lunch'' was joint runner-up in the third Outlook-Picador non-fiction contest in 2003.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=[[Outlook (magazine)|Outlook]]|url=http://www.outlookindia.com/article.aspx?223126|title=Outlook-Picador Non-Fiction Contest 2003: Dr Sad and the Power Lunch|date=3 March 2004|accessdate=23 November 2013}}</ref> She has also contributed fiction to ''[[Indian Literature (journal)|Indian Literature]]'', the journal published by the [[Sahitya Akademi]] (India's National Academy of Letters).<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Nambisan|first=Kavery|date=2005-01-01|title=The Ordinary Life of Srinivasalu|jstor=23340859|journal=Indian Literature|volume=49|issue=4 (228)|pages=183–189}}</ref>
She has also contributed some works of criticism, including a piece on 'New Issues in Fiction'<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Nambisan|first=Kavery|date=2005-01-01|title=New Issues in Fiction|jstor=23340770|journal=Indian Literature|volume=49|issue=4 (228)|pages=41–44}}</ref> to the journal ''[[Indian Literature (journal)|Indian Literature]].''
==Awards and recognition==
=== Literary Awards and Recognition === Kavery Nambisan was a ''[[Coorg Person of the Year]]'' in 2005.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Hindu|author=Jeevan Chinnappa|title=P.M. Belliappa is 'Coorg Person of the Year 2011'|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-karnataka/pm-belliappa-is-coorg-person-of-the-year-2011/article2779554.ece|accessdate=23 November 2013|date=6 January 2012}}</ref>
=== Medical and Professional Awards and Recognition ===
==List of Publications == *''Once Upon a Forest'', [[Children's Book Trust]], India, 1986. (As Kavery Bhatt.) *''Kitty Kite'', Children's Book Trust, India, 1987. (As Kavery Bhatt.) *''The Truth (almost) About Bharat'', Penguin India, 1991. (As Kavery Bhatt.) *''The Scent of Pepper'', Penguin India, 1996. *''Mango-coloured fish'', Penguin India, 1998. *''On Wings of Butterflies'', Penguin India, 2002. *''The Hills of Angheri'', Penguin, 2005. *''The Story that Must Not Be Told'', Penguin, 2010. *''A Town Like Ours'', Aleph Book Company, 2014.
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
