{{Infobox settlement | name = Lai Châu Province | native_name = Tỉnh Lai Châu | native_name_lang = vi | type = [[Provinces of Vietnam|Province]] | image_skyline = | image_caption = | image_map = Lai Chau in Vietnam.svg | map_caption = Location of Lai Châu within Vietnam | coordinates = {{coord|22|0|N|103|0|E|region:VN_type:adm1st|display=inline,title}} | subdivision_type = Country | subdivision_name = {{flag|Vietnam}} | subdivision_type1 = [[Regions of Vietnam|Region]] | subdivision_name1 = [[Northwest (Vietnam)|Northwest]] | seat_type = Capital | seat = [[Lai Châu]] | leader_party = | leader_title = [[Provinces of Vietnam#People's Council|People's Council]] Chair | leader_name = Lỳ Khai Phà | leader_title1 = [[Provinces of Vietnam#People's Committee|People's Committee]] Chair | leader_name1 = Lò Văn Giàng | area_footnotes = | area_total_km2 = 9068.8 | elevation_footnotes = | elevation_m = | population_footnotes = [http://www.gso.gov.vn/default.aspx?tabid=512&idmid=5&ItemID=14277 Statistical Handbook of Vietnam 2014] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150706154400/http://www.gso.gov.vn/default.aspx?tabid=512&idmid=5&ItemID=14277 |date=2015-07-06 }}, General Statistics Office Of Vietnam | population_total = 415,300 | population_as_of = 2014 | population_density_km2 = auto | demographics_type1 = Demographics | demographics1_title1 = [[List of ethnic groups in Vietnam|Ethnicities]] | demographics1_info1 = [[Tai peoples|Tai]], [[Hmong people|H'Mông]], [[Vietnamese people|Vietnamese]], [[Giay people|Giáy]], [[Yao people|Dao]] | timezone = [[Indochina Time|ICT]] | utc_offset = +7 | timezone_DST = | area_code_type = [[Telephone numbers in Vietnam|Area codes]] | area_code = 213 | iso_code = [[ISO 3166-2:VN|VN-01]] | website = {{URL|http://www.laichau.gov.vn}} }} '''Lai Châu''' ({{audio|Lai_Châu.ogg|listen|help=no}}) is a [[Provinces of Vietnam|province]] in the [[Northwest (Vietnam)|Northwest]] region of [[Vietnam]]. Lai Châu Province is the most sparsely populated in Vietnam, and it shares a border with China. It was once a semi-independent [[Tai Dón people|White Tai]] confederation known as [[Sip Song Chau Tai]], but was absorbed by France into French Indochina in the 1880s and subsequently became part of Vietnam following Vietnamese independence in 1954.Forbes, Andrew, and Henley, David: ''Vietnam Past and Present: The North'' (History and culture of Hanoi and Tonkin). Chiang Mai. Cognoscenti Books, 2012. ASIN: B006DCCM9Q.http://www.zum.de/whkmla/histatlas/seasia/haxlaos.html It became part of the [[Northwest Autonomous Area]] of the [[Democratic Republic of Vietnam]] from 1955 to 1975, when Lai Châu Province was formed. [[Điện Biên Province]] was carved out of Lai Châu in 2004. == Etymology == ''Sip Song Chau Tai'' is a [[Tai Lü language|Tai Lü]] compound consisting of ''sibsong'' "twelve" and ''chu'' "master". It is [[cognate]] to {{lang-t|สิบสองจุไท}}, and may rendered in English as "Twelve Tai Kingdoms" or "Chiefdoms", according to relative standing in the [[mandala (Southeast Asian political model)|Southeast Asian mandala political model]], in allusion to either a [[Chief of the Name]] or a [[tribal chief]]. ''Sibsong'' derives from Chinese [[wikt:十|十]] (ten) and [[wikt:雙|雙]] (pair). "Chu", (rendered in Tai as จุ or in longer form [[wikt:เจ้า|เจ้า]],) derives from [[Middle Chinese]] 主 (ćǘ) "master." == Administrative divisions == [[File:BandohanhchinhtinhLChau.png|thumb|right|Map of Lai Châu Province in October 2017]] Lai Châu is subdivided into eight district-level sub-divisions: {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%; text-align:center" ! rowspan="2"| Second Tier
subdivisions ! rowspan="2"| Area
(km²) ! colspan="3"| Third Tier subdivisions |- ! width="60px"| [[Ward (Vietnam)|Ward]] ! width="60px"| [[Commune-level town (Vietnam)|Township]] ! width="60px"| [[Rural commune (Vietnam)|Commune]] |- | [[Lai Châu]] city || 70.77 || 5 || || 2 |- | [[Mường Tè District]] || 2679.34 || || 1 || 13 |- | [[Nậm Nhùn|Nậm Nhùn District]] || 1388.08 || || 1 || 10 |- | [[Phong Thổ District]] || 103.46 || || 1 || 17 |- | [[Sìn Hồ District]] || 1526.96 || || 1 || 21 |- | [[Tam Đường District, Lai Châu|Tam Đường District]] || 684.72 || || 1 || 13 |- | [[Tân Uyên District, Lai Châu|Tân Uyên District]] || 903.26 || || 1 || 9 |- | [[Than Uyên District]] || 796.88 || || 1 || 11 |} They are further subdivided into seven commune-level towns (or townlets), 96 communes, and five wards. ==Languages== Languages spoken in Lai Châu Province include the following. *[[Hmong–Mien languages]] **[[Hmong language|Hmong]] *[[Kra languages]] **[[Laha language|Laha]] - [[Than Uyên District|Than Uyên]] *[[Tibeto-Burman languages]] **[[Sila language (Laos)|Sila]] - [[Mường Tè District|Mường Tè]] **[[Côông language|Côông]] - [[Mường Tè District|Mường Tè]] **[[Lahu language|Lahu]] - [[Mường Tè District|Mường Tè]] **[[Hani language|Hani]] - [[Mường Tè District|Mường Tè]], [[Phong Thổ District|Phong Thổ]] *[[Austroasiatic languages]] **[[Kháng language|Kháng]] - [[Mường Tè District|Mường Tè]], [[Phong Thổ District|Phong Thổ]], [[Than Uyên District|Than Uyên]] == Economy == [[File:Laichaubridge.jpg|thumb|left|300px|A bridge in Lai Châu Province]] Lai Châu has long been the poorest province in Vietnam. It is also the least industrialised province. In 1974, the industrial output of [[Hanoi]] - the richest province in North Vietnam at that time - was 47 times as high as that of Lai Châu.Beresford, Melanie (2003): "Economic Transition, Uneven Development, and the Impact of Reform on Regional Inequality", in Luong, Hy V. (ed.): ''Postwar Vietnam: dynamics of a transforming society''. Lanham, Maryland: Rowman & Littlefield The province became even more backward after the more industrialised south was separated to become [[Điện Biên Province]]. In 2007, Hanoi's industrial output (before its merger with [[Hà Tây Province]]) was 93 times that of Lai Châu.General Statistics Office (2009): ''Socio-economical Statistical Data of 63 Provinces and Cities''. Statistical Publishing House, Hanoi Industrial output has, however, grown rapidly in recent years, more than tripling between 2000 and 2007, making the fastest growing sector in the province compared to an agriculture and forestry sector that has grown by less than 50% and a service sector that has more than doubled in the same time. Industrial products include liquor, bricks, cement and electricity. Industrial output in 2007 was 476.6 billion [[Vietnamese đồng]]s, accounting for 28.9% of the province's economy, compared to only 16.5% in 2000. Lai Châu's main agricultural products (in 2007) are rice (99,900t), maize (35,000t), [[cassava]] (48,900t) and tea (16,532t). The production of rice and maize tripled since 2000, while the output of cassava and tea has been increasing by around 40% and 120%. Tea from Lai Châu is sold to other provinces in Vietnam and also exported to other countries. Lai Châu has a relatively large forestry sector with an output of 176.3 billion đồngs in 2007. It has, however, been far overtaken by the agricultural, industrial and service sectors and contributed little to recent growth. It has grown by only 1.66% in 2007 and 1.69% in 2006, after declining by almost 19% between 2000 and 2005. There are plans to exploit [[rare-earth element]]s in Lai Châu. [[Vietnam]]'s central government signed an agreement in October 2010 to supply Japan with [[rare-earth elements]]{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-11661330| title=Rare earths supply deal between Japan and Vietnam| work=[[BBC News]]| date=31 October 2010| accessdate=31 October 2010}} in Lai Châu Province.{{cite news| url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/asia-pacific/2010/10/2010103191334878158.html| title=Vietnam signs major nuclear pacts | publisher=[[Al Jazeera]] | date= 31 October 2010 | accessdate= 31 October 2010}} This is part of Japan's efforts to diversify its supply of rare earths and decrease its dependence on imports from China. Lai Châu's economy grew by 14.56% in 2007, 12.3% in 2006 and 50.75% between 2000 and 2005. == Infrastructure == [[File:Lai Châu Province road construction.jpg|thumb|left|300px|Road construction works in Lai Châu province]] === Transport === National Road 4 connects Lai Châu to [[Lào Cai Province]], National Road 12 to [[Điện Biên Province]] and National Road 32 to [[Yên Bái Province]]. There is also a road to [[Gejiu]] in China. There is neither an airport nor a railway in the province. Road transport has grown rapidly in recent years. Freight traffic increased from 1 million tons.km in 2000 to 21.3 tons.km in 2007, while passenger traffic increased from 4.4 to 16.7 million passenger km. Road infrastructure is still not very developed. Only 19.36% of the roads in the province are paved and only 10.53% of respondents to a survey of local businesses think that road quality is good or very good.[http://pcivietnam.org/province_profile_detail.php?province=54 Vietnam Provincial Competitiveness Index 2009] === Telecommunication === As of 2007, there 22,100 telephone subscribers in Lai Châu, a significant increase from the 14,200 in the previous year. Only 35.59% of the respondents to a survey assessed telecommunications quality as good or very good, the lowest value among all the provinces in Vietnam. == Climate == *Annual average temperature: 23 degrees Celsius. *Annual average rainfall: 2.5 m. == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * {{official website|http://www.laichau.gov.vn|Official '''Lai Châu Province''' website}} {{Commonscat|Lai Chau Province}} {{Geographic location |Centre = Lai Châu Province |North = [[Yunnan]], {{flag|China}} |Northeast = |East = [[Lào Cai Province]] |Southeast = [[Yên Bái Province]] |South = [[Sơn La Province]] |Southwest = [[Điện Biên Province]] |West = |Northwest = }} {{Subdivisions of Vietnam}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lai Chau Province}} [[Category:Lai Chau Province| ]] [[Category:Northwest (Vietnam)]] [[Category:Hani people]]

revision.text:
'''Lamour Desrances''' (also spelled '''L'Amour Desrances''', '''Lamour Derance''', and '''Lamour Dérance''') was a [[Haitian Revolution|Haitian revolutionary]] leader. A former [[Maroon (people)|maroon]], he was born in [[Africa]] and brought to [[Saint-Domingue]] as a [[slave]]. During the revolution, when local figures often gained power in control of small armed forces, Desrances became a local military leader in the mountains surrounding [[Port-au-Prince]] and [[Saint-Marc]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Études sur l'histoire d'Haïti, suivies de la vie du général J.M. Borgella|author1=Beaubrun Ardouin |author2=Jérôme Maximilien Borgella|year=1853|language=French|page=119}}</ref>
At the time of the [[War of Knives]], Desrances was loyal to [[André Rigaud]] in his battle with [[Toussaint Louverture]], and was one of the few black officers in the predominantly [[mulatto]] northern Rigaud-loyal army.<ref>{{cite book|title=Avengers of the New World: The Story of the Haitian Revolution|author=Laurent Dubois|year=2004|publisher=Harvard University Press|ISBN=0-674-01826-5|pages=232}}</ref> After Rigaud's defeat by Louverture, Desrances is referred to as a rebel in Louverture's autobiography. [[Céligny Ardouin]] argues that Louverture and [[Jean-Jacques Dessalines]] saw Desrances as a growing rival due to his power in the region, and determined to defeat him.<ref>{{cite news|title=COMMENT SE CONCERTA LUTTE POUR L'INDÉPENDANCE|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g-P2PZ5FXUcC&lpg=PA30&ots=Felkt2M3Vf&dq=Lamour+Desrances&pg=PA28&ci=227,324,567,113|author=Céligny Ardouin|author-link=Céligny Ardouin|page=30|language=French}} in {{cite book|title=Auteurs haïtiens: Morceaux choisis|author=Solon Ménos|author-link=Solon Ménos|author2=Dantès Bellegarde|author2-link=Dantès Bellegarde|author3=Georges Sylvain|author3-link=Georges Sylvain|year=1904|publisher=Impr. de Mme F. Smith}}</ref> Louverture marched on Desrances' forces in November 1802, and they scattered into the local forest.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://docsouth.unc.edu/neh/beard63/beard63.html|pages=308–309|title=Toussaint L'Ouverture: A Biography and Autobiography|translator=Beard, J. R. (John Relly)|author=Toussaint L'Ouverture|publisher=James Redpath|location=Boston|year=1863}}</ref>
Two months later, the French forces arrived under [[Charles Leclerc]] and during L'Ouverture's open conflict with the French, Desrances notably changed his loyalty to the French under General [[Pampile de Lacroix]] to fight against Dessalines' forces.<ref>{{cite book|title=Avengers of the New World: The Story of the Haitian Revolution|author=Laurent Dubois|year=2004|publisher=Harvard University Press|ISBN=0-674-01826-5|pages=270}}</ref> An enemy of L'Ouverture in both instances, L'Ouverture wrote of him: "L’Amour Desrances, who had caused all the inhabitants of the Plain of Cul-de-Sac to be assassinated; who urged the laborers to revolt; who pillaged all this part of the island."<ref>L'Ouverture also records that Leclerc raised Desrances to the rank of brigade commander.{{cite book|url=http://docsouth.unc.edu/neh/beard63/beard63.html|pages=308–309|title=Toussaint L'Ouverture: A Biography and Autobiography|translator=Beard, J. R. (John Relly)|author=Toussaint L'Ouverture|publisher=James Redpath|location=Boston|year=1863}}</ref> The combined force of French and Desrances' and others' local militias defeated [[Dessalines]] army at Port-au-Prince and forced their retreat.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Desrances, Lamour}} [[Category:Haitian people of African descent]] [[Category:Haitian rebel slaves]] [[Category:People of the Haitian Revolution]] [[Category:People of the Latin American wars of independence]] [[Category:People of Saint-Domingue]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox officeholder | name = Lewis Dewart | image name = | caption = | state1 = [[Pennsylvania]] | district1 = [[Pennsylvania's 9th congressional district|9th]] | term_start1 = March 4, 1831 | term_end1 = March 3, 1833 | preceded1 = ''See below'' | succeeded1 = ''See below'' | office2 = Member of the [[Pennsylvania Senate]] | term2 = 1823-1826 | office3 = Member of the [[Pennsylvania House of Representatives]] | term3 = 1812-1820 | birth_date = {{birth date|1780|11|14}} | death_date = {{death date and age|1852|04|26|1780|11|14}} | birth_place = [[Sunbury, Pennsylvania]] | death_place = Sunbury, Pennsylvania | party = [[Democratic-Republican Party|Jacksonian Democrat]] }} '''Lewis Dewart''' (November 14, 1780 – April 26, 1852) was a [[Democratic-Republican Party|Jacksonian]] member of the [[U.S. House of Representatives]] from [[Pennsylvania]]. ==Biography== Lewis Dewart (father of [[William Lewis Dewart]]) was born in [[Sunbury, Pennsylvania]]. He was a clerk in his father’s store for several years and later became a [[coal]] operator and banker. He served as postmaster at Sunbury from 1806 to 1816. He was a member of the [[Pennsylvania House of Representatives]] from 1812 to 1820. He was elected to the [[Pennsylvania State Senate]] in 1823 and served three years. He was one of the organizers and builders of the Danville & Pottsville Railroad, and served as one of the first directors. Dewart was elected as a Jacksonian to the [[22nd United States Congress|Twenty-second]] Congress. He was again a member of the Pennsylvania House of Representatives from 1835 to 1840 and served as speaker in 1840. He was chief burgess of Sunbury in 1837 and a member of the school board. He was an unsuccessful candidate for the Democratic nomination for [[List of Governors of Pennsylvania|Governor of Pennsylvania]] in [[Pennsylvania gubernatorial election, 1841|1841]]. He died in Sunbury in 1852 and was buried in Sunbury Cemetery. ==See also== * [[Speaker of the Pennsylvania House of Representatives]] ==Sources== {{CongBio|D000289}} *[http://politicalgraveyard.com/bio/devison-dewesse.html The Political Graveyard] {{s-start}} {{s-par|us-hs}} {{USRepSuccessionBox | state=Pennsylvania | district=9 | before=[[Alem Marr]]
[[Philander Stephens]]
[[James Ford (Pennsylvania)|James Ford]] | after=[[Henry A. P. Muhlenberg]] | years=1831–1833
alongside: [[James Ford (Pennsylvania)|James Ford]] and [[Philander Stephens]] }} {{s-end}} {{PASpeakers}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dewart, Lewis}} [[Category:Members of the United States House of Representatives from Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Members of the Pennsylvania House of Representatives]] [[Category:Pennsylvania state senators]] [[Category:American postmasters]] [[Category:1780 births]] [[Category:1852 deaths]] [[Category:Clerks]] [[Category:Pennsylvania Jacksonians]] [[Category:Jacksonian members of the United States House of Representatives]] [[Category:School board members in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:19th-century American politicians]] {{Pennsylvania-Representative-stub}}

page.title: List of inductees of Canada's Walk of Fame

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} [[File:Mario Lemieux star on Walk of Fame adjusted.jpg|right|200px|thumb|[[Mario Lemieux]]'s star]]<onlyinclude><!-- See [[Wikipedia_talk:Featured_lists#Proposed_change_to_all_featured_lists]] for an explanation of this and other inclusion tags below -->
[[Canada's Walk of Fame]], located in [[Toronto]], Ontario, is a walk of fame that acknowledges the achievements and accomplishments of successful Canadians. It consists of a series of stars imbedded in 13 designated blocks worth of sidewalks in Toronto, located in front of [[Roy Thomson Hall]], the [[Princess of Wales Theatre]], and the [[Royal Alexandra Theatre]] on [[King Street, Toronto|King]] and Simcoe streets. The first group of members was inducted in 1998, and it has since expanded to include the RBC Emerging Artist Music Mentorship Prize competition, which assists emerging Canadian musicians with getting their careers off the ground.
The Walk of Fame was first conceived in 1996 when Peter Soumalias suggested the idea of a Walk of Fame for famous Torontonians to the board of the Toronto Entertainment District Association. They rejected his idea but he went on to establish a Walk of Fame for Canadians.<ref name="History">{{cite web|url=http://www.canadaswalkoffame.com/thewalk/history.xml.htm|title=History|author=Peter Soumalias|accessdate=2009-04-27|publisher=Canada's Walk of Fame|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080204073131/http://www.canadaswalkoffame.com/thewalk/history.xml.htm|archivedate=February 4, 2008}}</ref> Canada's Walk of Fame runs an annual contest in which Canadians can nominate potential inductees. In 2000, prior to the introduction of the online voting system, over 30,000 nominations were received via letters, fax and e-mail.<ref name="Record2">{{cite news|title=Walk on the 'famous' side; New pathway-to-the-stars entries include William Shatner and Gordie Howe|date=March 22, 2000|page=E07|publisher=''[[The Record (Waterloo Region)|The Record]]''|author=Andrew Flynn}}</ref> The committee then analyzes the nominees based on the following criteria: the nominee was born in Canada or has spent their formative or creative years in Canada; they have had a minimum of 10 years experience in their field; they have had a national or international impact on Canada’s Cultural heritage.<ref name="About">{{cite web|url=http://www.canadaswalkoffame.com/aboutus.xml.htm|title=About Us|date=January 29, 2007|accessdate=2009-04-27|publisher=Canada's Walk of Fame|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080604015048/http://www.canadaswalkoffame.com/aboutus.xml.htm|archivedate=June 4, 2008}}</ref> Following the Selection Committee's evaluation, the nominees that meet all of the requirements are forwarded to the board of directors, who then select the inductees.<ref name="About"/>
New inductees are inducted annually at an unveiling ceremony where their star, a stylized [[maple leaf]], is revealed.<ref name="Record2"/> The first was held in 1998 and only four of the twelve then-living inductees attended: [[Karen Kain]], [[Norman Jewison]], [[Barbara Ann Scott]] and [[Rich Little]].<ref name="Record">{{cite news|title=Sidewalk constellation; Walter Ostanek, Leslie Nielsen in group joining Canada's Walk of Fame|date=June 2, 2001|publisher=''[[The Record (Waterloo Region)|The Record]]''|author=John McKay}}</ref> Since 2008, the Walk of Fame also hands out the [[Cineplex Entertainment|Cineplex]] Legends Award, which is posthumously awarded "to Canadian pioneers in film, music, sport, arts, and innovation."<ref name="PR">{{cite web|url=http://www.newswire.ca/en/releases/archive/June2008/03/c7813.html|title=Canada's Walk of Fame Cements Another Legendary Group of Canadians into the Sidewalks of Toronto|publisher=CNW Group|date=June 3, 2008|accessdate=2008-06-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.canada.com/calgaryherald/news/entertainment/story.html?id=4371a73f-30bc-4193-819f-21cf3e9d32c4 |title=Albertans to take Canada's Walk of Fame |author=Canwest News Service |date=June 4, 2008 |accessdate=2008-06-04 |publisher=''[[Calgary Herald]]'' |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080605104718/http://www.canada.com/calgaryherald/news/entertainment/story.html?id=4371a73f-30bc-4193-819f-21cf3e9d32c4 |archivedate=5 June 2008 |df= }}</ref> In 2010 the Allan Slaight Award was introduced, which recognizes the achievements of young Canadians who have the ability to turn their talent into inspiration. The award is presented annually to a young Canadian who is making a positive impact in the field of music, film, literature, visual or performing arts, sports, innovation or philanthropy. The list of recipients of the Allan Slaight Award include: [[Nikki Yanofsky]] in 2010, [[Drake (rapper)|Drake]] in 2011, [[Melanie Fiona]] in 2012, [[Carly Rae Jepsen]] in 2013, [[The Weeknd]] in 2014 and [[Shawn Mendes]] in 2015.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}}
Of the 168 stars on the walk of fame, 154 are for individuals, including [[sportsperson|athlete]]s; coaches; actors, directors, writers and producers of movies, television and stage; singers, songwriters and musicians; playwrights; [[authors]]; comedians; [[cartoonists]]; and supermodels. Fourteen stars have been given to groups, such as music bands, comedy troupes, sports teams. In these cases, the group name is listed on the star and the names of individual members are omitted.<ref name="OSite">{{cite web|url=http://www.canadaswalkoffame.com|title=Canada's Walk of Fame|publisher=Canada's Walk of Fame|accessdate=2007-01-07}}</ref>
==Inductees== Some inductees were unable to attend the ceremony the year they were inducted, and as a result were honoured in a ceremony in a later year.

page.title: Martha, mother of Simeon Stylites the Younger

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.2)
revision.text:
{{Infobox saint |name=Saint Martha |birth_date=unknown |death_date=551 |feast_day=July 4 |venerated_in=[[Eastern Orthodox Church]] |image= |imagesize= |caption= |birth_place=[[Antioch]] |death_place= |titles= |beatified_date= |beatified_place= |beatified_by= |canonized_date= |canonized_place= |canonized_by= |attributes= |patronage= |major_shrine= |suppressed_date= |issues= }}
'''Saint Martha''' (died 551) was the mother of [[Simeon Stylites the Younger]]. She is [[veneration|venerated]] in the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]] on [[July 4 (Eastern Orthodox liturgics)|July 4]].
When her parents betrothed her to a young man, she seriously considered leaving home and withdrawing from the world. However, [[John the Baptist]] is said to have appeared to her and advised her to do as her parents had arranged and marry the man to whom they had betrothed her. Simeon Stylites was the child of this marriage.
She is said to have risen at midnight for prayer every night. She regularly helped those in need, visited the poor and orphans, and attended to the sick.
In the year before her death, she is said to have seen a number of [[angel]]s with candles in their hands and to have learned the time of her upcoming death from them. The vision prompted her to even greater dedication to prayer and good works.
She died in 551 AD, and was buried near her son.
There have been many reports of her appearing to various people since her death, generally to heal the sick and offer instruction to people. The most noted of these was to an abbot of the [[Monastery of Simeon Stylites the Younger|monastery founded by her son]]. The abbot placed a [[votive candle]] on her grave with the instruction that the light never be allowed to be extinguished. Martha appeared to him saying that when the abbot burned a light on her grave, he was asking her to pray to the Lord for him.
==References== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070928014909/http://www.westsrbdio.org/prolog/my.html?day=4&month=July Prolog:July 4 of the Western American Diocese of the Serbian Orthodox Church]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Martha, Mother Of Simeon Stylites The Younger}} [[Category:551 deaths]] [[Category:6th-century Christian saints]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] [[Category:Angelic visionaries]] [[Category:Christian female saints of the Middle Ages]]

'''Masagana 99''' was discontinued agricultural program of then [[Philippines|Philippine]] [[President of the Philippines|President]] [[Ferdinand Marcos]].<ref name=“Bettina”>{{Cite news |url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/video/news/10/26/16/farmers-oppose-revival-of-marcos-masagana-99 |title=Farmers oppose revival of Marcos’ ‘Masagana 99’ |last=Magsaysay |first=Bettina |work=ABS-CBN News |language=English, Filipino|date=27 October 2016|access-date=19 September 2017}}</ref> The Masagana 99 Rice Production Program aimed to increase rice production among Filipino farmers though critics said that it left poor farmers in debt and the program was used as a vehicle of political patronage.
==Etymology== “Masagana” is a Filipino term for “bountiful”<ref name=“Bettina”/> while 99 refers to the number of sacks of rice yielded per hectare of land in every harvest season.<ref name="return">{{cite news|last1=Nilles|first1=Giovanni|title=Return of FM’s Masagana 99, Biyayang Dagat eyed|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/10/24/1636806/return-fms-masagana-99-biyayang-dagat-eyed|accessdate=28 September 2017|work=The Philippine Star|date=24 October 2016}}</ref>
==Background== Promoted by Marcos as a way to for the Philippines to achieve [[rice]] [[Self-sufficiency economy|self-sufficiency]], the program achieved initial success by encouraging farmers to plant new [[IR8|“Miracle Rice” (IR8)]] variety of rice which the [[International Rice Research Institute]] had been developing since 1962, during the administration of President [[Carlos P. Garcia]].<ref name=“BillGanzel”>{{Cite web | url= http://www.livinghistoryfarm.org/farminginthe50s/crops_17.html |title=The Development of “Miracle Rice” Varieties |last=Ganzel |first=Bill |date=2007 |website=Wessels Living History Farm |publisher=Ganzel Group |access-date=19 September 2017}}</ref> The program was launched at the time the country was experiencing a shortage of supply on rice and was credited for the launching of the Philippine [[Green Revolution]] in 1973 which allowed the country to export rice to other Asian countries.<ref name="return"/>
However, the program eventually failed because its credit subsidy component proved unsustainable.<ref name=“1980”>{{Cite web |url=http://agris.fao.org/agris-search/search.do?recordID=XB8310418 |title=Some notes on the Masagana 99 [rice] program and small farmer access to credit [Philippines] |last=Economics) |first=Esguerra, E.F. (University of the Philippines, Quezon City. School of |date=1980 |website=Philippine Sociological Review (Philippines)|access-date=19 September 2017}}</ref> The program is said to have catered to rich landowners and has been criticized for leaving poor farmers in debt and for having become a vehicle of political patronage.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://manilastandard.net/news/national/233611/farmers-decry-da-s-masagana-6000-program.html|title=Farmers decry DA’s Masagana 6000 program|work=Manila Standard|access-date=2018-03-05|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|title=Marcoses should apologize to Filipino farmers|last=Tadem|first=Eduardo C.|date=|work=|access-date=2018-03-05|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://opinion.inquirer.net/93768/marcos-rule-no-model-progress|title=Marcos rule no model for progress|last=INQUIRER.net|access-date=2018-03-05|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=L.R.|first=Rola,|last2=Management)|first2=Peria, A. (Philippines Univ., Los Banos, College, Laguna (Philippines). Coll. of Economics and|date=1990|title=Economic considerations of policy issues associated with technology transfer in rural development|url=http://agris.fao.org/agris-search/search.do?recordID=PH9110976|journal=PCARRD Book Series (Philippines)|language=English}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sourcewatch.org/index.php/Masagana_99|title=Masagana 99 - SourceWatch|website=www.sourcewatch.org|language=en|access-date=2018-03-05}}</ref>
==Proposed revival== [[President of the Philippines|President]] [[Rodrigo Duterte]] expressed his interest to revive the program on October 2016.<ref name="return"/> The plan met opposition from MASIPAG, a group of farmers and scientist, saying that revival of the program will bring back issues such as debt, replacement of traditional varieties with newer ones, and the promotion of pesticide use which they say will harm animals, farmers and crops and insisted that only large firms benefited from the program. The [[Department of Agriculture (Philippines)|Department of Agriculture]] notes that the old variety used in the Masagana 99 program is already phaseout and the Masagana 99 can use newer varieties of rice and insists that environmentally friendly pesticides will be promoted under the potentially revived Masagana 99.<ref name=“Bettina”/>
== References == {{reflist}}

{{Infobox scientist |name = Natalia Rybczynski |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_date = |birth_place = |residence = |nationality = [[Canada|Canadian]] |death_date = |death_place = |field = [[paleontology]] |work_institution = [[Canadian Museum of Nature]] |alma_mater = [[Duke University]] |doctoral_advisor = |doctoral_students = |known_for = |prizes = |religion = |footnotes = }} '''Natalia Rybczynski''' is a [[Canada|Canadian]] [[paleobiology|paleobiologist]], [[professor]] and [[researcher]].
She is a research scientist with the [[Canadian Museum of Nature]] and holds a professorship at [[Carleton University]] in [[Ottawa]], [[Ontario]]. Her doctorate was obtained at [[Duke University]] and her main interests are evolutionary functional morphology, particularly at the polar climes.<ref>{{cite web|title=Natalia Rybczynski at the Canadian Museum of Nature|url=http://nature.ca/puijila/pr_tm_e.cfm#nr|website=Canadian Museum of Nature|accessdate=14 October 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141021170045/http://nature.ca/puijila/pr_tm_e.cfm#nr|archivedate=21 October 2014|df=}}</ref>
Rybczynski is notable for having discovered a previously unknown carnivorous arctic mammal, a proto-seal, which represents a [[transitional fossil|"missing link"]] between land-dwelling mammals and modern day ocean-going seals. ''[[Puijila darwini]]'' was discovered in 2007 on [[Devon Island]] in the Canadian arctic. Discovery of this specimen was announced in the journal [[Nature (journal)|''Nature'']] in April 2009. She has also contributed to the understanding of the biomechanics of ''[[Suminia]]'', a primitive mammal thought to exhibit early evidence of teeth and jaw structure specialized for chewing.<ref>{{cite web|title=Rybczynski|url=http://www1.carleton.ca/biology/people/natalia-rybczynski|website=Carleton University|accessdate=14 October 2014}}</ref> Her discovery of a fossil [[tibia]] of a [[High Arctic camel]] was featured in a November 2015 [[TED talk]] given by [[Radiolab]] producer Latif Nasser.<ref>{{cite web|title=You have no idea where camels really come from|url=https://www.ted.com/talks/latif_nasser_you_have_no_idea_where_camels_really_come_from|accessdate=15 April 2016}}</ref>
She is the niece of writer and architect [[Witold Rybczynski]].
==Selected publications== * Fraser, Danielle, et al. "[http://www.plosone.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0106499 Mean Annual Precipitation Explains Spatiotemporal Patterns of Cenozoic Mammal Beta Diversity and Latitudinal Diversity Gradients in North America]." PLoS ONE 9.9 (2014): e106499. * Eberle, Jaelyn J., Natalia Rybczynski, and David R. Greenwood. "Early Eocene mammals from the Driftwood Creek beds, Driftwood Canyon Provincial Park, northern British Columbia." Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology 34.4 (2014): 739-746. * Fraser, Danielle, and Natalia Rybczynski. "Complexity of ruminant masticatory evolution." Journal of morphology (2014). *Rybczynski, N., Gosse, J. C., Harington, C. R., Wogelius, R. A., Hidy, A. J., and Buckley, M. (2013). "Mid-Pliocene warm-period deposits in the High Arctic yield insight into camel evolution". Nature Communications 4 (1550): 1550. * Rybczynski, Natalia, Mary R. Dawson, and Richard H. Tedford. "A semi-aquatic Arctic mammalian carnivore from the Miocene epoch and origin of Pinnipedia." Nature 458.7241 (2009): 1021-1024. * Rybczynski, Natalia, and Robert R. Reisz. "Earliest evidence for efficient oral processing in a terrestrial herbivore." Nature 411.6838 (2001): 684-687. * Rybczynski, Natalia. Cranial morphology and phylogenetic significance of Suminia getmanovi, a Late Permian anomodont from Russia. 1997. * Rybczynski, Natalia, et al. "A three-dimensional animation model of Edmontosaurus (Hadrosauridae) for testing chewing hypotheses." Palaeontologia Electronica 11 (2008): 14. * Rybczynski, Natalia. "Castorid phylogenetics: implications for the evolution of swimming and tree-exploitation in beavers." Journal of Mammalian Evolution 14.1 (2007): 1-35. * Ballantyne, A. P., et al. "Pliocene Arctic temperature constraints from the growth rings and isotopic composition of fossil larch." Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology 242.3 (2006): 188-200. * Rybczynski, Natalia. "Cranial anatomy and phylogenetic position of Suminia getmanovi, a basal anomodont (Amniota: Therapsida) from the Late Permian of Eastern Europe." Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society 130.3 (2000): 329-373.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2001/06/0607_chewer.html National Geographic article on Suminia] referencing Rybczynski

{{Infobox person | name = Nia Daniati | image = | image_size = | birth_date ={{birth date and age|1964|04|17}} | birth_place =[[Jakarta]], Indonesia | deathdate = | deathplace = | height = | spouse = {{plainlist| *{{marriage|Mohammad Hisham|1991|1993|reason=divorced}} *{{marriage|[[Farhat Abbas]]|2002|2014|reason=divorced}} }} | children = 2 | parents = | yearsactive =1980–present | occupation ={{hlist|Singer|actress}} | website = }} '''Nia Daniati''' (born April 17, 1964) is an Indonesian singer and actress. Daniati gained fame with her hit single "Gelas-Gelas Kaca" and also through singing several songs written by musician [[Rinto Harahap]]. In addition, Daniati has appeared in several soap operas and films, including ''Antara Dia dan Aku'' which led to her being nominated for the [[Citra Award for Best Leading Actress|Best Actress]] at the [[Indonesian Film Festival]]. Daniati released many studio albums and singles in the 1980s and 1990s during her career in the local music industry. ==Personal life== In September 25, 1991, Daniati married Mohammad Hisham, a businessman from [[Brunei]] in [[Jakarta]] and the couple later had a daughter. After a year of marriage, Daniati and Hisham divorced. In 2002, Daniati married lawyer [[Farhat Abbas]], who is 12 years her junior. In 2014, Daniati filed for divorce from Abbas, due to him having an affair with his spokeswoman. ==Discography== ===Studio albums=== * ''Country vol.1'' * ''Nia Daniati The Best Of Pop Bossas'' * ''Nia Daniati Mega Pop Intim Vol 3'' * ''Nia Daniati 15 Lagu Terbaik'' * ''Tembang Asmara Vol. 1 (Siapa Tak Ingin Disayang)'' * ''Tembang Asmara Vol. 3 (Masih Ada Cinta)'' * ''Tembang Asmara Vol. 4 (Tak Ingin Seperti Dia)'' * ''Tembang Asmara Vol. 6 (Aku Tak Ingin Dimadu)'' * ''Tak Ingin Seperti Dia I'' (1993) * ''Tak Ingin Seperti Dia II'' (1998) * ''Tak Ingin Seperti Dia III'' (2016) ==Filmography== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !Year !Title !Role !Notes |- | 1979 | ''Antara Dia dan Aku'' | Nur | Debut film
Nominated – 1980 [[Indonesian Film Festival]] for [[Citra Award for Best Leading Actress|Best Leading Actress]] |- | 1980 | ''Senyum untuk Mama'' | | Supporting role |- | 1980 | ''Nostalgia di SMA'' | Anggra | Supporting role |- | 1981 | ''Setetes Kasih di Padang Gersang'' | | |- | 2016 | ''[[Gelas Gelas Kaca]]'' | | |- |} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Portal|Indonesia}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Daniati, Nia}} [[Category:1964 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Jakarta]] [[Category:Javanese people]] [[Category:Indonesian Muslims]] [[Category:Indonesian female singers]] [[Category:Indonesian-language singers]] [[Category:Indonesian actresses]]

{{Infobox musical artist | name = Nwe Yin Win
{{my|နွဲ့ယဉ်ဝင်း}} | image = | caption = | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Joyce Win | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1945|04|23|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Sagaing]], [[Burma]] | death_date = | instrument = | genre = [[Burmese pop]] | occupation = singer | years_active = 1970s to present | label = | associated_acts = | website = }} '''Nwe Yin Win''' ({{lang-my|နွဲ့ယဉ်ဝင်း}}, {{IPA-my|nwɛ̰ jɪ̀ɴ wɪ́ɴ|pron}}; born '''Joyce Win''' on 23 April 1945) is a [[Burma|Burmese]] [[singer]], considered one of the pioneers of modern [[Burmese pop music]].{{cite journal | title=Burmese Pop Music: Identity in Transition | author=Min Zin | url=http://www.irrawaddy.org/article.php?art_id=2710 | date=September 2002 | volume=10 | number=7 | work=The Irrawaddy | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100803105658/http://www.irrawaddy.org/article.php?art_id=2710 | archivedate=2010-08-03 | df= }} Nwe Yin Win was born in [[Sagaing]] to parents a [[Bamar]] father Min Swe (also known as Win Maung) and an [[Anglo-Burmese]] mother "Cathy" Tin Tin Hla. She attended the English-speaking [[BEHS 4 Tamwe|St. Francis Girls' School]] (today's Tamwe 4 High School) and [[BEHS 2 Sanchaung|St. Philomena's Convent High School]] (Sanchaung 2 High School). In 1967, she graduated from [[Rangoon University]] with a degree in [[English language|English]] before getting a master's degree (M.Ed.) in 1973 at the [[Yangon Institute of Education|Rangoon Institute of Education]]. During her time in college, she began dabbling with a music career. She was one of the most popular singers in [[Myanmar]] in the 1970s, known for her [[Burmese language]] [[cover song|covers]] of American [[country music|country]] and [[pop music|pop]] songs. Before her career in entertainment, she was a university lecturer in English. She continues to make records, even dabbling into [[Burmese hip hop]], and continues to perform in musical concerts.{{cite news | title=Piracy Hits Burma’s Legitimate Film and Music Scene | url=http://www.irrawaddy.org/article.php?art_id=6101 | author=Aaron Clark | publisher=Associated Press | date=2006-08-28 | access-date=2010-07-05 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100811185306/http://irrawaddy.org/article.php?art_id=6101# | archive-date=2010-08-11 | dead-url=yes | df= }} ==References== {{reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Win, Nwe Yin}} [[Category:1945 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Anglo-Burmese people]] [[Category:Burmese female singers]] [[Category:People from Sagaing Region]] [[Category:University of Yangon alumni]]

{{original research|date=October 2012}}
'''Peter Joseph Bis''' (c. 1951 - August 16, 2012) was a [[homeless]] man in [[Washington, D.C.]], known by the [[Capitol Hill]] community for his social personality and keen, savant-like memory.<ref name="washingtonpost1">{{cite news|author1=Steve Hendrix |author2=J. Freedom du Lac |lastauthoramp=yes |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/capitol-hill-grieves-for-homeless-man-who-was-neighborhood-fixture/2012/08/21/1395b668-ebc8-11e1-b811-09036bcb182b_story.html |title=Capitol Hill grieves for homeless man who was neighborhood fixture |publisher=The Washington Post |date=2011-07-18 |accessdate=2012-10-18}}</ref> His usual daytime location was the corner of Second Street and Massachusetts Avenue Northeast, sitting on a crate under a tree outside an [[Exxon]] station by [[Union Station (Washington, D.C.)|Union Station]]. According to his brother, James Bis, Bis suffered from [[schizophrenia]]. He would greet and converse with passers-by, often offering repetitive, random advice such as “No skinny dipping!” or pointing out the number of days until the weekend. He never drank alcohol or used drugs, but did use cigarettes and drink coffee. He took pride in his neighborhood, spent his days saying hello to the regulars who passed him on the sidewalk, and was provided with food and clothes by the local community. He was even given an apartment at one point, but was eventually evicted because his [[hoarding]] tendencies filled up his residence.<ref name="washingtonpost1"/> He would usually sleep in the garage of the Exxon station, and the Exxon workers would let him use a computer in the office.
==Early life== Little is known about Bis’s childhood or pre-college years. He grew up in [[Kalamazoo]] near [[Western Michigan University]], the son of two teachers. According to his younger brother James, Peter Bis attended Monsignor John R. Hackett High School graduating class of 1969, graduated from [[Western Michigan University]] in 1974 with a [[bachelor’s degree]] in [[history]]. He went to [[Thomas M. Cooley Law School]] in [[Lansing, Michigan]] for a year, then worked as a hotel night clerk, then started a car-painting company. He was unable to stick with these plans, however, and eventually started wandering the country as a result of his developing schizophrenia.<ref name="washingtonpost1"/>
==Schizophrenia== James Bis reported that the illness appeared in Peter Bis’s adult years, as the latter frequently started wearing a lead-lined baseball cap with red lights. The schizophrenia was eventually diagnosed, and his family petitioned that he be committed for treatment, but after only a few months of in-patient treatment, Bis began wandering the country. Though he was never known to have purposefully [[Hitchhiking|hitchhiked]], he would accept rides from drivers. James Bis described his brother as “a harmless kind of schizophrenic” who avoided getting help for his illness.<ref name="washingtonpost1"/>
Bis’s schizophrenia often made it difficult for listeners to figure out what was accurate in his stories of his past. He claimed that he had received the equivalent of five or six [[doctorates]], that he had studied in the [[Holy See|Vatican]], that he had been married and divorced, and that he once had a job as a [[cab driver]] in [[Michigan]].<ref name="blogspot2006">{{cite web|author=Marc |url=http://theworldaccordingtomarc.blogspot.com/2006/05/peter-joseph-bis.html |title=The World According To Marc: Peter Joseph Bis |publisher=Theworldaccordingtomarc.blogspot.com |date=2006-05-11 |accessdate=2012-10-18}}</ref> While most of his claims were ungrounded, these claims endeared Bis to the community, since they could never fully figure out his true background.
==Profound memory== The people of the local community frequently knew him for his keen memory. After his death, personal [[blogs]] and D.C. newspapers alike produced articles in memory of him, specifically mentioning his uncanny memory. Washington, D.C. journalist and professor, Terry Mattingly, an Orthodox Christian, referenced a conversation with Bis in which Bis wished him a happy Easter. After Mattingly had gone a few steps, Bis stopped him and recalled that [[Orthodox Christianity|Orthodox]] Easter was not until a week later. “He was right, of course. Had I shared that personal detail with him or did he glean that tidbit of liturgical minutia from one of the newspapers he read, day after day? Anyone who knew him could describe similar mysterious encounters,” wrote Mattingly in his column for [[Scripps Howard News Service]].<ref name="tmatt1">{{cite web|author=Monday, October 1st, 2012 <!-- by tmatt --> |url=http://www.tmatt.net/2012/10/01/a-soulful-voice-on-a-capitol-hill-sidewalk/ |title=Blog Archive » Soulful voice on a Capitol Hill sidewalk |publisher=tmatt.net |date=2012-10-01 |accessdate=2012-10-18}}</ref>
==Conspiracy theories== Besides his sharp memory, Bis was known by the community for his [[conspiracy theories]], which he delved into on his [[personal blog]], which according to the title, focused on “[[Holy See|Vatican]], [[Finances]], [[Sicilian Mafia|Mafia]], [[Kalamazoo]].” The blog was written in [[third-person narrative|third person]] and was one long post, which Bis added to routinely. The blog may have actually been written for him by another person, according to one source,<ref name="blogspot2006"/> but the identity of the person is unknown, apart from a theory that the blog’s dictation “to a friend” may have been the blog’s scribe. Bis reportedly believed he was an [[Extraterrestrial life|alien]], and was especially known for his claim that he was [[Princess Diana|Princess Diana’s]] ex-lover, and that the [[Central Intelligence Agency]] was responsible for her death. He preferred not to refer to himself as homeless, preferring the term “[[political refugee]].”
==Effect on the D.C. community== Numerous [[bloggers]] and [[Capitol Hill]] voices have referenced him as being extremely influential on the local community. After a period of time living by the [[United Nations]] building in New York City, Bis moved to Capitol Hill in Washington, D.C. He stationed himself outside the Exxon station next to [[Union Station (Washington, D.C.)|Union Station]] in D.C., particularly under the tree in front of the station. He usually sat on a crate under the tree, where he would greet passers-by every day. He would use the restrooms at the Exxon station, and help to keep it clean; he would only sleep inside the garage on especially cold nights—other than that, he insisted on sleeping outside.<ref name="washingtonpost1"/>
Since he usually kept his belongings under his tree, the D.C. local city government once threatened to remove his belongings. Betsy Woodruff of [[National Review Online]] reports that 24 of his acquaintances—including lobbyists and hill staffers—signed a petition against the removal of his possessions. Woodruff herself was acquainted with Bis from her time as an intern for the [[Heritage Foundation]], which was right next to Bis’s Exxon station. She said that upon introducing a friend of hers to Bis one day, he proceeded to take them into the Exxon to watch [[YouTube]] videos, smoke, and weep over the death of his [[ex-girlfriend]] Princess Diana. “So he probably didn’t date Lady Di,” wrote Woodruff. “But I’ve never heard anyone talk about a significant other with as much passion and kindness as Pete.”<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/corner/314207/memoriam-peter-bis-betsy-woodruff |title=In Memoriam: Peter Bis - By Betsy Woodruff - The Corner - National Review Online |publisher=Nationalreview.com |date=2012-08-16 |accessdate=2012-10-18}}</ref> A 2006 post from The World According to Marc blog reported meeting Bis while Bis happened to be sitting on a bench near [[Union Station (Washington, D.C.)|Union Station]] and three [[United States Senate]] buildings. The blogger, Marc, included a picture of Bis and shared the story of how Bis would never ask for money, but seemed particularly interested in the people he would meet. The blogger also mentioned that Bis had given him a business card and told him to follow his own—Bis’s—blog, which featured a lengthy, convoluted path of far-reaching [[conspiracy theories]]. Marc said that after initially meeting, he would make a point to walk to work early so that he could sit and chat with Bis for a bit.<ref name="blogspot2006"/>
Similarly, Josie of TellMeAStoryJosie blog reported having had a number of personal interactions with Bis. She reported his common “Three more days ‘til the weekend!” greeting, and his just as common, unrelated “No skinny dipping!” advice. “Pete was as much a part of the landscape of our life here on the Hill as the Capitol dome in the distance,” she wrote in her post about him, following the news of his death.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tellmeastoryjosie.wordpress.com/2012/08/16/pete-or-thoughts-on-home/ |title=Pete, or Thoughts on Home « tell me a story |publisher=Tellmeastoryjosie.wordpress.com |date=2012-08-16 |accessdate=2012-10-18}}</ref>
Bis was a popular individual for many D.C. interns, including the interns for [[Talk Radio News]], two of whom performed an interview with him in 2008. This also included interns from the [[Washington Journalism Center]], one of whom blogged about him on the program’s blog, also in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|last=Welcome |first=Rose |url=http://thewashingtonjournalismcenter.com/?p=5027 |title=Goodbye to a Hill icon » The Washington Journalism Center Blog |publisher=Thewashingtonjournalismcenter.com |date= |accessdate=2012-10-18}}</ref>
==Death== His death on August 16, 2012 was initially reported by the Running For 28 Years blog by bloggers from the local D.C. area. The blogger reported that he awoke to flashing blue and red lights around 1:30 a.m. outside his apartment window, not far from the Exxon station. After walking over to the station, the blogger asked a police officer who confirmed that Bis had been found dead inside the Exxon garage from an apparent [[heart attack]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.runningfor28years.com/journal/2012/8/16/rip-peter-biz.html |title=Squarespace - Account Not Available |publisher=Runningfor28years.com |date= |accessdate=2012-10-18}}</ref> His body was later cremated and sent to his brother, James Bis.<ref name="washingtonpost1"/>
A neighborhood Catholic church, St. Joseph’s on Capitol Hill, held a memorial [[Mass (liturgy)|Mass]] for him several weeks later. [[Terry Mattingly]] reported that a painting of Bis, titled, “A Contemplation of Justice,” was placed near the entrance of the church. The homilist, Deacon Gary Bockweg, said that over the years many people had suggested opportunities for Bis to get off the streets and into an actual job, including Bockweg’s own suggestion to work as a [[Wal-Mart]] greeter. However, Bockweg said that Bis had turned down the offer, saying he was over-qualified to work as a [[Walmart greeter|Wal-Mart greeter]]. Additionally, Bockweg shared information that when he had first seen Bis many years ago, Bis had been in St. Joseph’s and was well-dressed but quiet. As time passed, Bis began to arrive with less propriety, and even began bringing a wheelchair of what could only have been his personal effects. He also grew more talkative, which drew Bockweg to get to know him better.
“The last thing people do today when talking to a stranger is call them by name,” said Bockweg. “That’s how Pete connected. … He called us by name and that slowed us down. That made Pete real to us.”<ref name="tmatt1"/>
==References== {{Reflist}} <!-- <ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/capitol-hill-grieves-for-homeless-man-who-was-neighborhood-fixture/2012/08/21/1395b668-ebc8-11e1-b811-09036bcb182b_story.html | work=The Washington Post | first1=Steve | last1=Hendrix | first2=J. Freedom | last2=du Lac | title=Capitol Hill grieves for homeless man who was a neighborhood fixture | date=2012-08-22}}</ref> <ref>http://theworldaccordingtomarc.blogspot.com/2006/05/peter-joseph-bis.html</ref> <ref>http://www.tmatt.net/2012/10/01/a-soulful-voice-on-a-capitol-hill-sidewalk/</ref> -->
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bis, Peter Joseph}} [[Category:1951 births]] [[Category:2012 deaths]] [[Category:Homeless people]]

[[File:Pierangelo_Bertoli_1991.jpg|thumb|right|Pierangelo Bertoli (1991)]]
{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians --> | name = Pierangelo Bertoli | image = | caption = | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = | alias = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1942|11|05}} | death_date = {{death date and age|2002|10|07|1942|11|05}} | death_place = [[Modena]] | origin = [[Sassuolo]] ([[Italy]]) | instrument = [[Vocals]], [[Guitar]] | genre = [[Folk rock]] | occupation = [[Singer-songwriter]] | years_active = 1974–2002 | label = [[Compagnia Generale del Disco|CGD]], [[Ascolto]], [[Casa Ricordi|Dischi Ricordi]] | associated_acts = | website = [http://www.bertolifansclub.org/ Bertoli Fans Club] }} '''Pierangelo Bertoli''' (November 5, 1942 – October 7, 2002) was an [[Italians|Italian]] [[singer-songwriter]] and [[poet]]. Close to [[Communism|libertarian communist]] issues his works told mainly about [[Environmentalism|environment]], [[laïcité]], [[antimilitarism]] and social issues regarding marginalized and rebellious people.
==Biography== Born in [[Sassuolo]], in the [[Province of Modena]] and belonging to a working-class family, when he was 4 he suffered of [[poliomyelitis]] and he lost use of his legs. He started his career of singer at the end of 1973 with the album ''[[Rosso colore dell'amore]]'' (1974) and one year later with the self-produced album ''[[Roca Blues]]''. One of his most famous album was ''[[A muso duro]]'' of 1979.
In 1990, he collaborates with [[Elio e le Storie Tese]]. In 1991 (with [[Tazenda]]) and 1992 he took part to the [[Festival della canzone italiana|Sanremo Music Festival]].
His last album, ''[[301 guerre fa]]'' (2002) was composed with the collaboration of his son Alberto and [[Luciano Ligabue]]. Bertoli died in [[Modena]] on October 7, 2002 by a heart attack due to a [[tumor]].
Married with Bruna, Bertoli had 3 sons, Emiliano, Petra and [[Alberto Bertoli|Alberto]], also a [[singer]].
==Discography== {{colbegin}} *''[[Rosso colore dell'amore]]'' (1974) *''[[Roca Blues]]'' (1975) *''[[Eppure soffia]]'' (1976) *''[[Il centro del fiume]]'' (1977) *''[[S'at ven in meint]]'' (1978) *''[[A muso duro]]'' (1979) *''[[Certi momenti]]'' (1980) *''[[Album (Pierangelo Bertoli)|Album]]'' (1981) *''[[Frammenti]]'' (1983) *''[[Dalla finestra]]'' (1984) *''[[Petra (Pierangelo Bertoli)|Petra]]'' (1985) *''[[Canzone d'autore]]'' (1987) *''[[Tra me e me]]'' (1988) *''[[Sedia elettrica]]'' (1989) *''[[Oracoli]]'' (1990) *''[[Italia d'oro]]'' (1992) *''[[Gli anni miei]]'' (1993) *''[[Una voce tra due fuochi]]'' (1995) *''[[Angoli di vita]]'' (1997) *''[[301 guerre fa]]'' (2002) *''[[Promissas]]'' (2002, single) {{colend}}
==Sources== *{{cite book|first=Michele |last=Straniero |title=Pierangelo Bertoli|publisher=Lato Side |year=1981 }} *{{cite book|first=Domenico |last=Mangiardi|title="Pierangelo Bertoli : I "certi momenti"|publisher=Bastogi|year=2001|isbn=88-8185-404-X}} *{{cite book|first=Domenico |last=Mangiardi |title=Pierangelo Bertoli: Un emiliano tragico non è un vero emiliano|publisher=Giunti|year=2006 |isbn=978-88-09-04973-4}}
==External links== * {{IMDb name|id=0078200|name=Pierangelo Bertoli}} *{{it}} [http://www.bertolifansclub.org/ Bertoli Fans Club] (Official Bertoli website)

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}} {{Use South African English|date=April 2013}} {{Infobox minister | image = Pik Botha.jpg | honorific-suffix = | office1 = Minister of Mineral and Energy Affairs | term_start1 = 27 April 1994 | term_end1 = May 1996 | successor1 = Penuel Maduna | predecessor1=George Bartlett | president1 = [[Nelson Mandela]] | office2=Deputy Leader of the
[[National Party (South Africa)|National Party]] in [[Transvaal Province|Transvaal]] | leader2=[[F. W. de Klerk]] | term_start2=1987 | term_end2=1996 | office3 = [[Minister of International Relations and Cooperation|Minister of Foreign Affairs]] | term_start3 = 27 April 1977 | term_end3 = 10 May 1994 | successor3= [[Alfred Nzo]] | predecessor3= [[Hilgard Muller]] | primeminister3 =[[P. W. Botha]] (1978–84)
[[B.J. Vorster]] (1966–78) | president3 =[[F. W. de Klerk]] (1989-94)
[[P. W. Botha]] (1984-89) | office4 = [[Parliament of South Africa|Member of Parliament]] | constituency4 = [[Westdene, South Africa|Westdene]] | term_start4 = 1977 | term_end4=1994 | constituency5 = [[Wonderboom, Pretoria|Wonderboom]] | term_start5 = 22 April 1970 | term_end5=1974 | office6 = [[South African Ambassador to the United States]] | term_start6 = 30 July 1975 | term_end6 = 11 May 1977 | primeminister6= B.J. Vorster | predecessor6 = Johan Samuel Frederick Botha | successor6 =Donald Bell Sole |birth_name = Roelof Frederik Botha | birth_date = {{Birth date|1932|04|27|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Rustenburg]], South Africa | death_date = {{Death date and age|2018|10|12|1932|04|27|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Pretoria]], South Africa | spouse = Helena Susanna Bosman (m. 1953)
Ina Joubert (m. 1998) | party = [[National Party (South Africa)|National]] {{small|(until 1997)}} | children = 4 | residence = | alma_mater = [[University of Pretoria]] | occupation = Diplomat and politician | profession = Law | religion = [[Dutch Reformed]] }} '''Roelof Frederik "Pik" Botha''', {{post-nominals|country=ZAR|DMS}} (27 April 1932 – 12 October 2018) was a South African politician who served as the country's [[foreign minister]] in the last years of the [[History of South Africa in the apartheid era|apartheid era]].{{cite web | url=https://www.timeslive.co.za/news/south-africa/2018-10-12-apartheid-era-foreign-affairs-minister-pik-botha-has-died/ | title=Apartheid-era foreign affairs minister Pik Botha has died | publisher=TimesLive | accessdate=October 12, 2018}} He was considered a liberal – at least in comparison to others in the ruling [[National Party (South Africa)|National Party]] and among the [[Afrikaner]] community – but the bulk of his career was spent defending South Africa's apartheid system of [[racial segregation]] against foreign criticism. Botha was nicknamed 'Pik' (short for ''pikkewyn'', [[Afrikaans]] for 'penguin') because of a perceived likeness to a [[penguin]] in his stance, accentuated when he wore a suit.[http://archive.spectator.co.uk/article/7th-april-1984/9/a-smart-penguin A smart penguin], [[Geoffrey Wheatcroft]], ''[[The Spectator]]'', 7 April 1984, page 9 He was not related to Prime Minister (later President) [[P. W. Botha]], under whom he served as foreign minister.{{cite web |last1=Funteriano |first1=Andre |title=Explainer: Are you confusing Pik Botha with PW Botha? Meet both |url=https://briefly.co.za/17853-explainer-are-confusing-pik-botha-pw-botha-meet-both.html#17853 |website=briefly.co.za |accessdate=13 October 2018 |date=12 October 2018}} ==Early life== Botha was born at [[Rustenburg]] in the [[Transvaal (province)|Transvaal]].{{cite news |last1=Van der Vat |first1=Dan |title=Pik Botha obituary |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/oct/12/pik-botha-obituary-south-africa |accessdate=13 October 2018 |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' |date=12 October 2018}} At the age of four, he was struck by [[meningitis]] in [[Lourenço Marques]] (modern-day Maputo, Mozambique); he received treatment at a small hospital in [[Barberton, Mpumalanga|Barberton]], Transvaal, and his mother vowed that if he survived, he would become a church minister.[http://janiallan.com/2014/01/24/pik-botha-poetry-waves-politspeak/ Pik Botha – waves of politspeak] janiallan.com. 24 January 2014 Botha attended Paul Kruger Primary School where his father was principal. He excelled in high school, becoming chairman of the debating society, captain of the first rugby team and officer in the school cadets. Botha was also a keen writer of both prose and poetry in [[Afrikaans]], and his writing supplemented his salary in his early years as a diplomat. In his first year studying law at the [[University of Pretoria]], a [[theologian]] explained to him that God would not expect him to keep his mother's promise to become a church minister.{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/oct/12/pik-botha-obituary-south-africa|title=Pik Botha obituary|last=Vat|first=Dan van der|date=2018-10-12|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-10-15}} == Diplomat and lawyer == Botha began his career in the South African foreign service in 1953, serving in [[Sweden]] and [[West Germany]]. From 1963 to 1966, he served on the team representing South Africa at the [[International Court of Justice]] in [[The Hague]] in the matter of ''[[Ethiopia]] and [[Liberia]] v. South Africa'', over the South African occupation of [[South-West Africa]] (now [[Namibia]]). In 1966, Botha was appointed legal adviser at the Department of Foreign Affairs, in which capacity he served on the delegation representing South Africa at the [[United Nations]] from 1967 to 1977. In 1974, he was appointed [[South African Permanent Representative to the United Nations|South Africa's permanent representative to the United Nations]] and presented his credentials to [[UNSG|Secretary-General]] [[Kurt Waldheim]] on 15 October 1974;{{cite web |title=New Permanent Representative of South Africa Presents Credentials |url=https://www.unmultimedia.org/s/photo/detail/246/0246098.html |website=United Nations Photo |accessdate=14 October 2018 |date=15 October 1974}} in November of that year, however, South Africa was suspended from membership of the [[UNGA|General Assembly]] and, over the ensuing years, the country was excluded from official participation in virtually all of the UN's organs and agencies.{{cite web |title=United Nations: History and Present Status |url=http://www.dirco.gov.za/foreign/Multilateral/inter/un.htm |publisher=Department of International Relations and Cooperation, Republic of South Africa |accessdate=14 October 2018}} == Politician == In the elections of [[South African general election, 1970|1970]] and [[South African general election, 1974|1974]], Botha was elected to the [[House of Assembly of South Africa|House of Assembly]] as [[Parliament of South Africa|MP]] for [[Wonderboom, Pretoria|Wonderboom]] in the [[Transvaal Province|Transvaal]]. In 1975, he was appointed South Africa's Ambassador to the United States, in addition to his UN post. [[South African general election, 1977|In 1977]], he re-entered Parliament as MP for [[Westdene, South Africa|Westdene]], and was appointed [[Minister for Foreign Affairs]] by [[Prime Minister of South Africa|Prime Minister]] [[Balthazar Johannes Vorster|B. J. Vorster]]. He continued to represent Westdene for the remainder of his political career.{{cite news |last1=Donaldson |first1=Andrew |title=Pik Botha: A good man working for a bad government |url=https://www.news24.com/Obituaries/pik-botha-a-good-man-working-for-a-bad-government-20181012 |accessdate=14 October 2018 |publisher=news24.com |date=12 October 2018}} Botha entered the contest to be the leader of the National Party in 1978. He was allegedly considered Vorster's favourite and received superior public support among whites (''We want Pik!'') but withdrew after criticism concerning his young age, lack of experience (having spent 16 months as foreign minister) and alleged liberal beliefs as opposed to the ultra-conservative NP machinery (in which he lacked a significant position), instead throwing his support behind [[Pieter Willem Botha|P. W. Botha]], who was ultimately elected.[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,919860,00.html SOUTH AFRICA: The Not-So-Favorite Choice], ''[[TIME Magazine]]'', October 9, 1978 In 1985, Pik Botha helped to draft a speech that would have announced common decision-making on all levels in a single constitutional unit and a formula for bringing about the release of [[Nelson Mandela]], but this draft was rejected by P. W. Botha.[http://www.politicsweb.co.za/news-and-analysis/the-rubicon-revisited The Rubicon revisited], Hermann Giliomee, Politicsweb, 20 August 2008 The next year, he stated publicly (during a press conference in Parliament, asked by German journalist Thomas Knemeyer) that it would be possible for South Africa to be ruled by a black president provided that there were guarantees for [[minority rights]], but was quickly forced to acknowledge that this position did not reflect government policy.[http://www.iol.co.za/the-star/apartheid-still-spits-in-face-of-anc-1486293 Apartheid still spits in face of ANC], ''[[The Star (South Africa)|The Star]]'', 14 March 2013 Botha recalled in 2011 that he had been "severely reprimanded and almost fired" over his remarks.{{Cite news|url=https://www.timeslive.co.za/sunday-times/lifestyle/2011-08-07-what-ive-learnt-pik-botha/|title=FROM THE ARCHIVES {{!}} What I've learnt: Pik Botha|access-date=2018-10-15|language=en-US}} Throughout 1988 Pik Botha was instrumental in lengthy peace talks between South Africa, [[Cuba]], and the [[People's Republic of Angola]] aimed at ending the [[South African Border War]]. In December of that year Botha and Defence Minister [[Magnus Malan]] ratified the [[Brazzaville Protocol]], which led to the effective cessation of hostilities in that conflict.[https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1988/12/14/cuba-angola-south-africa-sign-accord/3269b973-4180-4c23-972b-179674f9e09b/ Cuba, Angola, South Africa Sign Accord], ''[[The Washington Post]]'', December 14, 1988 === Namibian independence === On 22 December 1988, Pik Botha signed the [[New York Accords|tripartite agreement]] involving [[Angola]], [[Cuba]] and South Africa at [[United Nations headquarters]] in New York City which led to the implementation of [[List of United Nations Security Council Resolutions 401 to 500|Security Council Resolution 435]], and to South Africa's granting of independence to [[Namibia]]. On 21 December 1988, Botha, with a 22-strong South African delegation from [[Johannesburg]], was initially booked to travel to the Namibian independence ratification ceremony in New York on [[Pan Am Flight 103]] from London. Instead, the booking was cancelled as he and six delegates took an earlier flight, thereby avoiding the fatal PA103 bombing over [[Lockerbie]], Scotland.[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/terrorism-in-the-uk/6060436/Lockerbie-and-the-conspiracy-theories.html Lockerbie and the conspiracy theories], ''[[Daily Telegraph]]'', 20 Aug 2009 ===National unity=== Botha subsequently served as Minister of Mineral and Energy Affairs in South Africa's first post-apartheid government from 1994 to 1996 under President [[Nelson Mandela]].{{cite web |last1=Mtshali |first1=Samkelo |title=News of #PikBotha's death draws mixed reaction in political arena |url=https://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/news-of-pikbothas-death-draws-mixed-reaction-in-political-arena-17462142 |website=iol.ca.za |accessdate=14 October 2018|date=13 October 2018}} Botha had first met Mandela in May 1990 at the historic [[Groote Schuur Minute]], and was highly impressed by Mandela's knowledge of [[Afrikaners|Afrikaner]] history. Botha became deputy leader of the National Party in the Transvaal from 1987 to 1996. He retired from politics in 1996 when [[Frederik Willem de Klerk|F. W. de Klerk]] withdrew the National Party from the government of national unity.{{cite news |title=South Africa shaken by sudden resignation of De Klerk's party |url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/south-africa-shaken-by-sudden-resignation-of-de-klerk-s-party-1.47572 |accessdate=14 October 2018 |publisher=''[[The Irish Times]]'' |date=10 May 1996}}{{cite news |last1=Madisa |first1=Kgothatso |title=Pik Botha one of 'leading personalities in SA politics' – De Klerk |url=https://www.sowetanlive.co.za/news/south-africa/2018-10-12-pik-botha-one-of-leading-personalities-in-sa-politics-de-klerk/ |accessdate=14 October 2018 |publisher=Sowetan Live |date=12 October 2018}} In 2000, Botha declared his support for [[President of South Africa|President]] [[Thabo Mbeki]]. Botha expressed criticism for the government's [[affirmative action]] policies saying that the South African government of 1994 would never have reached a constitutional settlement with the ANC had it insisted on its current affirmative action programme.[http://www.fin24.com/Economy/ANC-broke-AA-agreement-says-Pik-Botha-20130815 ANC broke AA agreement, says Pik Botha], [[News24|Fin24]], August 16 2013 In an interview on affirmative action, Botha publicly declared that he had never been a member of the ANC, and would not join under its current policies.[https://web.archive.org/web/20131023055631/http://www.beeld.com/nuus/2013-08-16-regstel-aksie-tref-swartes-ergste Regstel-aksie ‘tref swartes ergste’], ''[[Beeld]]'', 16 August 2013 (in [[Afrikaans]]) On 12 December 2013, Botha appeared on the BBC's ''[[Question Time (TV programme)|Question Time]]'', hosted in [[Johannesburg]], discussing the life and legacy of [[Nelson Mandela]].[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/nelson-mandela/10514293/BBC-Question-Time-in-South-Africa-Whos-Who.html BBC Question Time in South Africa: Who's Who], ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', 12 December 2013 ==Personal life== Botha married Helena Bosman in 1953, with whom he had two sons, the rock musician [[Piet Botha]] and the economist Roelof Botha,{{Cite news|url=https://www.iol.co.za/business-report/opinion/pik-botha-what-an-honour-to-know-this-man-17456592|title=Pik Botha: What an honour to know this man {{!}} IOL Business Report|access-date=2018-10-15|language=en}} and two daughters, Anna Hertzog and the artist Lien Botha. Among Botha's eight granchildren is grandson [[Roelof Botha]], former CFO of [[PayPal]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.fin24.com/BizNews/sa-prodigy-pik-bothas-43yo-grandson-to-lead-silicon-valleys-top-vc-firm-20170201|title=SA prodigy, Pik Botha’s 43yo grandson, to lead Silicon Valley’s top VC firm|work=Fin24|access-date=2018-10-15}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.timeslive.co.za/news/south-africa/2018-10-12-pik-bothas-last-days-recalled-by-family/|title=Pik Botha's last days recalled by family|access-date=2018-10-15|language=en-US}} Helena died in 1996, after having been ill, including being partially paralysed, following a fall in her home in 1991.{{Cite news|url=https://www.apnews.com/bd40daeec6a0827d151ff9c7dec0b541|title=Helena Botha, Wife of South African Minister, Dies After Long Illness|work=AP NEWS|access-date=2018-10-15}} Two years later, Botha took Ina Joubert, a former journalist with the [[South African Broadcasting Corporation|SABC]], as his second wife.{{Cite news|url=https://www.sahistory.org.za/dated-event/former-minister-foreign-affairs-pik-botha-marries-ina-joubert-ex-journalist-sabc-his-bir|title=Former Minister of Foreign Affairs, Pik Botha, marries Ina Joubert, ex-journalist of the SABC, on his birthday in Pretoria.|last=tinashe|date=2012-04-23|work=South African History Online|access-date=2018-10-15|language=en}} Botha died of natural causes at his home in [[Pretoria]] on 12 October 2018 at the age of 86.https://m.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/former-foreign-affairs-minister-pik-botha-dies-20181012https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-45833957 {{commonscat|Roelof Frederik Botha}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Wikiquote}} * [http://www.sahistory.org.za/pages/people/bios/botha-p.htm South African History Online] * [http://www.whoswhosa.co.za/Pages/profilefull.aspx?IndID=2778 South African Who's Who] {{S-start}} {{S-off}} {{S-bef|before=[[Hilgard Muller]]}} {{S-ttl|title=[[Minister of Foreign Affairs (South Africa)|Minister of Foreign Affairs]]|years=1977–1994}} {{S-aft|after=[[Alfred Nzo]]}} {{S-end}} {{SouthAfricaForeignMinisters}} {{Nelson Mandela cabinet 1}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Botha, Pik}} [[Category:1932 births]] [[Category:2018 deaths]] [[Category:People from Rustenburg]] [[Category:Afrikaner people]] [[Category:South African people of German descent]] [[Category:National Party (South Africa) politicians]] [[Category:Foreign ministers of South Africa]] [[Category:Members of the House of Assembly of South Africa]] [[Category:Members of the National Assembly of South Africa]]
