revision.text:
[[File:Poet-Diplomat Abhay K.jpg|thumb|Poet-Diplomat Abhay K]] '''Poet-diplomats''' are poets who have also served their countries as [[diplomats]]. The best known poet-diplomats are perhaps [[Geoffrey Chaucer]] and [[Thomas Wyatt (poet)|Thomas Wyatt]]; the category also includes recipients of the [[Nobel Prize in Literature]]: [[Ivo Andrić]], [[Gabriela Mistral]], [[Saint-John Perse]],<ref>{{cite web | url=http://news.unlv.edu/unlvtoday/saint-john-perse-poet-diplomat-and-nobel-prize-winner-nov-7 | title=Saint John Perse: Poet, Diplomat and Nobel Prize Winner | accessdate=13 November 2016}}</ref> [[Miguel Ángel Asturias]], [[Pablo Neruda]], [[George Seferis]], [[Czesław Miłosz]] and [[Octavio Paz]].<ref name="Abhay Kumar">{{cite news |title=Two shades of passion |author=Abhay Kumar |newspaper=[[The Kathmandu Post]] |date=November 3, 2012 |url=http://kathmandupost.ekantipur.com/ampnews/2012-11-03/two-shades-of-passion.html}}</ref><ref>[http://www.hindu.com/mag/2004/08/29/stories/2004082900290300.htm Diplomats as litterateurs] The Hindu August 29, 2004</ref><ref name=tcr>{{cite journal|last=Bertolet|first=Craig E.|title=Chaucer's Envoys and the Poet-Diplomat|journal=[[The Chaucer Review]]|year=1998|volume=33|issue=1|pages=66–89|jstor=25096037}}</ref> Contemporary poet-diplomats include [[Abhay Kumar|Abhay K]],<ref>{{cite news |title=Well versed in diplomacy |newspaper=[[Nepali Times]] |date=17–23 January 2014 |url=http://nepalitimes.com/article/review/abhay-kumar-poet-diplomat,1054}}</ref> [[Indran Amirthanayagam]], [[Kofi Awoonor]],<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/hay-festival/10326757/Kofi-Awoonor-the-literary-world-pays-tribute.html Kofi Awoonor: the literary world pays tribute, The Telegraph September 22, 2013]</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://bookhaven.stanford.edu/2013/09/the-face-of-a-massacre-eminent-poet-and-diplomat-kofi-awoonor-is-killed/ | title=The face of a massacre: eminent poet, diplomat Kofi Awoonor is killed | accessdate=13 November 2016}}</ref> [[Philip McDonagh]]<ref>{{cite web | url=http://irelandhouse.fas.nyu.edu/object/ne.philipmcdonagh2012 | accessdate=13 November 2016| title=Glucksman Ireland House}}</ref> and Yiorgos Chouliaras.<ref>[http://harvardreview.fas.harvard.edu/?q=authors/yiorgos-chouliaras Yiorgos Chouliaras] Harvard Review July 24, 2013</ref>
==Overview== Abhay Kumar wrote, "There seems to be a connection between poetry and diplomacy as several diplomats over the ages have excelled in poetry".<ref>{{cite news |title=Poetry and Diplomacy |author=Abhay Kumar |website=[[The University of Iowa]] |date=December 19, 2016 |url=https://iwp.uiowa.edu/silkroutes/city/new-delhi/text/poetry-and-diplomacy}}</ref> He further adds, "Diplomacy is a complex art that involves the mixing of political acumen, cultural finesse, language abilities and conversation skills to wield the power of persuasion. Diplomacy is generally conducted in short sentences which reveal as much as much they hide. Poetry is no different".<ref name="Abhay Kumar"/> He adds that poetry and diplomacy share a few attributes such as ambiguity and brevity in expressions, a detached handling of the subject matter among others.
Aldo Matteucci wrote, "Many diplomats have used poetry in their diplomatic work: wrapping words in silk is the diplomat’s job. A diplomat may turn a lie into a ‘constructive ambiguity’ – which is a way of defining poetry. Some poets have been diplomats – Neruda, Claudel, St. John Perse. It’s an occupational hazard: the stimulating place, the sheltered existence – and the ability to paraphrase the unknowable. Few diplomats will admit to using poetry as a survival strategy".<ref>{{cite news |title=Poetry: A Survival Strategy for Diplomats|author=Aldo Matteucci |newspaper=Reflections on Diplomacy |date=November 2, 2007 |url=http://deepdip.wordpress.com/2007/11/02/poetry-a-survival-strategy-for-diplomats/}}</ref>
Kamel S. Abu Jaber wrote,"The language of diplomacy, often like poetry, has the ability to move people from mood to mood".<ref>{{cite news |title=Language and diplomacy|author=Kamel S. Abu Jaber |newspaper=DiploFoundation |year= 2001|url=http://www.diplomacy.edu/resources/general/language-and-diplomacy/}}</ref>
Stefano Baldi and Pasquale Baldocci wrote in their book ''Through the Diplomatic Looking Glass'',"The publication of poetry by diplomats seems more inspired by an inner need to express oneself freely than the wish to share sensations and feelings developed during the career. Only verses with their detachment from reality can present an escape from cold and bureaucratic style often imposed by the profession".<ref>{{cite news |title=Poetry and Theatre|author=Stefano Baldi and Pasquale Baldocci|newspaper= Through the Diplomatic Looking Glass (page 57)Paperback, 176 pages {{ISBN|978-99932-53-18-1}} |year= 2007|url=http://issuu.com/minam/docs/through_the_diplomatic_looking_glass}}</ref>
Brazil bestowed the rank of Ambassador posthumously to its poet-diplomat [[Vinicius de Moraes]] recognizing his poetic talent.<ref>[http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/90001/90782/90873/7107465.html Brazil bestows posthumous rank on poet, diplomat Vinicius de Moraes] The People's Daily August 17, 2010</ref>
Russian diplomats have a curious obsession with poetry. “Poets and diplomats use the same building blocks: the idea and the word,” said Vladimir Kazimirov<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/russian-diplomats-have-a-curious-obsession-with-poetry/2016/04/01/c0c26d4e-f688-11e5-958d-d038dac6e718_story.html Russian diplomats have a curious obsession with poetry] The Washington Post, 2 April 2016 </ref>
“Poetry and diplomacy both rely on the alchemy of paradox. We mix fear and hope, power and weakness, love and hate to find a way out of the impossible,” said Dominique de Villepin, French Foreign Minister and a published poet in July 2002.<ref>[https://www.theglobalist.com/diplomacy-the-art-of-the-impossible/ Diplomacy — The Art of the Impossible? ] The Globalist, 31 December, 2012</ref>
==Notable poet-diplomats== <!--!>{{Gallery |title=Some poet-diplomats |width=160 | height=170 |align=right |footer=Chaucer |File:Geoffrey_Chaucer.jpeg |footer=Neruda |File:Pablo_Neruda_(1966).jpg }}can't fix my gallery, some gadget problem<--> *[[Giovanni Boccaccio]] *[[Thomas Wyatt (poet)|Thomas Wyatt]] *[[Diego Hurtado de Mendoza (poet and diplomat)|Diego Hurtado de Mendoza]] *[[Constantijn Huygens]] *[[Matthew Prior]] *[[Joel Barlow]] *[[Valentin Iremonger]] *[[Nizar Qabbani]] *[[Ahmed Fouad Shennib]] *[[Abioseh Davidson Nicol]] *[[Eduardo Cote Lamus]] *[[Shathel Taqa]] *[[Salah Stétié]] *[[David Rubadiri]] *[[Salah Ahmed Ibrahim]] *[[John Weston (diplomat)|John Weston]] *[[Li Zhaoxing]] *[[Homero Aridjis]] *[[Reda Mansour]] *[[Aleksander Griboyedov]] *[[George Henry Boker]] *[[Robert Bulwer-Lytton]] *[[Abd al Aziz al-Amawi]] *[[Wilfrid Scawen Blunt]] *[[Luís Caetano Pereira Guimarães Júnior]] *[[James Rennell Rodd]] *[[Elena Vacarescu]] *[[Émile Martel (writer)|Émile Martel]] *[[Félix Rubén García Sarmiento]] *[[Paul Claudel]] *[[Pablo Neruda]] *[[Miguel Ángel Asturias]] *[[James Weldon Johnson]] *[[Abdul Hadi Dawai]] *[[José Gorostiza Alcalá]] *[[Jorge Carrera Andrade]] *[[Denis Devlin]] *[[Vinicius de Moraes]] *[[Peter Zsoldos]] *[[Milan Rakić]] *[[Jovan Dučić]] *[[Miloš Crnjanski]] *[[Ivo Andrić]] *[[Joao Cabral de Melo Neto]] *[[Abdülhak Hâmid Tarhan|Abdülhak Hamit Tarhan]]
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[https://iwp.uiowa.edu/silkroutes/city/new-delhi/text/poetry-and-diplomacy Poetry and Diplomacy ] *[https://www.poetryfoundation.org/harriet/2012/04/poetry-diplomacy-in-the-congo/ Poetry Diplomacy in the Congo] *[http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/1754-0208.12338/pdf Poetry as an Act of International Diplomacy] *[http://culture360.asef.org/news/poetry-the-new-tool-of-soft-diplomacy/ Poetry the new tool of soft diplomacy ] *[http://www.rferl.org/a/washington-poetry-diplomacy-with-iran/26654728.html In Washington, Poetry Diplomacy With Iran ] *[http://jclc.dukejournals.org/content/1/1-2/241.abstract Poetry and Diplomacy in the Zuozhuan ] *[http://www.radionz.co.nz/national/programmes/saturday/audio/2564379/leilani-tamu-poetry-and-diplomacy Leilani Tamu - poetry and diplomacy ] *[http://zeenews.india.com/entertainment/bookworm/diplomatic-poetic-literature-a-growing-creativity_2434.htm Diplomatic poetic literature: A growing creativity ] <!--!>*[http://www.hindustantimes.com/StoryPage/Print/428343.aspx Poet-Diplomat] *[http://myrepublica.com/portal/index.php/twb/?action=news_details&news_id=56160 Poet Diplomat] ??<--> *[http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/kozhikode/homecoming-for-poetdiplomat/article4872844.ece Homecoming for poet-diplomat] *[http://www.jayanthadhanapala.com/content/ws11LudowykMemorialLecture.html The Diplomat as a creative writer]
[[Category:Diplomats by role]] [[Category:Poets]]

{{icelandic name|Páll|surname}} [[Image:Páll Melsteð.jpg|right|thumb|200px|Páll Melsteð in 1876.]] '''Páll Melsteð''' (13 November 1812 - 9 February 1910) was an [[Iceland]]ic historian, official, editor and member of the [[Althing]]. In 1892 he was awarded the [[Order of the Dannebrog]].
==Early life==
Páll was the son of [[Páll Melsteð (amtmann)|Páll Melsteð]] the official. At the age of 16 Páll entered the [[Menntaskólinn í Reykjavík|Learned School]] and graduated in 1834. He then went to study law at the [[University of Copenhagen]] but also studied history and the fine arts, especially singing. He returned to Iceland in 1840 when he married his first wife, Jórunn Ísleifsdóttir. They lived in [[Álftanes]] for several years where Páll started working on his first book, ''Ágrip af merkisatburðum mannkynssögunnar'' ["A Synopsis of the Significant Events of History"], which was printed in [[Viðey]] in 1844. He had also started work on a history of Iceland but in 1844 his house burnt down and his manuscripts were lost.
==Editor==
Páll now moved to [[Reykjavík]] where he was the prime mover in founding ''Reykjavíkurpósturinn'' at a time when no newspaper was being published in Iceland. Páll had a role in editing the paper from 1846 through 1849. In 1848 he also played a role in founding ''[[Þjóðólfur]]''. He also had a large role in the first years of ''Íslendingur'' (1860–1863) and was the editor of ''Víkverji'' in 1873 and 1874.
==Official== [[Image:Þóra Melsteð.jpg|right|thumb|Þóra Melsteð]] In 1848 and 1849 Páll was the [[sýslumaður]] (a kind of [[sheriff]]) of [[Árnessýsla]] but from 1849 to 1854 he was the sýslumaður of [[Snæfellsnessýsla]]. He was elected as a representative of [[Snæfellsnes]] to the [[National Assembly of 1851]] and to the [[Althing]] in 1859. In 1855 Páll again went again to Copenhagen to study law since he had not completed a degree the first time. He graduated in Danish laws in 1857. From 1858 to 1862 Páll was sýslumaður for [[Gullbringu- og Kjósarsýsla]]. In 1858 Jórunn died and Páll married his second wife, [[Þóra Melsteð]]. They were to work together on establishing [[Kvennaskólinn]], the first girls' school of Iceland.
==Historian==
From 1862 to 1885 Páll worked as a lawyer in Reykjavík. In 1868 he started teaching part-time at the Learned School and in 1885 he became a full-time history professor. In the 1860s Páll wrote and published a multi-volume work on world history, ''Fornaldarsagan'' (1864), ''Miðaldarsagan'' (1866), ''Nýja sagan'' (1868). In 1891 his ''Norðurlandasaga'' ["History of the Nordic Countries"] was published. He also wrote a number of historical articles in various periodicals. Páll's historical writings were praised for their lively and lucid writing style but criticized for their heavy emphasis on warfare and giving short shrift to cultural history. Páll's memoirs, ''Endurminningar'', were published posthumously in 1912.
==References==
* Ó[lafur] D[avíðsson] (1892). "Páll Melsteð", published in [http://www.timarit.is/?issueID=301488&pageSelected=0&lang=0 ''Sunnanfari'', July 1892]. In Icelandic. (The present article is largely a translation of Ólafur Davíðsson's (1862–1903) article.) *[[Peter Erasmus Christian Kaalund|Kr. Kaalund]]: ''[http://runeberg.org/dbl/11/0259.html Melsteð, Páll, f. 1812]'', entry in [[Carl Frederik Bricka|C. F. Bricka]] (ed.): ''[[Dansk biografisk lexikon]]: tillige omfattende Norge for Tidsrummet 1537–1814''; Gyldendal, Copenhagen 1887–1905; vol. XI (1897), p. 257f. In Danish. URL last accessed 2007-09-12. * N.N. "[http://www.althingi.is/altext/thingm/1311120008.html Páll Melsteð]" (2001). Published online, in Icelandic. Last retrieved on September 15, 2007. * Valtýr Guðmundsson: ''[http://illustrerettidende.dk/iti_pub/cv/main/HaefteSide.xsql?nnoc=iti_pub&p_AargangNr=34&p_HaefteNr=7&p_SideNr=76 Páll Melsted]'', in ''[[Illustreret Tidende]]'', vol. 34, no. 7, pp. 76–77; November 13, 1892. In Danish. URL last accessed 2007-09-18.
{{Authority control}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox War on Terror detainee | name = Ravil Mingazov | image = ISN 00702, Min Gazov Aviril.jpg | image_size = | caption = Ravil Mingazov`s official Guantanamo identity portrait | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1967|12|05}} | birth_place = [[Bolsheretski, Russia|Bolsheretski]], [[Russia]] | date_of_arrest = | place_of_arrest= Pakistan | arresting_authority= Pakistani officials | date_of_release = | place_of_release= | death_date = | death_place = | citizenship = [[Russia]]n | detained_at = [[Guantanamo Bay detention camp|Guantanamo]] | id_number = 702 | group = | alias = | charge = No charge [[extrajudicial detention]] | penalty = | status = * cleared for release through his [[habeas corpus]] petition * referred for prosecution by the [[Guantanamo Review Task Force]] * approved for transfer by the [[Periodic Review Board]] * transferred to the UAE on 2017-01-18 | csrt_summary = | csrt_transcript= | occupation = | spouse = | parents = | children = }} '''Ravil Mingazov''' is a citizen of [[Russia]] who was held in [[extrajudicial detention]] for almost fifteen years in the [[United States]]'s [[Guantanamo Bay detention camp]]s, in [[Cuba]].<ref name=DoDList2> {{cite web | url=http://www.dod.mil/news/May2006/d20060515%20List.pdf | title=List of Individuals Detained by the Department of Defense at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba from January 2002 through May 15, 2006 | publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]] | accessdate=2006-05-15 | quote= }} {{wikisource-inline|List of Individuals Detained by the Department of Defense at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba from January 2002 through May 15, 2006}} </ref> The Department of Defense reports that Mingazov was born on December 5, 1967, in [[Bolsheretski, Russia|Bolsheretski]], Russia.
Ravil Mingazov arrived at Guantanamo on October 28, 2002, and has been held at Guantanamo for {{Age in years, months and days|year=2002|month=10|day=28}}.<ref name=CshraHeightAndWeightTable> {{cite web |url = http://humanrights.ucdavis.edu/resources/library/documents-and-reports/gtmo_heightsweights.pdf |title = Measurements of Heights and Weights of Individuals Detained by the Department of Defense at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba (ordered and consolidated version) |publisher = [[Center for the Study of Human Rights in the Americas]], from DoD data |date = |author = |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fhumanrights.ucdavis.edu%2Fresources%2Flibrary%2Fdocuments-and-reports%2Fgtmo_heightsweights.pdf&date=2009-12-21 |archivedate = 2009-12-21 |deadurl = yes |df = }}</ref><ref name=NYTimesGuantanamoDocketIsn702> {{cite news | url=http://projects.nytimes.com/guantanamo/detainees/702-ravil-mingazov | title=Guantanamo Docket: Ravil Mingazov | publisher=[[New York Times]] | date=November 2008 | author= | accessdate=2010-04-13 | quote= }}</ref><ref name=Cv08-0442Doc88> {{cite web |url = http://docs.justia.com/cases/federal/district-courts/district-of-columbia/dcdce/1:2008mc00442/13190/88/0.pdf |title = Guantanamo Bay Detainee Litigation: Doc 88 -- petitioners' status report |publisher = [[United States Department of Justice]] |author = [[Douglas K. Spaulding]] |date = 2008-08-19 |accessdate = 2008-08-23 |quote = }} [https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fdocs.justia.com%2Fcases%2Ffederal%2Fdistrict-courts%2Fdistrict-of-columbia%2Fdcdce%2F1%3A2008mc00442%2F131990%2F88%2F0.pdf&date=2008-08-22 mirror] </ref><ref name=MassLive2009-11-10>{{cite news |url = http://www.masslive.com/news/index.ssf/2009/11/ravil_mingazov_one_of_guantana.html |title = Ravil Mingazov, one of Guantanamo Bay detention camp refugees Amherst is considering offering resettlement to, wanted by Interpol |publisher = [[Massachusetts Live]] |date = 2009-11-10 |author = Diane Lederman |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.masslive.com%2Fnews%2Findex.ssf%2F2009%2F11%2Fravil_mingazov_one_of_guantana.html&date=2009-11-12 |archivedate = 2009-11-12 |deadurl = yes |df = }}</ref><ref name=OfficialGuantanamoWeights>{{cite web |url = http://www.dod.mil/pubs/foi/detainees/measurements/ |title = Measurements of Heights and Weights of Individuals Detained by the Department of Defense at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba |publisher = [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] |author = [[JTF-GTMO]] |date = 2007-03-16 |accessdate = 2008-12-22 |quote = |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.dod.mil%2Fpubs%2Ffoi%2Fdetainees%2Fmeasurements&date=2008-12-22 |archivedate = 2008-12-22 |df = }} </ref>
Mingazov, a member of the [[tatars]] ethnic group, was a [[ballet dancer]], before he joined the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] army.<ref name=TheGuardian2015-11-05/> Anti-Muslim harassment drove Mingazov to leave Russia for [[Tajikistan]], in 2000.
Mingazov was approved for transfer on July 21, 2016.<ref name=MiamiHerald2016-07-21/> He was transferred to the [[United Arab Emirates]] on January 18, 2017.
==Official status reviews==
===Office for the Administrative Review of Detained Enemy Combatants=== [[File:CSRT notice read to a Guantanamo captive.jpg|thumb|Following the [[SCOTUS|Supreme Court's]] ruling in [[Rasul v. Bush]] the DoD was required to read a notice to every captive informing them that they would have an opportunity to learn why they were being held, and to offer a response, at their Combatant Status Review Tribunal.]]
Scholars at the [[Brookings Institution]], led by [[Benjamin Wittes]], listed the captives still held in Guantanamo in December 2008, according to whether their detention was justified by certain common allegations:<ref name=Brookings2008-12-16> {{cite news |url = http://www.brookings.edu/~/media/research/files/reports/2008/12/16%20detainees%20wittes/1216_detainees_wittes.pdf |title = The Current Detainee Population of Guantánamo: An Empirical Study |publisher = [[The Brookings Institution]] |date = 2008-12-16 |author = [[Benjamin Wittes]], Zaathira Wyne |accessdate = 2010-02-16 |quote = Al Sani said he traveled to Afghanistan shortly before September 11 and trained on a Kalashnikov. "I felt it was important in coming of age," he said. "I went to Afghanistan for weapons training, not to fight anyone." |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.brookings.edu%2F%7E%2Fmedia%2Fresearch%2Ffiles%2Freports%2F2008%2F12%2F16%2520detainees%2520wittes%2F1216_detainees_wittes.pdf&date=2012-06-22 |archivedate = 2012-06-22 |df = }}
</ref>
* Ravil Mingazov was listed as one of the captives who ''"The military alleges ... are associated with Al Qaeda."''<ref name=Brookings2008-12-16/> * Ravil Mingazov was listed as one of the captives who ''"The military alleges ... stayed in Al Qaeda, Taliban or other guest- or safehouses."''<ref name=Brookings2008-12-16/> * Ravil Mingazov was listed as one of the captives who ''"The military alleges ... took military or terrorist training in Afghanistan."''<ref name=Brookings2008-12-16/> * Ravil Mingazov was listed as one of the captives who ''"The military alleges that the following detainees were captured under circumstances that strongly suggest belligerency."''<ref name=Brookings2008-12-16/> * Ravil Mingazov was listed as one of the captives who was an ''"al Qaeda operative"''.<ref name=Brookings2008-12-16/> * Ravil Mingazov was listed as one of the ''"34 [captives] admit to some lesser measure of affiliation—like staying in Taliban or Al Qaeda guesthouses or spending time at one of their training camps."''<ref name=Brookings2008-12-16/> * Ravil Mingazov was listed as one of the captives who had ''"stayed at Taliban or Al Qaeda guesthouses."''<ref name=Brookings2008-12-16/> * Ravil Mingazov was listed as one of the captives who had admitted ''"some form of associational conduct."''<ref name=Brookings2008-12-16/>
===Writ of habeas corpus===
On May 13, 2010, [[US District Court Judge]] [[Henry H. Kennedy, Jr.]], the Obama administration to release Mingazov under the writ of habeas corpus.<ref name=TheGuardian2015-11-05/><ref name=McClatchy2010-05-04/><ref name=RiaNovosti2013-12-27/> Mingazov's was the 35 case where the judge ordered a release. The government had succeeded in convincing a habeas corpus judge continued detention was justified in an additional 13 cases.
A panel of judges on the Washington DC court of appeals reversed Kennedy's release order.<ref name=TheGuardian2015-11-05/>
===Formerly secret JTF-GTMO assessment===
On April 25, 2011, the whistleblower organization [[WikiLeaks]] published formerly secret assessments prepared by [[Joint Task Force Guantanamo]].<ref name=TheTelegraphDabDatabase> {{cite news | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/wikileaks-files/guantanamo-bay-wikileaks-files/8476672/WikiLeaks-The-Guantanamo-files-database.html | title = WikiLeaks: The Guantánamo files database | publisher = [[The Telegraph (UK)]] | date = 2011-04-27 | accessdate = 2012-07-10 }} </ref><ref name=TheTelegraphDabIsn702> {{cite news | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/wikileaks-files/guantanamo-bay-wikileaks-files/8477242/Guantanamo-Bay-detainee-file-on-Ravil-Mingazov-US9RS-000702DP.html | title = Guantanamo Bay detainee file on Ravil Mingazov, US9RS-000702DP, passed to the Telegraph by Wikileaks | publisher = [[The Telegraph (UK)]] | date = 2011-04-27 | accessdate = 2012-07-11 }} </ref> Ravil`s assessment was nine pages and recommended continued detention under DoD Control.<ref name=JtfGtmoAssessmentIsn702> {{cite news | url = http://media.mcclatchydc.com/smedia/2011/04/27/20/us9rs-000702dp.source.prod_affiliate.91.pdf | title = Recommendation for Continued Detention Under DoD Control (CD) for Guantanamo Detainee, ISN US9RS-00072DP | publisher = [[Joint Task Force Guantanamo]] | author = [[Mark H. Buzby]] | date = 2008-03-14 | accessdate = 2012-07-11 | quote = }} {{Commons-inline|File:ISN 00702, Min Gazov Aviril's Guantanamo detainee assessment.pdf}} </ref> It was signed by camp commandant [[Mark H. Buzby]].
===Guantanamo Joint Task Force Review===
On January 20, 2009, newly inaugurated [[United States President|President]] [[Barack Obama]] issued several [[Executive order (United States)|Presidential Executive Orders]] related to the Guantanamo detention center – which he had promised to close during his presidential campaign. Those Executive Orders set up a [[Guantanamo Review Task Force]], intended to replace OARDEC. In October 2013, [[Freedom of Information Act (United States)|Freedom of Information Act]] requests submitted by [[Carol Rosenberg]] and her colleagues at the ''[[Miami Herald]]'' triggered the publication of a list of ''"final dispositions"''.<ref name=OfficialGuantanamoDispositions> {{cite news | url = http://media.miamiherald.com/smedia/2013/06/17/15/48/2VNpb.So.56.pdf | title = Guantanamo Review Dispositions: Final Dispositions as of January 22, 2010 | publisher = [[United States Department of Defense]] | author = [[Guantanamo Review Task Force]] | date = January 22, 2010 | page = | location = | isbn = | accessdate = 2013-12-30 | quote = Ravil Mingazov Referred for prosecution. }} {{wikisource-inline|Guantanamo Review Dispositions -- Final Dispositions as of January 22, 2010}} </ref> According to that list Ravil Mingazov should be ''"referred for prosecution"''.
==Repatriation discussions==
Russian officials are scheduled to travel to Guantanamo on January 17, 2014, to meet with Mingazov.<ref name=RiaNovosti2013-12-27> {{cite news | url = http://en.ria.ru/russia/20131227/185979866/Russian-Delegation-to-Meet-Guantanamo-Prisoner.html | title = Russian Delegation to Meet Guantanamo Prisoner | publisher = [[Ria Novosti]] | author = | date = 2013-12-27 | page = | location = [[Moscow]] | isbn = | accessdate = 2013-12-30 | archivedate = 2013-12-30 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131230213148/http://en.ria.ru/russia/20131227/185979866/Russian-Delegation-to-Meet-Guantanamo-Prisoner.html | deadurl = No | quote = "We will use this visit and put the question bluntly so that this special facility will be closed as soon as possible," Dolgov said, noting that the long-discussed meeting had been delayed for "many months, if not years" because conditions for the visit had not been agreed upon with the US. }} </ref> According to the ''[[Moscow Times]],'' visiting Russian officials had been turned away in April 2013, because Mingazov had declined to meet with them.<ref name=MoscowTimes2014-01-17> {{cite news |url=http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/foreign-ministrys-rights-commissioner-to-visit-russian-inmate-at-guantanamo-bay-prison/492913.html |title=Foreign Ministry's Rights Commissioner to Visit Russian Inmate at Guantanamo Bay Prison |publisher=[[Moscow Times]] |author= |date=2014-01-17 |page= |location= |isbn= |accessdate=2014-01-17 |archivedate=2014-01-17 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140117212555/http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/foreign-ministrys-rights-commissioner-to-visit-russian-inmate-at-guantanamo-bay-prison/492913.html |deadurl=no |quote=In April 2013, the U.S. barred a Russian delegation from visiting Mingazov at the base in Cuba on the grounds that the prisoner had refused to meet them. |df= }} <!-- --> </ref>
==Asylum in the United Kingdom==
On November 6, 2015, [[The Guardian (UK)|''The Guardian'']] reported that Mingazov's teenage son and his former wife now live in the [[United Kingdom]], and that his family had filed an asylum application on his behalf.<ref name=TheGuardian2015-11-05/> His son and former wife arrived in the UK in 2014, and live with other relatives of Mingazov there.<ref name=Nottingham2017-01-21/>
==Transfer to the United Arab Emirates==
Mingazov was one of the last four individuals to be transferred from Guantanamo before the end Barack Obama's Presidency.<ref name=Nottingham2017-01-21/> Mingazov, an Afghan, [[Wali Mohammed (ISN 540)|Wali Mohammed]], and a Yemeni, [[Yassim Qasim Mohammed Ismail Qasim]], were transferred to the [[United Arab Emirates]], while [[Jabran al-Qahtani]] was repatriated to [[Saudi Arabia]], on January 18, 2017, just two days prior to [[Donald Trump]]'s inauguration. Trump had promised to curtail all transfers from Guantanamo.
==References== {{reflist|2|refs= <ref name=Nottingham2017-01-21> {{cite news |url = http://www.nottinghampost.com/guantanamo-bay-prisoner-with-al-qaeda-links-who-wanted-to-come-to-nottingham-is-now-free/story-30074411-detail/story.html |title = Guantanamo Bay prisoner with 'Al Qaeda links' who wanted to come to Nottingham is now free |publisher = [[Nottingham Post]] |author = Tracy Walker |date = 2017-01-21 |page = |location = |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nottinghampost.com%2Fguantanamo-bay-prisoner-with-al-qaeda-links-who-wanted-to-come-to-nottingham-is-now-free%2Fstory-30074411-detail%2Fstory.html&date=2017-01-22 |archivedate = 2017-01-22 |accessdate = 2017-01-22 |deadurl = yes |quote = Now his legal team have confirmed that the Russian national is now out of jail, and that he is currently in the United Arab Emirates (UAE). |df = }} </ref>
<ref name=MiamiHerald2016-07-21> {{cite news | url = http://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/world/americas/guantanamo/article91757887.html | title = Parole board OKs release of Guantánamo's last Russian captive | publisher = [[Miami Herald]] | author = [[Carol Rosenberg]] | date = 2016-07-25 | page = | location = | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160726133435/http://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/world/americas/guantanamo/article91757887.html | archivedate = 2016-07-26 | accessdate = 2017-01-22 | deadurl = No | quote = His attorney said Monday that Mingazov would resist going back to his homeland, which Thompson said has sent delegations to meet Mingazov at this base and informed him he would be punished for fleeing Russia without permission. }} </ref> <!-- {{cite news | url = | title = | publisher = | author = | date = | page = | location = | isbn = | language = [[English language|English]] | trans_title = | accessdate = 2017-01-22 | quote = }} </ref> --> <ref name=TheGuardian2015-11-05> {{cite news | url = https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/nov/05/russian-guantanamo-detainee-uk-ravil-mingazov-shaker-aamer | title = Russian Guantánamo detainee poses fresh diplomatic dilemma for UK | accessdate = 2015-11-06 | publisher = [[The Guardian (UK)|''The Guardian'']] | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151106035351/http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/nov/05/russian-guantanamo-detainee-uk-ravil-mingazov-shaker-aamer | archivedate = 2015-11-06 | deadurl = no | quote = Now his Washington DC-based lawyers have filed an official application with the UK Home Office appealing for Mingazov to be allowed to rejoin his family, who were granted political asylum in the UK last year. His 15-year-old son Yusef and former wife Dilyara Mingazov live in Nottingham along with several relatives. }} </ref> <ref name=McClatchy2010-05-04> {{cite news | url = http://www.mcclatchydc.com/2010/05/14/94155/russian-dancer-detained-at-guantanamo.html | title = Russian dancer ordered freed in Guantanamo habeas case | publisher = [[McClatchy News Service]] | author = [[Carol Rosenberg]] | date = 2010-05-14 | page = | location = | isbn = | accessdate = 2013-12-30 | archivedate = 2010-05-16 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100516213318/http://www.mcclatchydc.com/2010/05/14/94155/russian-dancer-detained-at-guantanamo.html | deadurl = No | quote = A federal court on Thursday ordered the Pentagon to set free from Guantáaamo a former Russian Army ballet dancer turned devout Muslim whose plight captured the imagination of a Massachusetts college town. }} </ref> }}
==External links== *[http://www.andyworthington.co.uk/2010/05/19/judge-orders-release-from-guantanamo-of-russian-caught-in-abu-zubaydahs-web/ Judge Orders Release from Guantánamo of Russian Caught in Abu Zubaydah’s Web] [[Andy Worthington]] May 19, 2010 * [http://www.commondreams.org/newswire/2010/05/14-5 Two Massachusetts Towns Welcome Guantánamo Detainee Ordered Released by a Federal Judge] [[Common Dreams NewsCenter]] May 14, 2010 * [http://www.rferl.org/content/Guantanamo_Prisoners_Mother_Says_Son_Fears_Returning_To_Russia/2046100.html Guantanamo Prisoner's Mother Says Son Fears Returning To Russia] [[Radio Free Europe]] May 18, 2010 *Human Rights First; [http://www.humanrightsfirst.info/pdf/Habeas-Works-final-web.pdf Habeas Works: Federal Courts’ Proven Capacity to Handle Guantánamo Cases (2010)]{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}
{{WoTPrisoners|state=collapsed}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Mingazov, Ravil}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People held at the Guantanamo Bay detention camp]] [[Category:Russian extrajudicial prisoners of the United States]] [[Category:Russian people]] [[Category:1967 births]]

revision.comment: alphabetized in category; added headings; removed credential per [[WP:CREDENTIAL]]; removed red link: [[WP:WTAF]]
revision.text:
The '''research-based design''' process is a research process proposed by Teemu Leinonen inspired by design theories.<ref>Ehn, P. & Kyng, M. (1987). "The Collective Resource Approach to Systems Design". In G. Bjerknes, P. Ehn & M. Kyng (Eds.), ''Computers and Democracy: A Scandinavian Challenge'' (pp. 17–57).Avebury.</ref><ref>Schön, D.A. (1987). ''Educating the Reflective Practitioner. Toward a New Design for Teaching and Learning in the Professions''. San Francisco: Jossey-Bass Publishers.</ref><ref>Nelson, H. & Stolterman, E. (2003). The Design Way: Intentional Change in an Unpredictable World: Foundations and Fundamentals of Design Competence. New Jersey: Educational Technology Publications</ref> It is strongly oriented towards the building of [[prototype]]s and it emphasizes creative solutions, exploration of various ideas and design concepts, continuous testing and redesign of the design solutions. This method is also influenced by the [[Participatory design#History in Scandinavia|Scandinavian participatory design]] approach. Therefore, most of the activities take place in a close [[dialogue]] with the community that is expected to use the tools designed.
==Phases== The process can be divided into four major phases, although they all happen concurrently and side-by-side. At different times of the research, researchers are asked to put more effort into different phases. The continuous iteration, however, asks researchers to keep all the phases alive all the time: contextual inquiry, participatory design, product design, prototype as hypothesis.
===Contextual inquiry=== {{See also|Contextual inquiry}} Contextual inquiry refers to the exploration of the socio-cultural context of the design. The aim is to understand the environment, situation, and culture where the design takes place. The results of the contextual inquiry are better understanding of the context by recognizing in it possible challenges and design opportunities. In this phase, design researchers use [[Ethnography|rapid ethnographic]] methods, such as [[Participant observation|participatory observation]], note-taking, sketching, informal conversations, and interviews. At the same time as the field work, the design researchers are doing a focused review of the literature, benchmarking existing solutions, and analyzing trends in the area in order to develop insights into the design challenges.
===Participatory design=== {{See also|Participatory design}} Throughout the contextual inquiry design researchers start to develop some preliminary design ideas, which would be validated during the next stage—participatory design—in workshops with different stakeholders. The participatory design sessions tend to take place with small groups of 4 to 6 participants. A common practice is to present the results as [[User scenario|scenarios]] made by the design researchers containing challenges and design opportunities. In the workshop, the participants are invited to come up with design solutions to the challenges and to bring to the discussion new challenges and solutions.
Since one of the main features of the research-based design is its participatory nature, the user's involvement is an integral part of the process. In this regard, participatory design workshops are organized during the different stages in order to validate initial ideas and discuss the prototypes at different stage of development.
===Product design=== {{See also|Product design}} The results of the participatory design are analyzed in a [[design studio]] by the design researchers who use the feedback to redefine the design problems and redesign the prototypes. By keeping a distance from the stakeholders, in the product design phase the design researchers will get a chance to analyze the results of the participatory design, categorize them, use specific design language related to implementation of the prototypes, and finally make design decisions.
===Prototype as hypothesis=== Ultimately, the prototypes are developed to be functional on a level that they can be tested with real people in their everyday situations. The prototypes are still considered to be a hypothesis, prototypes as hypothesis, because they are expected to be part of the solutions for the challenges defined and redefined during the research. It remains to the stakeholders to decide whether they support the assertions made by the design researchers.
Research-based design is not to be confused with design-based research.<ref>Barab, S.A. & Squire, K. (2004). Design-Based Research: Putting a Stake in the Ground. Journal of the Learning Sciences, 13(1), 1-14.</ref><ref>The Design-Based Research Collective. (2003). Design-based research: An emerging paradigm for educational inquiry. Educational Researcher, 5-8.</ref><ref>Fallman, D. (2007). Why Research-Oriented Design Isn’t Design-Oriented Research: On the Tensions Between Design and Research in an Implicit Design Discipline. Knowledge, Technology & Policy, 20(3), 193-200.</ref><ref>Leinonen, T., Toikkanen, T. & Silfvast, K. (2008). Software as Hypothesis: Research-Based Design Methodology. In the Proceedings of Participatory Design Conference 2008. Presented at the Participatory Design Conference, PDC 2008, Indiana University, Bloomington, IN, USA: ACM.</ref> In research-based design, which builds on art and design tradition, the focus is on the artifacts, the end-results of the design. The way the artifacts are, the affordances and features they have or do not have, form an important part of the research argumentation. As such, research-based design as a methodological approach includes research, design, and design interventions that are all intertwined.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Design}}
[[Category:Design]] [[Category:Research and development]] [[Category:Design researchers| ]]

{{Infobox Officeholder | name = Ricardo Alarcón de Quesada | image = Ricardo Alarcon (TV Brasil, 2008).jpg | caption = Ricardo Alarcón in 2008
(Photo: Marcello Casal Jr./ABr) | nationality = [[Cuban people|Cuban]] | office = President of the [[National Assembly of People's Power]] | term_start = 24 February 1993 | term_end = 24 February 2013 | vicepresident = [[Jaime Alberto Hernandez-Baquero Crombet]] | predecessor = [[Juan Escalona Reguera]] | successor = [[Esteban Lazo]] | office2 = [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Cuba)|Minister of Foreign Affairs]] | premier2 = [[Fidel Castro]] | term_start2 = 1992 | term_end2 = 1993 | predecessor2 = [[Isidoro Malmierca Peoli]] | successor2 = [[Roberto Robaina]] |birth_name=Ricardo Alarcón de Quesada | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1937|5|21|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Havana]], [[Cuba]] | death_date = | death_place = | residence = | party = [[Communist Party of Cuba]] | profession = [[Civil servant]] | signature = }} '''Ricardo Alarcón de Quesada''' (born 21 May 1937) is a [[Cuban people|Cuban]] politician. He served as Cuba's Permanent Representative to the [[United Nations]] (UN) for nearly 30 years and later served as [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Cuba)|Minister of Foreign Affairs]] from 1992 to 1993. Subsequently, Alarcón was President of the [[National Assembly of People's Power]] from 1993 to 2013, and because of this post, was considered the third-most powerful figure in Cuba.{{cite news|title=Cuba parliament opens as Fidel Castro visits|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-21568158|accessdate=24 February 2013|newspaper=BBC World Service|date=24 February 2013}} He also was a Member of the Central Committee of the [[Communist Party of Cuba]] until 2013.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-23157254 Cuba removes Ricardo Alarcon from top Communist body] A graduate of the [[University of Havana]] with a doctorate in philosophy, he served in various diplomatic posts following the [[Cuban Revolution]]. His first post in connection with Cuba's foreign policy was as Head of the Americas Division of Cuba's [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Cuba)|Foreign Ministry]]. During his tenure as Permanent Representative to the UN Alarcón held several leading offices, such as Vice President of the General Assembly of the United Nations. ==Life and career (1937–1993)== Alarcón was born in [[Havana]] on 21 May 1937. He entered the University of Havana in 1954 and graduated with a degree as a [[Doctor of Philosophy|Doctor of Philosophy and Humanities]].{{Cite book |author1=Lamrani, Salim |author2=Alarcón, Ricardo | title = United States Against Cuba: The War on Terrorism and the Five Case | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=JVAMeNkQfwcC&dq | page = 197 | publisher = Editorial El Viejo Topo | year = 2005 | isbn = 978-84-96356-37-5}} Alarcón became active in the Federation of University Students (FEU), serving as the secretary of culture for the FEU from 1955 to 1956. Alarcón would become active in Castro's [[26th of July Movement]], which was attempting to oust Cuban [[President of Cuba|President]] [[Fulgencio Batista]], in July 1955. Alarcón assisted in the organization of the student apparatus of the guerrilla organization's youth brigade. Alarcón was elected the FEU's Vice President in 1959, and would serve as the President of the Student Organization from 1961 to 1962. However, unlike the Castros, Alarcón was active in the urban underground resistance, and not the guerilla movement located in the countryside.{{Cite book | author = [[Ann Louise Bardach|Bardach, Ann Louise]] | title = Without Fidel: A Death Foretold in Miami, Havana, and Washington | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=5_BCdYfwqGQC&dq | volume = 3 | page = 205 | publisher = [[Simon & Schuster]] | year = 2009 | isbn = 978-1-4165-5150-8 }} In 1962, the new Castro-led government appointed Alarcón as the Director of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' Americas division, where he would begin his diplomatic career. Between 1966 and 1978 he served as Permanent Representative of Cuba to the [[United Nations]], Vice President of the [[General Assembly of the United Nations]], President of the Council of Administration to the United Nations Development Programme, and Vice-President of the United Nations Committee on the Exercise of the Inalienable Rights of the Palestinian People. In 1978 Alarcón was promoted to first vice-minister of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.[http://www.parlamentocubano.cu/ASANAC/espanol/presidente.htm Profile at Cuban parliament website] {{es icon}}. While serving as Permanent Representative to the UN for a second time, Alarcón was [[President of the United Nations Security Council|President of the Security Council]] in February 1990 and July 1991.[https://www.un.org/Depts/dhl/resguide/scpres1990.htm "Presidents of the Security Council : 1990-1999"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121018015052/http://www.un.org/Depts/dhl/resguide/scpres1990.htm |date=October 18, 2012 }}, UN.org. In 1992 was made Minister of Foreign Affairs, and in February 1993 he became the President of the National Assembly. ==President of the National Assembly (1993–2013)== Alarcón took over the office of President of the [[National Assembly of People's Power]] in 1993 in what Ben Corbett, a historian, considered a "demotion" from his earlier post as [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Cuba)|Minister of Foreign Affairs]].{{Cite book | author = Corbett, Ben | title = This Is Cuba: An Outlaw Culture Survives | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=sORNzu-XXfUC&dq | volume = | page = 256 | publisher = [[Basic Books]] | year = 2004 | isbn = 978-0-8133-4224-5}} However, William E. Ratliff and Roger W. Fontaine, in their book, ''A Strategic Flip-flop in the Caribbean: Lift the Embargo on Cuba'', ranks Alarcón as third-most powerful figure in Cuba.{{Cite book |author1=Ratliff, William E. |author2=Fontaine, Roger W. | title = A Strategic Flip-flop in the Caribbean: Lift the Embargo on Cuba | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=fz9jQ99bRe8C&dq | volume = | page = 68 | publisher = [[Hoover Press]] | year = 2000 | isbn = 978-0-8179-4352-3 }} One year after taking office, Alarcón travelled to the United States as the head of a five-member delegation to talk about the migration issues between the two countries. In a Government statement, Alarcón was described as the "best qualified" to deal with such delicate issues as emigration, and his knowledge of the "fundamental causes" to mass emigration from Cuba. Alarcón, along with the Cuba's Government, believes that the [[United States embargo against Cuba|United States economic embargo against Cuba]] is the main blame for the mass emigration from the country.{{cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/08/31/world/flight-from-cuba-cuba-names-leader-for-talks-with-us.html|title=Flight from Cuba; Cuba Names Leader For Talks With U.S.|accessdate=17 February 2011 | location=New York City, New York| work=[[The New York Times]] | date=31 August 1994 }} The negotiations were suspended for a while when he abruptly travelled to Cuba to discuss the situation with the Cuban Government.{{cite news|author=Lewis, Paul|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/09/08/world/us-cuban-talks-suspended-as-envoy-returns-to-havana.html|title=U.S.-Cuban Talks Suspended As Envoy Returns to Havana |accessdate=17 February 2011 | location=New York City, New York| work=[[The New York Times]] | date=8 September 1994 }} After his abrupt visit to Cuba, he returned to the United States and continued the negotiations. When he returned to the United States, he was more positive in tone, and several Cuban officials told the media that an agreement could be reached.{{cite news|author=Golden, Tim|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/09/09/world/cuba-in-shift-says-deal-can-be-reached-with-the-us.html|title=Cuba, in Shift, Says Deal Can Be Reached With the U.S. |accessdate=17 February 2011 | location=New York City, New York| work=[[The New York Times]] | page = 1| date=9 September 1994 }} Alarcón was able to reach an agreement with the [[United States Government]] on 9 September 1994, and the United States promised to issue at least 20,000 immigrant visas a year for Cuban citizens seeking to leave their homeland.{{cite news|author=Golden, Tim|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/09/22/world/cuban-official-criticizes-lag-by-the-us-in-issuing-visas.html|title=Cuban Official Criticizes Lag By the U.S. in Issuing Visas. |accessdate=17 February 2011 | location=New York City, New York| work=[[The New York Times]] | page = | date=22 September 1994 }} In August 2000, Alarcón was involved in a minor dispute with the United States when he was denied a visa to attend an international conference in [[New York City]]. Alarcón lived in [[Manhattan]] for over twelve years but because of his status as a Cuban government official he is only allowed within a 25-mile radius of the United Nations.{{cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/901925.stm|title=Cuban politician denied US visa|accessdate=17 February 2011 | location=London, United Kingdom| publisher=[[BBC Online]] | page = | date=29 August 2000 }} On 2 December 2003, United States [[Under Secretary for Arms Control and International Security]] [[John R. Bolton]] charged that Cuba, along with [[Iran]], [[North Korea]], [[Syria]], and [[Libya]], were "[[rogue state]]s...whose pursuit of [[weapons of mass destruction]] makes them hostile to U.S. interests [and who] will learn that their covert programs will not escape either detection or consequences." In response, Alarcón called Bolton "a liar" and cited US claims pertaining to [[Iraq]]'s [[Iraq and weapons of mass destruction|weapons of mass destruction]] in justification of the [[2003 invasion of Iraq|Iraq War]] which were later found to be incorrect.{{cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2003/dec/31/20031231-111715-9034r/|title=Cuban leader sees invasion risk as ‘real’|accessdate=17 February 2011 | location=New York City, New York| work=[[The New York Times]] | page = | date=31 December 2003 }} In 2006, Alarcón stated: "At some moment, US rhetoric changed to talk of democracy... For me, the starting point is the recognition that democracy should begin with [[Pericles]]'s definition – that society is for the benefit of the majority – and should not be imposed from outside."{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/cuba/story/0,,1836031,00.html|title=Propaganda war grips a land crippled by shortages|author=Campbell, Duncan |accessdate=17 February 2011 | location=London, United Kingdom | work=[[The Guardian]] | date=3 August 2006}} During [[Fidel Castro]]'s [[2006–2008 Cuban transfer of presidential duties|transfer of presidential duties]] to his brother [[Raúl Castro]], Alarcón told the foreign media that Fidel would be fit to run for re-election to the assembly in [[Cuban legislative election, 2008|January 2008 parliamentary election]].{{cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/6456747.stm|title=Castro 'to be fit to hold power'|accessdate=17 February 2011 | location=London, United Kingdom | publisher=[[BBC Online]] | date=15 March 2007}} However, in an interview with the [[CNN]], Alarcón said he was unsure if Fidel would accept the post or not.{{cite news|author=Lacey, Marc|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=950DEFDA1E3BF930A15752C0A96E9C8B63&|title=The Americas; Cuba: Will Castro Return? |accessdate=17 February 2011 | location=New York City, New York| work=[[The New York Times]] | page = | date=23 January 2008 }} Alarcón, in an interview on the topic on who would succeed Fidel Castro, said; "All those who have been trying to fool the world and put out the idea that something terrible would happen in Cuba, that people would take to the streets, that there would be great instability, the door slammed on them and they must have very swollen hands now".{{cite news|author=Miller, Jimmy|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/1525878/Succession-talk-fuels-the-Cuban-rumour-mill.html|title=Succession talk fuels the Cuban rumour mill |accessdate=17 February 2011 | location=London, United Kingdom| work=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] | date=8 August 2008 }} ==Family== Alarcon was married to Margarita Perea Maza. She died on 9 February 2008.''The Miami Herald''; "Wife of Cuban Official Dies After Long Illness"; 12 February 2008, Page 7A ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== *Ricardo Alarcón and Reinaldo Suarez, ''Cuba y Su Democracia'' (Editorial de Ciencias Sociales 2004) {{ISBN|987-1158-06-8}} *Fidel Castro and Ricardo Alarcón, ''EE.UU. fuera del oriente medio'' (Pathfinder Press 2001) {{ISBN|0-87348-625-0}} *Ricardo Alarcón and Mary Murray ''Cuba and the United States : an interview with Cuban Foreign Minister, Ricardo Alaron'' (Ocean Press 1992) {{ISBN|1-875284-69-9}} ==External links== {{Portal|Cuba}} *[http://www.pcc.cu/pccweb/glosario/personalidades/alarcon.php Official Biography] – ''Cuban Communist Party''. *[http://www.parlamentocubano.cu/ASANAC/espanol/presidente.htm Official Biography] – ''Cuban National Assembly''. {{S-start}} {{S-off}} {{Succession box| before = [[Isidoro Malmierca Peoli]] | title = [[Foreign relations of Cuba|Foreign Minister of Cuba]]|years=1992–1993| after = [[Roberto Robaina Gonzalez]]}} {{Succession box| title = [[National Assembly of People’s Power of Cuba|President of Cuban National Assembly]] | before = [[Juan Escalona Reguera]] | after = [[Esteban Lazo Hernández]] | years = 1993–2013}} {{S-dip}} {{Succession box| title = Permanent Representative of Cuba to the [[United Nations]]| before = ? | after = [[Alcibiades Hidalgo]] | years = 1966–1992 }} {{S-end}} {{CubanFMs}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Alarcon, Ricardo}} [[Category:Cuban diplomats]] [[Category:Cuban revolutionaries]] [[Category:1937 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Foreign ministers of Cuba]] [[Category:Presidents of the National Assembly of People's Power]] [[Category:Permanent Representatives of Cuba to the United Nations]] [[Category:Communist Party of Cuba politicians]] [[Category:People of the Cuban Revolution]] [[Category:People from Havana]] [[Category:1980s in Cuba]] [[Category:1990s in Cuba]] [[Category:2000s in Cuba]] [[Category:20th-century Cuban politicians]] [[Category:21st-century Cuban politicians]]

{{Other uses| Rima (disambiguation)}} {{refimprove|date=June 2014}} [[Image:RimaCI.jpg|right|thumb|Rima as first glimpsed by Abel (and comic book readers) in the 1951 ''[[Classics Illustrated]]'' adaptation, published in 1952]] '''Rima''', also known as '''Rima the Jungle Girl''', is the fictional heroine of [[William Henry Hudson|W. H. Hudson's]] 1904 novel ''[[Green Mansions|Green Mansions: A Romance of the Tropical Forest]]''. In it, Rima, a [[Jungle girl (stock character)|primitive girl]] of the shrinking rain forest of South America, meets Abel, a political fugitive. A movie of ''[[Green Mansions (film)|Green Mansions]]'' was made in 1959 starring [[Audrey Hepburn]]. In 1974, the character was adapted into the [[comic book]] ''Rima the Jungle Girl'', published by [[DC Comics]]. Though ''Rima the Jungle Girl'' ceased publication in 1975, the comic book version of Rima appeared in several episodes of [[Hanna-Barbera|Hanna-Barbera's]] popular [[Saturday morning cartoon]] series, ''[[Superfriends|The All-New Superfriends Hour]]'', between 1977 and 1980. [[File:Charcoal and chalk drawing of Audrey Hepburn.jpg|right|thumb|200px|Rima the Jungle Girl was played by Audrey Hepburn in the 1959 film ''Green Mansions.'']] ==Novel== Like her literary cousins [[Tarzan]] and [[Mowgli]], Rima sprang from an Edwardian adventure novel; in her case, ''[[Green Mansions|Green Mansions: A Romance of the Tropical Forest]]'', by [[William Henry Hudson|W. H. Hudson]], published in 1904. Hudson was an Argentine-British naturalist who wrote many classic books about the ecology of South America. Hudson based Rima on a South American legend about a lost tribe of white people who lived in the mountains.{{cite web |first=Rob | last=Schmidt |url=http://newspaperrock.bluecorncomics.com/2009/11/rima-native-white-girl.htm |title=Rima the "Native" white girl |work=Newspaper Rock |publisher=[[BlueCornComics.com]]|date=November 11, 2009|accessdate=May 28, 2014}} The book has a religious tone and Rima's speech is poetic.[https://books.google.com/books?id=y0E5QtomF2QC&dq=editions:mc7vmAI5TVcC&source=gbs_navlinks_s Google Books About page for the 1989 edition.] It is a romantic adventure set in the South American jungle in which a political fugitive named Abel meets Rima, a girl living in the forest.[https://books.google.com/books?id=MUmgAAAAMAAJ&dq=editions:mc7vmAI5TVcC&source=gbs_navlinks_s Google Books About Page of the 1943 edition.] Its theme is the loss of wilderness and the return-to-nature dream, and how unpleasant it would be for a savage to meet modern man (the reverse case is not considered).[https://books.google.com/books?id=LFMRAAAAYAAJ&dq=editions:mc7vmAI5TVcC&source=gbs_navlinks_s Google Books About page of 1916 edition.] ==Movie== Actor and director [[Mel Ferrer]] adapted ''[[Green Mansions (film)|Green Mansions]]'' into a 1959 film for [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer|MGM Studios]], with Audrey Hepburn as Rima.[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0052864/fullcredits?ref_=tt_ov_st_sm IMDB, Green Mansions (1959), Full Cast & Crew] The adaptation deviated far from the novel. ==Comic books== {{Superherobox | image =[[Image:Rima6ms.jpg|200px]] | caption = ''Rima the Jungle Girl'' #6 (March 1975). Art by [[Nestor Redondo]]. | character_name = Rima | publisher = [[DC Comics]] | debut = '''Historical:''' 1904
'''Modern:''' 1974 | creators = [[William Henry Hudson|W. H. Hudson]] | alter_ego = | full_name = | species = | homeworld = | alliances = | partners = | aliases = | supports= | powers = }} Rima starred in a seven-issue [[comic book]] series, [[DC Comics]]' ''Rima the Jungle Girl'' (May 1974 – May 1975), adapted by an uncredited writer and with artwork by [[penciler]]-[[inker]] [[Nestor Redondo]] and covers by [[Joe Kubert]]. DC writer-editor [[Robert Kanigher]] is the credited writer from issue #5 on. A variation of the character debuted in a six-issue DC Comics limited series May 2010 to Mar 2011 ''[[First Wave (comics)|First Wave]]'', written by Eisner Award–winning writer Brian Azzarello. Rima is here portrayed as a South American native with piercings and tattoos; she does not speak, but instead communicates in bird-like whistles.{{cite web |first=Alex |last=Segura |url=http://dcu.blog.dccomics.com/2009/11/09/how-about-some-more-rags-morales%E2%80%99-sketches-from-first-wave/ |title=How About Some More Rags Morales' Sketches From First Wave? |work=The Source |publisher=[[DC Comics.com]] |date=November 9, 2009 |accessdate=November 10, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20110721151342/http://dcu.blog.dccomics.com/2009/11/09/how-about-some-more-rags-morales%E2%80%99-sketches-from-first-wave/ |archivedate=July 21, 2011 |df= }} Although the DC character is a fully grown and powerful woman with [[Blond#platinum blond|ash blonde]] hair, the novel's Rima was 17, small (4′ 6″), demure, and dark-haired. Natives avoided her forest, calling her "the Daughter of the Didi" (an evil spirit). Rima's only defense was a reputation for magic earned through the display of strange talents such as talking to birds, befriending animals, and plucking poison darts from the air. Although in the original book Rima was burned alive by Indian savages, in the comics she escaped the fire to have further adventures. ===Comic book titles=== These [[comic book]] titles feature the Rima character: ====''Classics Illustrated'' #90: ''Green Mansions''==== [[Classics Illustrated]] published a short adaptation from the novel, with direct quotes. In this adaptation Rima is blond. (Copyright December 1951 Gilberton Company). ====''Rima the Jungle Girl''==== Title character 1974–1975 ====''The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen''==== Rima is mentioned, but not seen, in [[America's Best Comics]]' ''[[The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen]]'' vol. 2, #3 (2003), by writer [[Alan Moore]] and artists [[Kevin O'Neill (comics)|Kevin O'Neill]] and [[Ben Dimagmaliw]]: "...it is near here that the world-famous 'bird girl' Riolama or Rima was discovered..." ====''First Wave''==== Rima is re-imagined in DC's 2010 title ''[[First Wave (comics)|First Wave]]''. ==Cartoons== Rima the Jungle Girl appeared in three episodes of [[Hanna-Barbera]]'s ''[[The All-New Super Friends Hour]]'' during the 1977–78 season, alongside such mainstays as [[Aquaman]], [[Batman]], and [[Wonder Woman]]. In her run with the ''Super Friends'' TV series, she is often known for being one of the new 'affirmative action heroes' during that period. Along with characters [[Apache Chief]], [[Black Vulcan]], and [[Samurai (Super Friends)|Samurai]], Rima is considered a minority character. She first appears in "Fire" (October 1, 1977). [[Batman]], [[Robin (comics)|Robin]], and Rima the Jungle Girl contend with a spreading forest fire, and have to search for a pair of escaped prisoners who have stolen a forestry truck filled with dynamite. Rima's main contribution is to call upon a nearby bear to push down some trees for an emergency bridge across a wide gap. Her next appearance is in "River of Doom" (November 4, 1977): [[Wonder Woman]] and Rima the Jungle Girl search for archaeologists who have accidentally stumbled onto a burial ground of angry natives. The archaeologists are captured and sentenced to death on the River of Doom. The superheroes find the would-be victims by using indigenous animals to scout them out at Rima's command. They later rescue the scientists. Rima's main contribution is summoning [[crocodile]]s to attack their pursuers' canoes. Finally, she is featured in "Return of Atlantis", from October 25, 1980. Aquaman is captured by Queen Ocina when the lost city of [[Atlantis (DC Comics)|Atlantis]] rises from the sea. Ocina plans to conquer the world with her female warriors, but Wonder Woman and Rima gather the Amazons of [[Themyscira (DC Comics)|Paradise Island]] to stop her. Note: In breach of both DC Comics' and the ''Super Friends'' TV show's continuities, this "Atlantis" is not the kingdom over which [[Aquaman]] reigns. ==Other appearances== Rima was mentioned in [[Ray Bradbury]]'s 1950 short story, "[[The Veldt (short story)|The Veldt]]". Rima was also mentioned in "Watcher in the Shadows" by Geoffrey Household (1960; reissued 2010) and also in "Vane Pursuit" by Charlotte MacLeod (1989). [[Dornford Yates]] mentioned her in Chapter I of his 1931 comic-detective novel ''Adele and Co.'', in connection with the Hudson Memorial (see below). ===Statue=== The Hudson Memorial in London's [[Hyde Park, London|Hyde Park]], created in 1925, has a [[bas-relief]] of Rima the Bird Girl sculpted by [[Jacob Epstein]].http://londonist.com/2013/09/the-day-peter-pan-was-tarred-and-feathered.php Image of statue with history of praise and criticism ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{gcdb series|id=2152|title=Rima the Jungle Girl}} * {{comicbookdb|type=character|id=20213|title=Rima the Jungle Girl}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20091027125906/http://www.geocities.com/jessnevins/vicr.html Fantastic Victoriana: R] by [[Jess Nevins]] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050223122449/http://www.oakmeadow.com/curric/Lit/Mansions.txt Full Text of the Novel: Green Mansions] {{Superfriends series}} [[Category:American superheroes]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 1904]] [[Category:Comics characters introduced in 1974]] [[Category:1974 comics debuts]] [[Category:Comics based on novels]] [[Category:Comics adapted into animated series]] [[Category:Comics adapted into television series]] [[Category:Comics set in South America]] [[Category:DC Comics superheroes]] [[Category:DC Comics titles]] [[Category:Fantasy comics]] [[Category:Jungle (genre) comics]] [[Category:Jungle girls]] [[Category:Fictional activists]] [[Category:Fictional orphans]] [[Category:Film characters]] [[Category:Super Friends characters]] [[Category:Fictional feral children]] [[Category:Fictional characters who use magic]] [[Category:Female characters in comics]]

{{multiple issues| {{BLP sources|date=January 2016}} {{orphan|date=January 2016}} }} '''Robert D. Austin''' (born 1962) is an innovation and technology management researcher and professor of Management of Innovation and [[Digital transformation|Digital Transformation]] at [[Copenhagen Business School|Copenhagen Business School (CBS)]], Copenhagen, Denmark.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Robert Austin - CBS - Copenhagen Business School|url = http://www.cbs.dk/en/research/departments-and-centres/department-of-management-politics-and-philosophy/staff/rampp#publications|website = CBS - Copenhagen Business School|accessdate = 2016-01-08}}</ref> He is best known for pedagogical innovations in the teaching of [[technology management]], and for his "artful making" research, which examines business innovation through the lens of art practice. He is also an adjunct research professor at the [[Ivey Business School]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Rob Austin {{!}} Faculty & Research {{!}} Ivey Business School|url = http://www.ivey.uwo.ca/faculty/directory/rob-austin/|website = www.ivey.uwo.ca|access-date = 2016-01-12}}</ref>
== Biography == Austin received bachelor's degrees in [[English literature|English Literature]] and [[Engineering]] from [[Swarthmore College]] in 1984, a master’s in [[Industrial engineering|Industrial Engineering]] and [[Management science|Management Science]] from [[Northwestern University]] in 1986, and a [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] in Management and Decision Sciences from [[Carnegie Mellon University|Carnegie Mellon University (CMU)]] in 1995. His doctoral thesis was the recipient of the Herbert A. Simon Doctoral Dissertation Award for Behavioral Research in the Administrative Sciences.
From 1997 to 2009, Austin was a professor of business administration at [[Harvard Business School]], working primarily in the area of Technology and Operations Management.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Coursera - Free Online Courses From Top Universities|url = https://www.coursera.org/instructor/robausting|website = Coursera|access-date = 2016-01-12|language = en-US}}</ref> He joined the [[Copenhagen Business School|Copenhagen Business School (CBS)]] faculty in 2007. He has also spent time as a manager at the [[Ford Motor Company]] (1986-1995), a member of the executive team of a startup subsidiary of Novell (1999-2000), the CEO of an executive education foundation (2010-2011), and dean of the faculty of business administration at the [[University of New Brunswick]] at Fredericton (2011-2013).
He is the author of more than 70 published articles, cases, and notes, and eight books.
==Selected publications== * Austin, Robert D. Measuring and Managing Performance in Organizations, New York: Dorset House, 1996. * Austin, Robert D. and Lee Devin. Artful Making: What Managers Need to Know About How Artists Work, Upper Saddle River, NJ: Financial Times Prentice Hall, 2003. * Austin, Robert D., Nolan, Richard L. and Shannon O'Donnell, Adventures of an IT Leader, Harvard Business Review Press, 2009.<ref>{{Cite web|title = The adventures of an IT leader - Research@CBS|url = http://research.cbs.dk/en/publications/uuid(03c3e310-5ee3-11de-835c-000ea68e967b).html|website = research.cbs.dk|accessdate = 2016-01-08}}</ref> * Austin, Robert D., Devin, Lee, and Erin E. Sullivan, "Accidental Innovation: Supporting Valuable Unpredictability in Creative Process,” Organization Science, September/October 2012 vol. 23 no. 5, 1505-1522.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Accidental Innovation - Research@CBS|url = http://research.cbs.dk/en/publications/uuid(e1594e42-47ab-4178-b4d2-558252c7667d).html|website = research.cbs.dk|accessdate = 2016-01-08}}</ref> * Austin, Robert D. "The Dandelion Principle: Redesigning Work for the Innovation Economy," MIT Sloan Management Review, Summer 2014.<ref>{{Cite web|title = The Dandelion Principle - Research@CBS|url = http://research.cbs.dk/en/publications/uuid(55571533-8591-41f0-bee5-e5eba4529844).html|website = research.cbs.dk|accessdate = 2016-01-08}}</ref>

{{redirect|Fenton Aylmer}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox military person | honorific_prefix= | name =Sir Fenton John Aylmer | honorific_suffix=Bt VC | image =Fenton Aylmer VC.jpg | image_size =125 | caption =Lieutenant General Sir Fenton John Aylmer, 13th Baronet of Donadea VC KCB | birth_date ={{Birth date|df=yes|1862|04|05}} | death_date ={{Death date and age|df=yes|1935|09|03|1862|04|05}} | placeofburial_label = | placeofburial = [[Golders Green]], [[London]] | birth_place =[[Hastings]], [[Sussex]] | death_place =Lingfield Road, [[Wimbledon, London|Wimbledon]], [[Surrey]] | placeofburial_coordinates = | nickname = | allegiance ={{UK}} | branch ={{army|United Kingdom}} | serviceyears =1880–1919 | rank =[[File:British Army (1920-1953) OF-8.svg|23px]] [[Lieutenant General]] | unit =[[Corps of Royal Engineers]] | commands = {{plainlist| *[[III Corps (India)|Tigris Corps]] *Commandant, Royal Engineers }} | battles = {{plainlist| *[[Burmese resistance movement 1885–95]] *[[Hunza–Nagar Campaign]] *[[Chitral Expedition]] *[[First World War]] ([[Mesopotamian campaign]]) *Battle of Sheikh Sa'ad *[[Siege of Kut]] *Battle of Hanna) *[[Battle of Dujaila|Dujaila Redoubt]] *Sinn Abtar Redoubt }} | awards =[[Victoria Cross]]
[[Knight Commander of the Order of the Bath]] | relations =Elsie Julie Oppermann (wife) | laterwork = }} [[Lieutenant-general (United Kingdom)|Lieutenant-General]] '''Sir Fenton John Aylmer, 13th Baronet''', [[Victoria Cross|VC]], [[Order of the Bath|KCB]] (5 April 1862 – 3 September 1935) was an [[Anglo-Irish]] recipient of the [[Victoria Cross]]. He was in command of the first failed efforts to break the [[siege of Kut]] in 1916. From a military background, Aylmer was commissioned into the Indian Army, and immediately involved in fierce fighting on the north-west frontier. In a singularly heroic action, still in his twenties, he helped rescue Townshend's garrison at [[Chitral]], spearheading the relief column. For his valorous conduct he was awarded the Victoria Cross, and rapid promotion through the officer class. ==Early career== Born the son of Captain Fenton John Aylmer (24 December 1835 – 9 April 1862) and Isabella Eleanor Darling (died 27 December 1908).{{cite web |url=http://thepeerage.com/p12792.htm#i127917 |title=Lt.-Gen. Sir Fenton John Aylmer, 13th Bt., V.C. |work=The Peerage |date=29 January 2011 }} Aylmer attended the [[Royal Military Academy, Woolwich]], as a Gentleman Cadet and was promoted [[Lieutenant]] on 27 July 1880.{{London Gazette|issue=24870|page=4258|date=3 August 1880}} He took part in the Burma expedition between 1886 and 1887.[http://www.kcl.ac.uk/lhcma/locreg/AYLMER1.shtml Liddell Hart Centre for Military Archives] ==The Victoria Cross== Fenton was 29 years old, and a [[Captain (British Army and Royal Marines)|captain]] in the [[Corps of Royal Engineers]], [[British Army]] and [[Bengal Sappers & Miners]] ([[British Indian Army]]),[http://www.victoriacross.org.uk/ccroyeng.htm The Royal Engineers Museum - Victoria Crosses held by the Royal Engineers Museum] during the [[Hunza–Nagar Campaign]], India when he won the [[Victoria Cross]] in 1891 for the following deed: {{Quote|On 2 December 1891 during the assault on [[Nilt Fort]], [[British India]], Captain Aylmer, with the storming party, forced open the inner gate with gun-cotton which he had placed and ignited, and although severely wounded, fired 19 shots with his revolver, killing several of the enemy, and remained fighting until, fainting from loss of blood, he was carried out of action.{{London Gazette|issue=26306|page=4006|date=12 July 1892}}}} He was promoted [[Major]] on 18 October 1893 in recognition of his services during the Hunza-Nagar Expedition,{{London Gazette|issue=26450|page=5833|date=17 October 1893}} and was part of the [[Chitral Expedition]] in 1895. Further service with the Royal Engineers saw him promoted a [[Brevet (military)|brevet]] [[Lieutenant-colonel (British Army)|Lieutenant-colonel]]. In July 1901 he was appointed Assistant [[Quartermaster general]] in India, and promoted to the substantive rank of [[Colonel (British Army)|Colonel]].{{London Gazette |issue=27383 |date=6 December 1901 |page=8642}} Ten years later, in March 1912, having been promoted to [[major-general]], he became [[Adjutant-General (India)|Adjutant-General, India]].[http://www.gulabin.com/armynavy/pdf/Army%20Commands%201900-2011.pdf Army Commands] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150705000000/http://www.gulabin.com/armynavy/pdf/Army%20Commands%201900-2011.pdf |date=5 July 2015 }} In 1913 he married Lady Risley, the widow of Sir Herbert Risley, head of the Indian Civil Service. Born Elsie Julie Oppermann, daughter of Friedrich Oppermann, she was considered a great beauty and had, for many years prior to her marriage to him had an affair with Aylmer—an affair that was well-known within Indian society and apparently tolerated by Sir Herbert. Lady Aylmer died on 18 July 1934. ==World War I== Having been promoted to [[lieutenant general]], Aylmer was put in charge of the first effort to end the [[siege of Kut]]. General Aylmer was in command of the [[Tigris Corps]], consisting of the [[7th (Meerut) Division]], the [[12th Indian Division]], and a number of other smaller military units. All told he had more than 20,000 men. They left [[Basra]] in late December 1915 and arrived at Sheikh Sa'ad on 3 January 1916.Tucker, p. 1,233 While the 12th Indian Division (under command of General [[GF Gorringe|George Gorringe]]) made a diversionary move near Nasiriyeh, the 7th (under the command of General Younghusband) staged a direct assault on the Ottoman positions on 6 January (the [[Battle of Sheikh Sa'ad]]). After two days of fighting, the Ottoman army withdrew. The British sustained approximately 4,000 casualties - much more than the medical units could cope with. The Ottoman troops, under the generalship of [[Colmar Freiherr von der Goltz|Baron von der Goltz]] only withdrew some six miles up river and occupied another defensive position near the edge of the Suwaikiya Marshes. A British assault on this position on 13 January was partially successful, the position was carried but again with significant losses (some 1,600 casualties) (the Battle of Wadi). By now, a third division had been added to Aylmer's Tigris Corps, the [[3rd (Lahore) Division]]. This new division, along with the weakened 7th Division, attacked Ottoman defensive works at Hanna on 21 January (the [[Battle of Hanna]]). This assault was a complete failure. The Ottoman troops held their trench lines while some 2,700 British soldiers were killed or wounded. General Aylmer was reinforced with another division, the [[13th (Western) Division]]. The next month was spent resting the troops and probing the Ottoman defensive positions. With time running out on Major-General [[Charles Vere Ferrers Townshend|Townshend]]'s garrison in [[Kut]], Aylmer finally launched a two pronged attack on the Ottoman positions, one attack at the Sinn Abtar Redoubt, the other attack at the [[Battle of Dujaila|Dujaila Redoubt]]. The attacks were launched on 7 March 1916. Both attacks failed due to lack of initiative and an inability to coordinate the timing of the assaults: they ended up being sequential, not simultaneous as was intended. The British lost some 4,000 casualties. Fenton Aylmer was replaced by the former commander of the 12th Indian division, Major-General [[GF Gorringe|George Gorringe]]. He did not command in battle again, retiring from the British Army in 1919. However, from 1922 till his death he was the Commandant of the [[Royal Engineers]]. Following his death in 1935 he was cremated at the [[Golders Green Crematorium]] where his ashes remain.[https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/6821519 Fenton John Aylmer] at Find-A-Grave His Victoria Cross is displayed at the [[Royal Engineers Museum]] in [[Chatham, Kent]], England. ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==Sources== *{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TogXVHTlxG4C&pg=PA1233&lpg=PA1233&dq=The+Attempt+to+Relieve+Kut,+1916+Aylmer&source=bl&ots=OoGp7gneY6&sig=yM_Haf2sinqes0dR2nNzjbyJsLo&hl=en&sa=X&ei=MH8ZUaGmCYWH0AXY3YCIBw&ved=0CFAQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=The%20Attempt%20to%20Relieve%20Kut%2C%201916%20Aylmer&f=false|last=Tucker|first=Spencer C.|title=World War 1|publisher=Routledge|year=1997|isbn=978-1857283914}} *[[Irish Winners of the Victoria Cross]] (Richard Doherty & David Truesdale, 2000) *[[Monuments to Courage]] (David Harvey, 1999) *[[The Register of the Victoria Cross]] (This England, 1997) *[[The Sapper VCs]] (Gerald Napier, 1998) ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060810230716/http://www.remuseum.org.uk/rem_his_vc.htm#1a Royal Engineers Museum] Sappers VCs *[https://web.archive.org/web/20051120154659/http://www.victoriacross.org.uk/golders.htm Burial location of Fenton Aylmer] "Golders Green Crematorium, London" *[http://www.victoriacross.org.uk/ccroyeng.htm Location of Fenton Aylmer's Victoria Cross] "Royal Engineers Museum, Gillingham" *[http://www.1914-1918.net/meso_bat9.htm The Attempt to Relieve Kut, 1916] - from The Long, Long March website, downloaded January, 2006. {{s-start}} {{s-mil}} {{s-bef|before=[[Arthur Barrett (Indian Army officer)|Sir Arthur Barrett]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Adjutant-General (India)|Adjutant-General, India]]|years=1912–1915}} {{s-aft|after=[[John Walter (Indian Army officer)|John Walter]]}} |- {{s-reg|ie-bt}} {{succession box | title=[[Aylmer baronets|Baronet]]
'''of Donadea''' | years=1928–1935 | before= Arthur Percy FitzGerald Aylmer | after=Gerald Arthur Evans-Freke Aylmer}} {{s-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Aylmer, Fenton}} [[Category:1862 births]] [[Category:1935 deaths]] [[Category:Anglo-Irish people]] [[Category:Baronets in the Baronetage of Ireland]] [[Category:People from Hastings]] [[Category:British recipients of the Victoria Cross]] [[Category:British Army generals of World War I]] [[Category:British military personnel of the Chitral Expedition]] [[Category:Knights Commander of the Order of the Bath]] [[Category:Royal Engineers officers]] [[Category:Bengal Sappers and Miners personnel]] [[Category:British military personnel of the Hunza-Naga Campaign]] [[Category:British Army recipients of the Victoria Cross]] [[Category:Golders Green Crematorium]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2016}} {{Use British English|date=May 2016}} [[File:Starsuckers.jpg|thumb|''Starsuckers'' poster]]
'''''Starsuckers''''' is a 2009 British documentary film aiming to expose the "shams and deceit involved in creating a pernicious [[celebrity culture]]".
Directed by [[Chris Atkins (journalist)|Chris Atkins]], director of the 2007 documentary ''[[Taking Liberties (film)|Taking Liberties]]'', it shows the production team planting a variety of celebrity-related stories in the [[UK media]], such as a claim that the singer [[Avril Lavigne]] had been seen asleep in a [[nightclub]]. A variety of [[tabloid newspaper]]s accepted the stories without corroboration or evidence.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/oct/14/starsuckers-tabloids-hoax-celebrities Starsuckers celebrity hoax dupes tabloids], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 14 October 2009,</ref>
The film launched as part of the [[British Film Institute]]'s 53rd Film Festival. Thirty minutes of footage from the film were shown to the [[Leveson Inquiry]] as part of the evidence presented by the film's director, Chris Atkins.<ref>{{cite news |title=Leveson inquiry: Chris Atkins, David Leigh, Charlotte Harris - live |author=Lisa O'Carroll and Josh Halliday |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/blog/2011/dec/06/leveson-inquiry-leigh-atkins-harris-live |newspaper=The Guardian |date=6 December 2011 |accessdate=6 December 2011}}</ref>
==Legal threats from Max Clifford==
On 23 October 2009, six days before the ''Starsuckers'' premiere, the makers reported that they had received an e-mail from the law firm [[Carter-Ruck]], acting on behalf of controversial [[publicist]] [[Max Clifford]] and threatening them with an [[injunction]].<ref>http://starsuckers3.blogspot.com/2009/10/weve-been-carter-fcked.html</ref><ref>http://www.indexoncensorship.org/2010/04/starsucker-uk-media-culture/</ref>
==Criminal convictions==
In December 2015, three [[City of London|City]] traders, James Hyde, Hamish Maclellan, and Phillip Jenkins, along with their accountant Terence Potter, were convicted of conspiring to cheat [[HMRC|HM Revenue & Customs]] by falsifying documents to show that they had each actively worked 10 or more hours a week on the production of Starsuckers and were eligible for tax rebates. Three other defendants were acquitted at the same trial.<ref>http://citywire.co.uk/new-model-adviser/news/ex-adviser-found-guilty-of-conspiracy-to-cheat-hmrc/a866698</ref>
In June 2016, two further producers of Starsuckers, Christopher Walsh Atkins and Christina Slater, were convicted of the same charge of conspiring to cheat HM Revenue & Customs, and were jailed for 5 and 4 years respectively.<ref>https://www.judiciary.gov.uk/wp-content/uploads/2016/07/r-v-walsh-atkins-and-slater.pdf</ref> Terence Potter was again convicted.<ref>http://courtnewsuk.co.uk/film-producers-guilty-movie-investment-scam</ref>
==See also== * [[Narcissism]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * http://www.starsuckersmovie.com * {{IMDb title|1510934}} * [http://www.screendaily.com/festivals/other-festivals/festival-news/london-film-festival-boosts-awards-for-53rd-edition/5005421.article ''Screen Daily''] * [http://ukscreen.com/news/clooney-in-triplicate-at-the-london-film-festival UK screen]
